downtempo, and even a breaks track.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] VRR: Otherworld to be demolished

I look at it this way (as I did w/ punk) - there will ALWAYS be a core group 
of folks into the sound/scene. Sometimes the popularity will be high, 
sometimes low. You take the good with the bad. But I hardly think the 
electronic or "rave" scene is gonna die out any time soon. The drop off in 
popularity started back in 2001 already. Here we are at the close of 2005. 
Is the scene dead? No. Is it gone? No. Are there still fans? Yes. Are there 
new kids? Maybe not as many as flooded the scene in '99, but I seem to 
recall (at least on the East Coast) all the old skoolers being mad when the 
scene became commercially available to the mass consumer market, so should 
we care?? The music and scene aren't going away - they're just changing as 
EVERYTHING does.
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, November 30, 2005 7:13 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] VRR: Otherworld to be demolished


I think the formulaic cookie-cutter approach to production is much
more detrimental to our scene's popularity among them dagnabbed
younguns (and their alleged segment) than any marketing scheme.

Pendulum put drum and bass back in the UK's Top 40 with "Slam" earlier
this year. That track owes more to Motley Crue and George Clinton than
it does to anything within d&b proper. They weren't like, gosh, how
can we get d&b into the Top 40? They just did something totally
bizarre and unexpected which seemed perfectly logical to them. (Which
is actually very typical of Australian musicians -- INXS, Men Without
Hats, etc.)

Music is like technology -- a marketing budget is a sign of a bad
product. Focus on quality, that's the only thing that matters. If your
product is the best availabe, you'll be overwhelmed by people who want
it.

By the way, I skipped this thread earlier, and I didn't see that
picture of Sameer. I have to admit I'm utterly terrified to see how
much he resembles George Will. I have to take back that stuff
endorsing him as a Presidential candidate, because those fashion
decisions are just unsupportable.

> > > > On 11/30/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > > > > Well - considering the punk scene was dead by the mid 80's - I'd 
> > > > > say
> > the
> > > > > corporate scene was just capitalizing on an image/sound.
> > > > >
> > > > > What amuses me is how EVERY music scene likes to act like they're
> > all
> > > > > accepting and love to welcome new people into the group. The 
> > > > > reality
> > is
> > > -
> > > > > every music "scene" is cliquey in it's own regard. I have had 
> > > > > punks
> > look
> > > > > down their nose at me for getting into "rave" music, and vice 
> > > > > versa.
> > It
> > > > > works that way across the board. Shit - in the rave scene, it even
> > gets
> > > > > cliquey in regards to what GENRE you like.
> > > > >
> > > > > The notion that we should be educating new folks is nice and all -
> > but
> > > can
> > > > > you remember back to when you were a young, impressionable kid
> > getting
> > > > > into
> > > > > something? How would you have felt with some "old" person telling
> > you
> > > > > about
> > > > > "how it was" and "how it should be", etc.? Half the time it's that
> > sort
> > > of
> > > > > thing that turns people off. Being made to felt like you missed 
> > > > > out
> > on
> > > > > some
> > > > > grand era and now to be accepted you must suddenly fit some
> > mold/adhere
> > > to
> > > > > some "rule", etc.
> > > > >
> > > > > LAME.
> > > > >
> > > > > It's one thing if people are inquisitive and truly interested in
> > > > > something -
> > > > > but what you're suggesting is along the lines of raver 
> > > > > recruitment.
> > > Again
> > > > > I
> > > > > say - let them figure it out on their own. That's how most of us
> > wound
> > > up
> > > > > in
> > > > > whatever scene we got into (or in the case of folks like myself, 
> > > > > how
> > > they
> > > > > got into EVERY music scene they're into). Sure - if you know some
> > newbie
> > > > > you
> > > > > should maybe suggest things, but I honestly think people should
> > figure
> > > > > shit
> > > > > out on their own so they don't have some slanted viewpoint to work
> > off
> > > of.
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > > > From: "Sean G" <rationalhatter@gmail.com>
> > > > > To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com >

> > > > >

> > > > > punk/hardcore and allowed it to be coopted by corporate culture. 
> > > > > Go
> > grab
> > > > > that kid on the corner in a plaid kilt, doc martins, and a
> > > factory-sealed
> > > > > mohawk and ask if he's ever heard of joy division.
> > > > >
> > > > > If you aren't trying, you aren't a raver. You're just a hater who

> > > > > drum

> > > > >

> > > > > > You know - I've always heard the "old guys hould teach the new
> > guys"
> > > > > > thing
> > > > > > for YEARS. Back when I was into the punk/hardcore scene, it was
> > the
> > > same
> > > > > > way.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Bottom line is, most people are fucking morons. Sheep. Happy to
> > suck
> > > the
> > > > > > corporate teat and jump on any bandwagon they can.Those are the
> > > > > > "thizzing"
> > > > > > fools that most of us like to avoid like the fucking plague. 
> > > > > > Nice
> > > times
> > > > > > out
> > > > > > of ten, those folks will never "get" the scene (much less 
> > > > > > anything
> > > > > > else).
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I say - let the smart folks find their way - those are the 
> > > > > > people
> > that
> > > > > > will
> > > > > > wind up contributing in the long run. The rest are useless 
> > > > > > twats.
> > Most
> > > > > > will
> > > > > > never make it very far into "the scene", and if they do it'll 
> > > > > > most
> > > > > > likely
> > > > > > be
> > > > > > some lame-o candied out teeny bopper event. They'll do their
> > drugs,
> > > act
> > > > > > the
> > > > > > part, and then fade away into the next "cool" trend.
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > > > > From: "Sean G" < rationalhatter@gmail.com>
> > > > > > To: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>

> > > > > >
> > > > > > Its too bad --
> > > > > >
> > > > > > None of the essential elements of rave culture discussed in this
> > essay
> > > > > > are
> > > > > > still present. We have superstar DJ gigs with people waving 
> > > > > > their
> > arms
> > > > > > at
> > > > > > Tietso instead of dancing, raves happen in decrepit city centers
> > not
> > > in
> > > > > > the
> > > > > > woods, people don't wanna hug they want to fuck, spirituality 
> > > > > > and
> > > asking
> > > > > > the
> > > > > > big questions has been replaced by "are you thizzin?"
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Which is not to say that nobody is finding themselves + evolving
> > with
> > > > > > the
> > > > > > help of raves. The layout, the chemicals, the music, the
> > atmosphere --
> > > > > > some
> > > > > > kind of gnosis or ecstatic experience is pretty much unavoidable
> > under
> > > > > > these
> > > > > > circumstances. The capitalist rockstar machine has muddled 
> > > > > > things
> > up a
> > > > > > bit,
> > > > > > but there's still hope.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I think the biggest tragedy is that the older krews have given 
> > > > > > up
> > on
> > > > > > generation thizz. The folks now doing nothing but deep house
> > monthlies
> > > > > > at
> > > > > > club mighty would do well to pay it forward and court the new
> > school.
> > > > > > Maybe
> > > > > > use some of their resources and contacts amassed from years of
> > > > > > involvement
> > > > > > in the club and rave scene to show these kids that there is
> > something
> > > > > > more
> > > > > > to all this than entertainment and gettin faded. The new punks
> > don't
> > > > > > know
> > > > > > shit... but who's gonna teach them?
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I think they /want/ to learn. The high turnover rate of ravers
> > these
> > > > > > days
> > > > > > would seem to suggest a awareness of the shallow, short-sighted,
> > burn
> > > > > > bright
> > > > > > burn out nature of the modern 'party' scene. Seems like nobody 
> > > > > > is
> > > > > > willing
> > > > > > to
> > > > > > step up to the plate...

	 <20051201100548.C52389@kzsu.stanford.edu>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] sameer wtf

I don't see a problem with this. When you drive around a home depot
with a pickup truck and have 20 illegal immigrant day workers surround
your truck, asking for work, it gets old really quick. Thing is, is
that the government isn't really enforcing anything.

Illegal immigrants are a real problem out here. I wouldn't call it
racist whatsoever. Enter the country legally, just as my ancestors
did, and you shouldn't have a problem. I'm irish and norweigan. My
great(x4) grandfather was a mine worker. He worked hard, eventually
got his family out of jersey, and ended up being one of the founders
of rochester, minnesota.

How would you fix the problem of illegal immigrants in arizona? I'd
love to hear an outsider's solution, since ours is apparently not good
enough. Having an opinion, and having a solution are two completely
different things. Illegal immigrants are driving down the prices of
homes, costing millions in healthcare and education, and driving down
the labor costs out here to a point where it's nearly impossible to
live if you work in construction, which is the biggest job market out
here.


BTW, my girlfriend is the chief page of the arizona state senate. I'm
fully aware of the laws, and I still agree with them.

legally" is a joke.

If you really wanna do something about the illegals coming in and trying to 
get work - go after the businesses that hire them. If no one hired them, 
they'd never come here. They come here 'cos they KNOW they can get hired and 
even the pittance they get here is way more than they'd get paid in Mexico.

Swell, and Swell was located in Tempe for a while.

have a sign on the California border that says, "Welcome To Arizona.
Watch Your Language."

Arizona). If I were half the lecher people think I am, I'd have been
in paradise.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] sameer wtf

I'm against illegal immigration. It's a system for bypassing the law
and creating an entire millions-plus population of second-class
citizens.

Think about it. They pay taxes, but they can't vote. Despite all the
best intentions of the Consitution and all the rest of it, today we
live in a society filled with people who pay taxes and can't vote.
That would be taxation without representation, wouldn't it?

Additionally, if you're a Latino trying to cross the Mexican-American
border, you're facing serious dangers. Down in Ciudad Juarez, a town
just over the Mexican border with Texas, the rate of murder and rape
is unbelievable. If you want to get the shudders sometime, google
"ciudad juarez femicide rape child prostitution."

However, most people against illegal immigration are for tightening
borders. That's just fighting the inevitable. Even if it wasn't
primarily motivated by racism and xenophobia, it'd still be pushing a
boulder uphill.

The borders should be loose, but the people hiring illegals and paying
them half the going rate for the work, they're the ones who should be
arrested. Their whole profit model depends on a persistent underclass
of second-class citizens. It isn't just exploitative and wrong, it
also undermines the foundations of American society.

On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> Fucking wah. Those illegals are doing work no American citizen would ever=
 do
> for the same wage. PERIOD.
>
> People act as if it's some huge burden on them. You wouldn't eat half the
> fruit and vegetables you eat if it weren't for them. Do you have any idea
> what prices on such stuff would be w/o illegals here in the country?
>
> That's just ONE of many jobs they do that our primadonna citizens wouldn'=
t
> touch with a ten foot pole.
>
> All this crying about the ridiculous formalities over "entering the count=
ry
> legally" is a joke.
>
> If you really wanna do something about the illegals coming in and trying =
to
> get work - go after the businesses that hire them. If no one hired them,
> they'd never come here. They come here 'cos they KNOW they can get hired =
and
> even the pittance they get here is way more than they'd get paid in Mexic=
o.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] VRR: Otherworld to be demolished

d00d, we're three years away from the 20th anniversary of the acid
house Summer of Love. drum & bass is in the top 40 in the UK.
turntables outsell guitars, some years. you get minor fluctuations in
the scene's popularity, but it won't be disappearing overnight. if
anything, the minor fluctuations are good, because the dips in
popularity shake out the trendies, and the peaks reward the hardcore.

On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> I look at it this way (as I did w/ punk) - there will ALWAYS be a core gr=
oup
> of folks into the sound/scene. Sometimes the popularity will be high,
> sometimes low. You take the good with the bad. But I hardly think the
> electronic or "rave" scene is gonna die out any time soon. The drop off i=
n
> popularity started back in 2001 already. Here we are at the close of 2005=
.
> Is the scene dead? No. Is it gone? No. Are there still fans? Yes. Are the=
re
> new kids? Maybe not as many as flooded the scene in '99, but I seem to
> recall (at least on the East Coast) all the old skoolers being mad when t=
he
> scene became commercially available to the mass consumer market, so shoul=
d
> we care?? The music and scene aren't going away - they're just changing a=
s
> EVERYTHING does.

> I think the formulaic cookie-cutter approach to production is much
> more detrimental to our scene's popularity among them dagnabbed
> younguns (and their alleged segment) than any marketing scheme.
>
> Pendulum put drum and bass back in the UK's Top 40 with "Slam" earlier
> this year. That track owes more to Motley Crue and George Clinton than
> it does to anything within d&b proper. They weren't like, gosh, how
> can we get d&b into the Top 40? They just did something totally
> bizarre and unexpected which seemed perfectly logical to them. (Which
> is actually very typical of Australian musicians -- INXS, Men Without
> Hats, etc.)
>
> Music is like technology -- a marketing budget is a sign of a bad
> product. Focus on quality, that's the only thing that matters. If your
> product is the best availabe, you'll be overwhelmed by people who want
> it.
>

From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] VRR: Otherworld to be demolished


d00d, we're three years away from the 20th anniversary of the acid
house Summer of Love. drum & bass is in the top 40 in the UK.
turntables outsell guitars, some years. you get minor fluctuations in
the scene's popularity, but it won't be disappearing overnight. if
anything, the minor fluctuations are good, because the dips in
popularity shake out the trendies, and the peaks reward the hardcore.

On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> I look at it this way (as I did w/ punk) - there will ALWAYS be a core 
> group
> of folks into the sound/scene. Sometimes the popularity will be high,
> sometimes low. You take the good with the bad. But I hardly think the
> electronic or "rave" scene is gonna die out any time soon. The drop off in
> popularity started back in 2001 already. Here we are at the close of 2005.
> Is the scene dead? No. Is it gone? No. Are there still fans? Yes. Are 
> there
> new kids? Maybe not as many as flooded the scene in '99, but I seem to
> recall (at least on the East Coast) all the old skoolers being mad when 
> the
> scene became commercially available to the mass consumer market, so should
> we care?? The music and scene aren't going away - they're just changing as
> EVERYTHING does.
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Wednesday, November 30, 2005 7:13 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] VRR: Otherworld to be demolished
>
>
> I think the formulaic cookie-cutter approach to production is much
> more detrimental to our scene's popularity among them dagnabbed
> younguns (and their alleged segment) than any marketing scheme.
>
> Pendulum put drum and bass back in the UK's Top 40 with "Slam" earlier
> this year. That track owes more to Motley Crue and George Clinton than
> it does to anything within d&b proper. They weren't like, gosh, how
> can we get d&b into the Top 40? They just did something totally
> bizarre and unexpected which seemed perfectly logical to them. (Which
> is actually very typical of Australian musicians -- INXS, Men Without
> Hats, etc.)
>
> Music is like technology -- a marketing budget is a sign of a bad
> product. Focus on quality, that's the only thing that matters. If your
> product is the best availabe, you'll be overwhelmed by people who want
> it.
>
> By the way, I skipped this thread earlier, and I didn't see that
> picture of Sameer. I have to admit I'm utterly terrified to see how
> much he resembles George Will. I have to take back that stuff
> endorsing him as a Presidential candidate, because those fashion
> decisions are just unsupportable.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Looking for some opinions on Neil Landstrumm doing a

NEIL LANDSTRUMM CAN HAVE MY BABIES.

Saw him at Mad (Bahia Cabana) in like 96 I think, with Tobias Schmidt and 
it was THE FRIKKING BOMB.  Can't vouch for if he is still any good but I'd 
*so* go.  I've seen MBM / Advent / Autechre / Surgeon whathaveyou, I've 
seen everybody and their mom and he still ranks in the top 5 live pas I've 
ever seen.

You should also book me, I'll play live or DJ.  I'm like, the 1929472nd 
ranked DJ in the Bay Area and can mix better than some people who get 
booked more.  I also play MY OWN FUCKING MUSIC when I play live unlike 
some folks.  Just ask any of my glossy eyed cronie army.  And Ed 
Colmar likes me, that's about as legit as it gets.  Doot doot!

<3,
andyw

Subject: Re: [sfraves] sameer wtf

Not true.

My dad puts signs up for a living. He's out in the heat during the
summer time for up to 12 hours a day. Previous to that job, he was
installing air filters for business in the area. He's used to doing
shit jobs.

Hell, when I first moved out here, I was a cable guy. Installing
outlets in people's walls when the attic is 160 degrees by 10am with
all the fucking asbestos and shitty insulation, dust, and spiders is
GRATE! Same thing goes with digging 200-foot trenches to bury a line
that you're only getting paid 6 bucks to install (since it was
piecework).

YOU might not be doing these jobs, but I know of a lot of people that
do. It might not affect you, but it definitely affects my family and a
lot of my friends.

I mean, of course outsourcing isn't bad either. They can do the job
for cheaper, so it's good for you in IT, right? I mean, you're saving
the company basket loads of money by giving the job to someone who can
do the job cheaper. Doesn't matter that it might potentially put you
or your friends out of business, because it's jobs that americans
wouldn't want to do anyhow, right?

Yeah, right.

My dad puts signs up for a living. He's out in the heat during the

outlets in people's walls when the attic is 160 degrees by 10am with
all the fucking asbestos and shitty insulation, dust, and spiders is

that you're only getting paid 6 bucks to install (since it was

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

> I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's music, you
> should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the lazy
> mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook, calling it a
> live set, and it being other people's music.

Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources of
meaningful output.

also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock it
til you've tried it.

also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
**is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus sixty
percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
possibility.

anyway back to needling Andy:

> It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or skill.  It's
> like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not their work.
> More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of communication

mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen people
doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with vinyl,
and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
going to crash.

> Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a frikking tune
> already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now pony up and
> do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to the
> world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?

just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
**good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the ease-of-use
with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science, you
wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's like,
look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string words
together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading, let
alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd rather
hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
their own badly. take the time to get it right.

anyhoo!

Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you can't
synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
that, what's the point?

also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a drum
machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out some
incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).

but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because it's
much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
minimally-effective tool to its limits.

--
Giles Soundwave =3D Giles Goat Boy
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking about is 
just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like an 80 bpm 
track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.

I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at all due to 
tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or slow it 
down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other 
programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and "true" as 
Ableton.
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ


> I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's music, you
> should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the lazy
> mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook, calling it a
> live set, and it being other people's music.

Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources of
meaningful output.

also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock it
til you've tried it.

also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
**is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus sixty
percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
possibility.

anyway back to needling Andy:

> It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or skill.  It's
> like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not their work.
> More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of communication

mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen people
doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with vinyl,
and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
going to crash.

> Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a frikking tune
> already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now pony up and
> do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to the
> world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?

just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
**good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the ease-of-use
with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science, you
wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's like,
look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string words
together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading, let
alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd rather
hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
their own badly. take the time to get it right.

anyhoo!

Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you can't
synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
that, what's the point?

also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a drum
machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out some
incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).

but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because it's
much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
minimally-effective tool to its limits.

--
Giles Soundwave = Giles Goat Boy
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

because they happen to own the White House at the moment isn't logical
or historically accurate. the working class got fucked by everybody.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

oh no no no no. you do not understand me.

I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.

beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.

80bpm * 60 percent =3D 80 * .6 =3D 48
80 + 48 =3D 128 =3D max tempo for record A: 128bpm

160 * 60 % =3D 160 * .6 =3D 96
160bpm - 96bpm =3D 64bpm =3D lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm

this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
play them both at house tempo.

I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.

On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking about is
> just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like an 80 b=
pm
> track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
>
> I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at all due =
to
> tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or slow =
it
> down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and "true"=
 as
> Ableton.
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>
>
> > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's music, you
> > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the lazy
> > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook, calling it=
 a
> > live set, and it being other people's music.
>
> Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
> ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
> voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
> Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
> who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources of
> meaningful output.
>
> also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock it
> til you've tried it.
>
> also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
> saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
> **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
> irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus sixty
> percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
> within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
> possibility.
>
> anyway back to needling Andy:
>
> > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or skill.  It'=
s
> > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not their wor=
k.
> > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of communication
>
> mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen people
> doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with vinyl,
> and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
> matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
> going to crash.
>
> > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a frikking tu=
ne
> > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now pony up a=
nd
> > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to the
> > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
>
> just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
> **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the ease-of-use
> with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science, you
> wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
> but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's like,
> look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string words
> together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading, let
> alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd rather
> hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> their own badly. take the time to get it right.
>
> anyhoo!
>
> Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you can't
> synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
> that, what's the point?
>
> also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a drum
> machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
> fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out some
> incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
>
> but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because it's
> much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> minimally-effective tool to its limits.
>
> --
> Giles Soundwave =3D Giles Goat Boy
> http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just vinyl.

For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it to 
160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch it down 
to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)

With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and vice 
versa).

The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the beats...unless 
someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from the 
Pioneer CDJ's)

> wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
> but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's like,
> look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string words
> together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading, let
> alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd rather
> hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> their own badly. take the time to get it right.
>
> anyhoo!
>
> Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you can't
> synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
> that, what's the point?
>
> also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a drum
> machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
> fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out some
> incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
>
> but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because it's
> much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> minimally-effective tool to its limits.
>
> --
> Giles Soundwave = Giles Goat Boy
> http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>


--
Giles Soundwave = Giles Goat Boy
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

> > Pendulum put drum and bass back in the UK's Top 40 with "Slam" earlier

> > it does to anything within d&b proper. They weren't like, gosh, how
> > can we get d&b into the Top 40? They just did something totally
> > bizarre and unexpected which seemed perfectly logical to them. (Which
> > is actually very typical of Australian musicians -- INXS, Men Without
> > Hats, etc.)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just viny=
l.

yes, I'm aware of that. I said PITCHSHIFTING. that would mean shifting
the pitch.

> For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it to
> 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch it do=
wn
> to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
>
> With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and vice
> versa).
>
> The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the beats...unless
> someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from the
> Pioneer CDJ's)

yes yes yes. I'm just saying however that the 80 <---> 160 beatmatch,
absurd a goal tho it is, can be achieved within the context of a
vinyl-only set. that's ALL I'm saying here.

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>
>
> oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
>
> I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
>
> beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
> and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
>
> 80bpm * 60 percent =3D 80 * .6 =3D 48
> 80 + 48 =3D 128 =3D max tempo for record A: 128bpm
>
> 160 * 60 % =3D 160 * .6 =3D 96
> 160bpm - 96bpm =3D 64bpm =3D lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm
>
> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> play them both at house tempo.
>
> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
>
> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking about =
is
> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like an 80
> > bpm
> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> >
> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at all du=
e
> > to
> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or slo=
w
> > it
> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and "tru=
e"
> > as
> > Ableton.
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>

> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

> >
> > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's music, yo=
u
> > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the lazy
> > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook, calling =
it
> > > a
> > > live set, and it being other people's music.
> >
> > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
> > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
> > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
> > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
> > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources of
> > meaningful output.
> >
> > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock it
> > til you've tried it.
> >
> > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
> > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
> > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
> > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus sixty
> > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
> > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
> > possibility.
> >
> > anyway back to needling Andy:
> >
> > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or skill.  I=
t's
> > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not their
> > > work.
> > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of communicati=
on
> >
> > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen people
> > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with vinyl,
> > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
> > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
> > going to crash.
> >
> > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a frikking
> > > tune
> > > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now pony up
> > > and
> > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to the
> > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
> >
> > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
> > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the ease-of-use
> > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science, you
> > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
> > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's like,
> > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string words
> > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading, let
> > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd rather
> > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
> >
> > anyhoo!
> >
> > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you can't
> > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
> > that, what's the point?
> >
> > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a drum
> > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
> > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out some
> > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
> >
> > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because it's
> > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
> >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

The only thing is, pitch-corrected time stretching in real time often
sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
"Master Pitch", it's just laughable!  Ewwy.

Certainly "close enough for jazz" though for mashup/remix on the fly
usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.

Cheers,
-GC

> d00d, we're three years away from the 20th anniversary of the acid
> house Summer of Love. drum & bass is in the top 40 in the UK.
> turntables outsell guitars, some years. you get minor fluctuations in
> the scene's popularity, but it won't be disappearing overnight. if
> anything, the minor fluctuations are good, because the dips in
> popularity shake out the trendies, and the peaks reward the hardcore.
>
> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > I look at it this way (as I did w/ punk) - there will ALWAYS be a core
> > group
> > of folks into the sound/scene. Sometimes the popularity will be high,
> > sometimes low. You take the good with the bad. But I hardly think the
> > electronic or "rave" scene is gonna die out any time soon. The drop off 
> > in
> > popularity started back in 2001 already. Here we are at the close of 
> > 2005.
> > Is the scene dead? No. Is it gone? No. Are there still fans? Yes. Are
> > there
> > new kids? Maybe not as many as flooded the scene in '99, but I seem to
> > recall (at least on the East Coast) all the old skoolers being mad when
> > the
> > scene became commercially available to the mass consumer market, so 
> > should
> > we care?? The music and scene aren't going away - they're just changing 
> > as
> > EVERYTHING does.
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>

> >
> > I think the formulaic cookie-cutter approach to production is much
> > more detrimental to our scene's popularity among them dagnabbed
> > younguns (and their alleged segment) than any marketing scheme.
> >
> > Pendulum put drum and bass back in the UK's Top 40 with "Slam" earlier
> > this year. That track owes more to Motley Crue and George Clinton than
> > it does to anything within d&b proper. They weren't like, gosh, how
> > can we get d&b into the Top 40? They just did something totally
> > bizarre and unexpected which seemed perfectly logical to them. (Which
> > is actually very typical of Australian musicians -- INXS, Men Without
> > Hats, etc.)
> >
> > Music is like technology -- a marketing budget is a sign of a bad
> > product. Focus on quality, that's the only thing that matters. If your
> > product is the best availabe, you'll be overwhelmed by people who want
> > it.
> >
> > By the way, I skipped this thread earlier, and I didn't see that
> > picture of Sameer. I have to admit I'm utterly terrified to see how

> > endorsing him as a Presidential candidate, because those fashion
> > decisions are just unsupportable.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

"Close enough for jazz"? My experience is that jazz guys are the
pickiest, least prone to corner-cutting guys on the planet. Classical
musicians are mercenaries by comparison. I mean look at Carl Craig. As
far as I can tell the only electronic music gear that was ever close
enough for jazz was the Korg Prophecy. Programming that thing requires
multiple graduate degrees in korgprophecyology.

Sorry, I just don't understand what you mean.

On 12/1/05, georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
> The only thing is, pitch-corrected time stretching in real time often
> sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
> hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
> "Master Pitch", it's just laughable!  Ewwy.
>
> Certainly "close enough for jazz" though for mashup/remix on the fly
> usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
> tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.
>
> Cheers,
> -GC
>
> --- "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> > You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just
> > vinyl.
> >
> > For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it
> > to
> > 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch
> > it down
> > to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
> >
> > With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and
> > vice
> > versa).
> >
> > The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the
> > beats...unless
> > someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from
> > the
> > Pioneer CDJ's)
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> > Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> >
> >
> > oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
> >
> > I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
> >
> > beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> > Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> > talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
> > and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
> >
> > 80bpm * 60 percent =3D 80 * .6 =3D 48
> > 80 + 48 =3D 128 =3D max tempo for record A: 128bpm
> >
> > 160 * 60 % =3D 160 * .6 =3D 96
> > 160bpm - 96bpm =3D 64bpm =3D lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bp=
m
> >
> > this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> > 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> > and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> > play them both at house tempo.
> >
> > I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
> > to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> > dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
> > sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
> > describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
> >
> > On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
> > about is
> > > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
> > an 80
> > > bpm
> > > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> > >
> > > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
> > all due
> > > to
> > > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or
> > slow
> > > it
> > > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> > > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
> > "true"
> > > as
> > > Ableton.
> > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
> > > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> > >
> > >
> > > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's
> > music, you
> > > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the
> > lazy
> > > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook,
> > calling it
> > > > a
> > > > live set, and it being other people's music.
> > >
> > > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
> > > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
> > > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
> > > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
> > > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources
> > of
> > > meaningful output.
> > >
> > > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock
> > it
> > > til you've tried it.
> > >
> > > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
> > > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
> > > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
> > > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus
> > sixty
> > > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
> > > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
> > > possibility.
> > >
> > > anyway back to needling Andy:
> > >
> > > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or
> > skill.  It's
> > > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not
> > their
> > > > work.
> > > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of
> > communication
> > >
> > > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen
> > people
> > > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with
> > vinyl,
> > > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
> > > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
> > > going to crash.
> > >
> > > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a
> > frikking
> > > > tune
> > > > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now
> > pony up
> > > > and
> > > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to
> > the
> > > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
> > >
> > > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
> > > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the
> > ease-of-use
> > > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science,
> > you
> > > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
> > > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> > > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's
> > like,
> > > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string
> > words
> > > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading,
> > let
> > > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> > > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd
> > rather
> > > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> > > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
> > >
> > > anyhoo!
> > >
> > > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> > > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you
> > can't
> > > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
> > > that, what's the point?
> > >
> > > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a
> > drum
> > > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> > > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
> > > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out
> > some
> > > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> > > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
> > >
> > > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because
> > it's
> > > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> > > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> > > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
> > >
> > > --
> > > Giles Soundwave =3D Giles Goat Boy
> > > http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>

Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:14 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ


On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just 
> vinyl.

yes, I'm aware of that. I said PITCHSHIFTING. that would mean shifting
the pitch.

> For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it to
> 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch it 
> down
> to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
>
> With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and vice
> versa).
>
> The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the beats...unless
> someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from the
> Pioneer CDJ's)

yes yes yes. I'm just saying however that the 80 <---> 160 beatmatch,
absurd a goal tho it is, can be achieved within the context of a
vinyl-only set. that's ALL I'm saying here.

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>
>
> oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
>
> I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
>
> beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
> and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
>
> 80bpm * 60 percent = 80 * .6 = 48
> 80 + 48 = 128 = max tempo for record A: 128bpm
>
> 160 * 60 % = 160 * .6 = 96
> 160bpm - 96bpm = 64bpm = lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm
>
> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> play them both at house tempo.
>
> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
>
> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking about 
> > is
> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like an 80
> > bpm
> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> >
> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at all due
> > to
> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or slow
> > it
> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and 
> > "true"
> > as
> > Ableton.
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

> >
> > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's music, you
> > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the lazy
> > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook, calling 
> > > it
> > > a
> > > live set, and it being other people's music.
> >
> > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
> > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
> > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
> > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
> > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources of
> > meaningful output.
> >
> > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock it
> > til you've tried it.
> >
> > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
> > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
> > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
> > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus sixty
> > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
> > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
> > possibility.
> >
> > anyway back to needling Andy:
> >
> > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or skill. 
> > > It's
> > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not their
> > > work.
> > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of 
> > > communication
> >
> > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen people
> > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with vinyl,
> > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
> > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
> > going to crash.
> >
> > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a frikking
> > > tune
> > > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now pony up
> > > and
> > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to the
> > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
> >
> > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
> > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the ease-of-use
> > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science, you
> > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
> > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's like,
> > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string words
> > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading, let
> > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd rather
> > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
> >
> > anyhoo!
> >
> > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you can't
> > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
> > that, what's the point?
> >
> > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a drum
> > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
> > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out some
> > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
> >
> > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because it's
> > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
> >
> > --
> > Giles Soundwave = Giles Goat Boy
> > http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

> The only thing is, pitch-corrected time stretching in real time often
> sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
> hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
> "Master Pitch", it's just laughable!  Ewwy.
>
> Certainly "close enough for jazz" though for mashup/remix on the fly
> usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
> tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.
>
> Cheers,
> -GC
>
> --- "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
>> You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just
>> vinyl.
>>
>> For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it
>> to
>> 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch
>> it down
>> to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
>>
>> With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and
>> vice
>> versa).
>>
>> The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the
>> beats...unless
>> someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from
>> the
>> Pioneer CDJ's)
>> ----- Original Message ----- 
>> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
>> To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
>> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>>
>>
>> oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
>>
>> I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
>>
>> beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
>> Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
>> talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
>> and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
>>
>> 80bpm * 60 percent = 80 * .6 = 48
>> 80 + 48 = 128 = max tempo for record A: 128bpm
>>
>> 160 * 60 % = 160 * .6 = 96
>> 160bpm - 96bpm = 64bpm = lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm
>>
>> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
>> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
>> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
>> play them both at house tempo.
>>
>> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
>> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
>> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
>> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
>> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
>>
>> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
>> about is
>> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
>> an 80
>> > bpm
>> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
>> >
>> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
>> all due
>> > to
>> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or
>> slow
>> > it
>> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
>> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
>> "true"
>> > as
>> > Ableton.
>> > ----- Original Message -----

>> ease-of-use
>> > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science,
>> you
>> > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
>> > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
>> > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's
>> like,
>> > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string
>> words
>> > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading,
>> let
>> > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
>> > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd

>> > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing

Subject: [sfraves] News: The Party's Over, Almost at 48 ABELL

CN ON: The Party's Over, Almost, At 48 Abell
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v05/n1866/a02.html
Newshawk: Herb
Rate this article Votes: 0
Pubdate: Sun, 27 Nov 2005
Source: Toronto Star (CN ON)
Copyright: 2005 The Toronto Star
Contact: lettertoed@thestar.com
Website: http://www.thestar.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/456
Author: Patrick Evans

THE PARTY'S OVER, ALMOST, AT 48 ABELL

Last Call: Loft Crazies Have Had A Great Run, But Landlord Is Going Legit

It's an age-old story.  A lamp factory gets into the landlord business. 
Then the tenants throw parties so wild they'd make Caligula run into the 
night.

Within vomiting distance of Queen and Dufferin, 48 Abell St.  party palace 
is owned by Aristocrat Lamps and Lighting ...  and ...  um ...  Property 
Management Inc.  It's an old factory revamped into 85 lofts where, for 25 
years now, partying tenants have thrown open their doors and invited in 
the night crowd to rock and rattle the chandeliers stored in the basement.

It was in the late '70s, when the lamp and lighting business had started 
to dim, that Aristocrat's Mervin Hollander, the arts-loving son in the 
family business, got his great idea.  Why not downsize the factory and 
rent out the extra space to starving artists?

Then and now, starving artists like a bit of fun.

"The big party we had was the Green Party," recalls Sea Ansley, whose web 
media company, Universal Metropolis, until recently had a studio at 48 
Abell.  "We got evicted."

That was on May 7, 2005.  Ansley says the "green" theme was a celebration 
of green tea and environmental awareness -- but mostly pot.  Universal 
Metropolis set up a hip-hop room, a rave room and a "chill" room with 
chefs making quiche and fondue.  There was a contest for the best strain 
of pot.  "The prize was a giant Indian glass bong," said Ansley.

But Ansley and pals hadn't realized their party was on the same day as the 
city's Marijuana March.  "Our party turned into the afterparty," he said.

Ansley, who had briefly worried nobody would show up, watched in horror 
from sunset to sunrise as about 700 people packed the halls of 48 Abell, 
dancing, getting high, puking and passing out.  A scary guy with a meat 
cleaver ran around hacking pineapples.

Aristocrat had issues with the Green Party.  For one, the pipes burst in 
the basement where they kept their lamp stocks.  Universal Media got the 
boot.

Mervin Hollander wants to put 48 Abell on the right side of the law.  The 
building is zoned for studio workspaces, although it's an open secret that 
people live there.  Hollander wants to upgrade the property, make the 
transition legal.

Except for the dead, rusted cars outside, the pit bulls who don't pick up 
after themselves, and the smell of wet paint and pot leaking into the 
hallways, 48 Abell is downright homey.  Behind closed doors, tenants have 
decorated their loft walls with huge, bright, splashy canvases.  The vast 
spaces have fat, cushy old couches and chairs.  Ladders lead up to 
bedrooms on wooden platforms.  There's plenty of heat.  No mice.  No 
cockroaches.

But Hollander says engineers keep telling him it would cost a fortune to 
bring the building up to code.  Tear it down, they say, and start from 
scratch.

So he hired a development firm to rethink the property.  The developers 
propose two towers to replace the old building.  One would offer 
low-income housing with a mind to the art crowd.  The other will offer 
snappy condominiums to hipsters who can afford real estate.

People in the neighbourhood are opposing the revamp, saying it'll force 
out 48 Abell's current tenants.

And a shiny new condo tower might wreck the classic low-rise Victorian 
look of Queen West.

In the meantime, going legit means cracking down on the nuttiness.

"We've done a lot to curb the reputation of booze cans and parties," says 
Nancy Estrela, who works in Aristocrat's ground floor office.

Estrela plays the unhappy role of party pooper.

"Everyone knows who I am," she says.  Her day ends at 5 p.m., but if 
there's a party that night, Estrela hears about it.  "You always have a 
neighbour who's ticked off.  So there's snitching."

The rising profile of the neighbourhood is also forcing Aristocrat's heavy 
hand.

The revamped Drake and Gladstone hotels have attracted a stampede of new 
partiers.  Estrela says after last call at the Drake, the still thirsty 
find 48 Abell just a hop, skip and a stagger away.

Estrela has safety concerns.

"It's a wood structure building so we can't have people smoking," she 
says, then adds: "The fire department has no sense of humour."

Estrela says there's a negative vibe at work that has nothing to do with 
management.  "The tenants changed.  They got older."

Friendly rents of $800 to $1,500 per studio have produced "not much flip," 
as Estrela puts it -- meaning some tenants at 48 Abell are overstaying 
their own scene.

Take, for example, David Park, 28.  He and his roommates threw a party in 
their loft last summer, featuring a giant inflatable pool.  Door crashers 
from a bachelor party down the hall added to the mayhem.

The wet floor the next morning wasn't as bad as what happened to the 
neglected pool after a couple of weeks.  "Algae started to form," says 
Park.  "It smelled funny.  It started to get kind of browny green." He 
looks sick, recalling it.  "I don't want to talk about it any more."

Park regrets the party.  The crazy stuff is getting old.  "I guess the 
party's over for me," he says.  "I'm kind of tired more, don't want to go 
out as much."

If the development plans go through, the building will be razed within a 
couple of years.  One tenant, illustrator Clayton Hanmer, predicts the art 
crowd will build a new bohemia somewhere else.

"It's not really my neighbourhood any more," he says, a reference to the 
weekenders "from Woodbridge and stuff" drawn to the reno hotels.  He 
misses that golden age of cheap beers among old men at the Gladstone.  And 
"the Drake was just boarded up and nasty," he recalls.  "Crack whores used 
to go there.  It was awesome."

Ex-tenant Ansley says there's already a buzz around 48 Abell about the 
hypothetical "last party" if the loft crowd gets displaced.  One last 
shout in a building about to be torn down.

"It'll be Toronto's biggest party of the decade," he says confidently.

Aristocrat might want to move out the chandeliers this time.

--

******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

On Thu, 1 Dec 2005, georgeC | origami wrote:

-&e->sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
-&e->hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
-&e->"Master Pitch", it's just laughable!  Ewwy.

Thank you for stating what should be obvious.  It's like we're part of a 
hivemind, a like minded collective.

PH33r TEH LAG

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] News: (anybody go to this?) No more parties on The Great Wall

--0-2070263092-1133471950=:51069
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8BIT


"...
No more rave parties at the Great Wall
(Beijing Today)
Updated: 2005-11-21 11:09

Critical media coverage of a rave party that saw 1,500 local and expat 
revelers gather at the Jinshanling section of the Great Wall this summer 
has prompted local authorities to prohibit any future events.


Crowds thronged the Wall at a rave party held at the Jinshanling section 
of the Wall this summer. [Ynet]

Cheng Dalin, deputy director of China Great Wall Society said that local 
government had re-assumed management of the Jinshanling Great Wall, 
previously overseen by the local tourism bureau.

The party at the Wall, criticized as "bawdy" in media reports, provoked 
widespread anger among Chinese people. One article in Hong Kong-based Next 
Magazine claimed that the Great Wall of China had been taken over by sex, 
drugs and rock and roll, accompanied by pictures of the inappropriate 
behavior of some party-goers.

CCTV followed up with an investigative report, revealing, that in 1997 a 
company called Guangda signed a 50-year lease with local authorities. The 
company claimed that it earned revenue by allowing use of its facilities 
at a charge of 60 yuan per head. The party organizers sold tickets for the 
event at 200 yuan each.

Fabrizio Zambuto, a photographer working in Beijing, said that he had 
attended several such parties at the Wall over the past five years, said, 
"Most people who went to the party respected the Wall."


A hi-fashioned woman dances to the music at the rave party held on the 
Wall in Hebei Province this summer. [Ynet]

He thought that some people's disrespectful behavior could be put down to 
a lack of facilities such as litter bins and toilets.

William Lindesay, founder and director of International Friends of the 
Great Wall, said "I have been going to rock parties for 25 years. But the 
Great Wall is something so majestic, it is not a place for that kind of 
party." Seven years ago Lindesay heled start public clean-up days at the 
Great Wall. He remains devoted to conserving the Wall.

Lindesay recalled how four years ago an Australian TV station provided him 
with video footage of a rave party at the Great Wall.

"The film showed dancing that was very inappropriate," he said. Last week, 
Lindesay and members of his organization donated 30 litter bins to the 
Jinshanling Great Wall management department.

The bins carry the slogan, 'He who does not love the Great Wall is not a 
true man, a version of Chairman Mao's famous words "He who does not reach 
the Great Wall is not a true man."

It is too early to say for certain whether a party will be held at the 
Wall next year. DJ Dio, one of the main organizers for this year's event 
said, "I think we should continue the tradition of having rave parties. If 
the authorities won't allow us to do so, of course we won't hold them 
there. But the last party we held was officially approved and we had all 
the paperwork done.?

Huang Yaohui, from China Great Wall Society, said that damage to the Great 
Wall has occurred not only at Jinshanling but to other sections too. He 
blames this on a combination of shortcomings in legislation, insufficient 
public awareness and poor supervision from relative agencies.

William Lindesay says that education is the key to protecting the Wall. 
Each time he visits the Great Wall, he asks other tourists to deal with 
trash they have discarded, "I remember once when I asked some people to 
pick up their litter, they thanked me for pointing it out rather than 
being offended."

..."

Source: 
http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2005-11/21/content_496624.htm

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
