Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ


"Close enough for jazz"? My experience is that jazz guys are the
pickiest, least prone to corner-cutting guys on the planet. Classical
musicians are mercenaries by comparison. I mean look at Carl Craig. As
far as I can tell the only electronic music gear that was ever close
enough for jazz was the Korg Prophecy. Programming that thing requires
multiple graduate degrees in korgprophecyology.

Sorry, I just don't understand what you mean.

On 12/1/05, georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
> The only thing is, pitch-corrected time stretching in real time often
> sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
> hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
> "Master Pitch", it's just laughable!  Ewwy.
>
> Certainly "close enough for jazz" though for mashup/remix on the fly
> usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
> tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.
>
> Cheers,
> -GC
>
> --- "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> > You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just
> > vinyl.
> >
> > For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it
> > to
> > 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch
> > it down
> > to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
> >
> > With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and
> > vice
> > versa).
> >
> > The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the
> > beats...unless
> > someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from
> > the
> > Pioneer CDJ's)
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> > Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> >
> >
> > oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
> >
> > I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
> >
> > beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> > Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> > talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
> > and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
> >
> > 80bpm * 60 percent = 80 * .6 = 48
> > 80 + 48 = 128 = max tempo for record A: 128bpm
> >
> > 160 * 60 % = 160 * .6 = 96
> > 160bpm - 96bpm = 64bpm = lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm
> >
> > this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> > 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> > and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> > play them both at house tempo.
> >
> > I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
> > to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> > dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
> > sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
> > describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
> >
> > On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
> > about is
> > > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
> > an 80
> > > bpm
> > > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> > >
> > > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
> > all due
> > > to
> > > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or
> > slow
> > > it
> > > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> > > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
> > "true"
> > > as
> > > Ableton.
> > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
> > > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> > >
> > >
> > > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's
> > music, you
> > > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the
> > lazy
> > > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook,
> > calling it
> > > > a
> > > > live set, and it being other people's music.
> > >
> > > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
> > > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
> > > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
> > > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
> > > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources
> > of
> > > meaningful output.
> > >
> > > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock
> > it
> > > til you've tried it.
> > >
> > > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
> > > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
> > > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
> > > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus
> > sixty
> > > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
> > > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
> > > possibility.
> > >
> > > anyway back to needling Andy:
> > >
> > > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or
> > skill.  It's
> > > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not
> > their
> > > > work.
> > > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of
> > communication
> > >
> > > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen
> > people
> > > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with
> > vinyl,
> > > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
> > > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
> > > going to crash.
> > >
> > > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a
> > frikking
> > > > tune
> > > > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now
> > pony up
> > > > and
> > > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to
> > the
> > > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
> > >
> > > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
> > > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the
> > ease-of-use
> > > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science,
> > you
> > > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
> > > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> > > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's
> > like,
> > > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string
> > words
> > > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading,
> > let
> > > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> > > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd
> > rather
> > > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> > > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
> > >
> > > anyhoo!
> > >
> > > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> > > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you
> > can't
> > > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
> > > that, what's the point?
> > >
> > > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a
> > drum
> > > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> > > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
> > > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out
> > some
> > > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> > > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
> > >
> > > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because
> > it's
> > > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> > > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> > > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
> > >
> > > --
> > > Giles Soundwave = Giles Goat Boy
> > > http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:16 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ


> You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just 
> vinyl.
>
> For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it to 
> 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch it 
> down to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
>
> With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and vice 
> versa).
>
> The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the beats...unless 
> someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from the 
> Pioneer CDJ's)
> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>
>
> oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
>
> I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
>
> beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
> and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
>
> 80bpm * 60 percent = 80 * .6 = 48
> 80 + 48 = 128 = max tempo for record A: 128bpm
>
> 160 * 60 % = 160 * .6 = 96
> 160bpm - 96bpm = 64bpm = lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm
>
> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> play them both at house tempo.
>
> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
>
> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>> It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking about is
>> just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like an 80 
>> bpm
>> track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
>>
>> I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at all due 
>> to
>> tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or slow 
>> it
>> down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
>> programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and "true" 
>> as
>> Ableton.
>> ----- Original Message -----
>> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
>> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>>
>>
>> > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's music, you
>> > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the lazy
>> > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook, calling it 
>> > a
>> > live set, and it being other people's music.
>>
>> Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
>> ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
>> voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
>> Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
>> who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources of
>> meaningful output.
>>
>> also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock it
>> til you've tried it.
>>
>> also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
>> saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
>> **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
>> irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus sixty
>> percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
>> within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
>> possibility.
>>
>> anyway back to needling Andy:
>>
>> > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or skill. 
>> > It's
>> > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not their 
>> > work.
>> > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of communication
>>
>> mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen people
>> doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with vinyl,
>> and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
>> matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
>> going to crash.
>>
>> > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a frikking 
>> > tune
>> > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now pony up 
>> > and
>> > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to the
>> > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
>>
>> just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
>> **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the ease-of-use
>> with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science, you
>> wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
>> but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
>> mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's like,
>> look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string words
>> together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading, let
>> alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
>> overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd rather
>> hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
>> their own badly. take the time to get it right.
>>
>> anyhoo!
>>
>> Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
>> traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you can't
>> synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
>> that, what's the point?
>>
>> also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a drum
>> machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
>> sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
>> fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out some
>> incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
>> hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
>>
>> but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because it's
>> much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
>> functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
>> minimally-effective tool to its limits.
>>
>> --
>> Giles Soundwave = Giles Goat Boy
>> http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
>>

>>> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
>>> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
>>>
>>> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>>> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
>>> about is
>>> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
>>> an 80
>>> > bpm
>>> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
>>> >
>>> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
>>> all due
>>> > to
>>> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or
>>> slow
>>> > it
>>> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
>>> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
>>> "true"
>>> > as
>>> > Ableton.
>>> > ----- Original Message -----
>>> > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
>>> > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>>> > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
>>> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>>> >
>>> >
>>> > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's
>>> music, you
>>> > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the
>>> lazy
>>> > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook,
>>> calling it
>>> > > a
>>> > > live set, and it being other people's music.
>>> >
>>> > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
>>> > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
>>> > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
>>> > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
>>> > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources
>>> of
>>> > meaningful output.
>>> >
>>> > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock
>>> it
>>> > til you've tried it.
>>> >
>>> > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
>>> > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
>>> > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
>>> > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus
>>> sixty
>>> > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
>>> > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
>>> > possibility.
>>> >
>>> > anyway back to needling Andy:
>>> >
>>> > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or
>>> skill.  It's
>>> > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not
>>> their
>>> > > work.
>>> > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of
>>> communication
>>> >
>>> > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen
>>> people
>>> > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with
>>> vinyl,
>>> > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
>>> > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
>>> > going to crash.
>>> >
>>> > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a
>>> frikking
>>> > > tune
>>> > > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now
>>> pony up
>>> > > and
>>> > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to
>>> the
>>> > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
>>> >
>>> > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
>>> > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the
>>> ease-of-use
>>> > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science,
>>> you
>>> > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
>>> > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
>>> > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's
>>> like,
>>> > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string
>>> words
>>> > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading,
>>> let
>>> > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
>>> > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd
>>> rather
>>> > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
>>> > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
>>> >
>>> > anyhoo!
>>> >
>>> > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
>>> > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you
>>> can't
>>> > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
>>> > that, what's the point?
>>> >
>>> > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a
>>> drum
>>> > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
>>> > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
>>> > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out
>>> some
>>> > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
>>> > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
>>> >
>>> > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because
>>> it's
>>> > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
>>> > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
>>> > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
>>> >
>>> > --
>>> > Giles Soundwave = Giles Goat Boy
>>> > http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

>>> The only thing is, pitch-corrected time stretching in real time often
>>> sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
>>> hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
>>> "Master Pitch", it's just laughable!  Ewwy.
>>>
>>> Certainly "close enough for jazz" though for mashup/remix on the fly
>>> usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
>>> tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.
>>>
>>> Cheers,
>>> -GC
>>>
>>> --- "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>>>
>>>> You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just
>>>> vinyl.
>>>>
>>>> For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it
>>>> to
>>>> 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch
>>>> it down
>>>> to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
>>>>
>>>> With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and
>>>> vice
>>>> versa).
>>>>
>>>> The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the
>>>> beats...unless
>>>> someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from
>>>> the
>>>> Pioneer CDJ's)
>>>> ----- Original Message -----
>>>> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
>>>> To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
>>>> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>>>> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
>>>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
>>>>
>>>> I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
>>>>
>>>> beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
>>>> Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
>>>> talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
>>>> and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
>>>>
>>>> 80bpm * 60 percent = 80 * .6 = 48
>>>> 80 + 48 = 128 = max tempo for record A: 128bpm
>>>>
>>>> 160 * 60 % = 160 * .6 = 96
>>>> 160bpm - 96bpm = 64bpm = lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm
>>>>
>>>> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
>>>> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
>>>> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
>>>> play them both at house tempo.
>>>>
>>>> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
>>>> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
>>>> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
>>>> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
>>>> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
>>>>
>>>> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>>>> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
>>>> about is
>>>> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
>>>> an 80
>>>> > bpm
>>>> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
>>>> >
>>>> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
>>>> all due
>>>> > to
>>>> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or
>>>> slow
>>>> > it
>>>> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
>>>> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
>>>> "true"
>>>> > as
>>>> > Ableton.
>>>> > ----- Original Message -----
>>>> > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
>>>> > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>>>> > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
>>>> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>>>> >
>>>> >
>>>> > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's
>>>> music, you
>>>> > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the
>>>> lazy
>>>> > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook,
>>>> calling it
>>>> > > a
>>>> > > live set, and it being other people's music.
>>>> >
>>>> > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
>>>> > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
>>>> > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
>>>> > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
>>>> > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources
>>>> of
>>>> > meaningful output.
>>>> >
>>>> > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock
>>>> it
>>>> > til you've tried it.
>>>> >
>>>> > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
>>>> > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
>>>> > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
>>>> > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus
>>>> sixty
>>>> > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
>>>> > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
>>>> > possibility.
>>>> >
>>>> > anyway back to needling Andy:
>>>> >
>>>> > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or
>>>> skill.  It's
>>>> > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not
>>>> their
>>>> > > work.
>>>> > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of
>>>> communication
>>>> >
>>>> > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen
>>>> people
>>>> > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with
>>>> vinyl,
>>>> > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
>>>> > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
>>>> > going to crash.
>>>> >
>>>> > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a
>>>> frikking
>>>> > > tune
>>>> > > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now
>>>> pony up
>>>> > > and
>>>> > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to
>>>> the
>>>> > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
>>>> >
>>>> > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
>>>> > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the
>>>> ease-of-use
>>>> > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science,
>>>> you
>>>> > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
>>>> > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
>>>> > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's
>>>> like,
>>>> > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string
>>>> words
>>>> > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading,
>>>> let
>>>> > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
>>>> > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd
>>>> rather
>>>> > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
>>>> > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
>>>> >
>>>> > anyhoo!
>>>> >
>>>> > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
>>>> > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you
>>>> can't
>>>> > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
>>>> > that, what's the point?
>>>> >
>>>> > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a
>>>> drum
>>>> > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
>>>> > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
>>>> > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out
>>>> some
>>>> > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
>>>> > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
>>>> >
>>>> > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because
>>>> it's
>>>> > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
>>>> > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
>>>> > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
>>>> >

> >>>> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> >>>> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> >>>> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> >>>> play them both at house tempo.
> >>>>
> >>>> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined i=
t
> >>>> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> >>>> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with mor=
e
> >>>> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you'r=
e
> >>>> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
> >>>>
> >>>> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> >>>> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
> >>>> about is
> >>>> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
> >>>> an 80
> >>>> > bpm
> >>>> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
> >>>> all due
> >>>> > to
> >>>> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (o=
r
> >>>> slow
> >>>> > it
> >>>> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> >>>> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
> >>>> "true"
> >>>> > as
> >>>> > Ableton.
> >>>> > ----- Original Message -----
> >>>> > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> >>>> > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> >>>> > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
> >>>> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> >>>> >
> >>>> >
> >>>> > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's
> >>>> music, you
> >>>> > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the
> >>>> lazy
> >>>> > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook,
> >>>> calling it
> >>>> > > a
> >>>> > > live set, and it being other people's music.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with you=
r
> >>>> > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
> >>>> > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, pla=
y
> >>>> > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been=
,
> >>>> > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources
> >>>> of
> >>>> > meaningful output.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock
> >>>> it
> >>>> > til you've tried it.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
> >>>> > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
> >>>> > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
> >>>> > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus
> >>>> sixty
> >>>> > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that eve=
n
> >>>> > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
> >>>> > possibility.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > anyway back to needling Andy:
> >>>> >
> >>>> > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or
> >>>> skill.  It's
> >>>> > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not
> >>>> their
> >>>> > > work.
> >>>> > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of
> >>>> communication
> >>>> >
> >>>> > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen
> >>>> people
> >>>> > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with
> >>>> vinyl,
> >>>> > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
> >>>> > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
> >>>> > going to crash.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a
> >>>> frikking
> >>>> > > tune
> >>>> > > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now
> >>>> pony up
> >>>> > > and
> >>>> > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to
> >>>> the
> >>>> > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
> >>>> >
> >>>> > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make i=
t
> >>>> > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the
> >>>> ease-of-use
> >>>> > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science,
> >>>> you
> >>>> > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me=
!
> >>>> > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> >>>> > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's
> >>>> like,
> >>>> > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string
> >>>> words
> >>>> > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading,
> >>>> let
> >>>> > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> >>>> > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd
> >>>> rather
> >>>> > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> >>>> > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > anyhoo!
> >>>> >
> >>>> > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> >>>> > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you
> >>>> can't
> >>>> > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't d=
o
> >>>> > that, what's the point?
> >>>> >
> >>>> > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a
> >>>> drum
> >>>> > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> >>>> > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that disma=
l
> >>>> > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out
> >>>> some
> >>>> > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> >>>> > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
> >>>> >
> >>>> > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because
> >>>> it's
> >>>> > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> >>>> > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> >>>> > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
> >>>> >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

Well, that's where the whole "you can just hop on this thing and let it 
drive itself" theory is blown out of the window (I would guess - I'm sure 
George can correct me if I'm wrong though - thanks George!). You still have 
to have a sense of how to DJ using a program like that. So I'm sure you have 
to work it like you would decks. I think it just makes it a little easier.

The biggest thing that annoys me about folks who dismiss DJing programs and 
tools as "cheating" is, you still have to have a reasonable sense of how to 
craft a set, layer and transition tracks, etc. You COULd just let the 
program do it all for you, but it'll sound like ass as a result.

> >>> The only thing is, pitch-corrected time stretching in real time often
> >>> sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
> >>> hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
> >>> "Master Pitch", it's just laughable!  Ewwy.
> >>>
> >>> Certainly "close enough for jazz" though for mashup/remix on the fly
> >>> usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
> >>> tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.
> >>>
> >>> Cheers,
> >>> -GC
> >>>
> >>> --- "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> >>>
> >>>> You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just
> >>>> vinyl.
> >>>>
> >>>> For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it
> >>>> to
> >>>> 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch
> >>>> it down
> >>>> to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
> >>>>
> >>>> With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and
> >>>> vice
> >>>> versa).
> >>>>
> >>>> The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the
> >>>> beats...unless
> >>>> someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from
> >>>> the
> >>>> Pioneer CDJ's)
> >>>> ----- Original Message -----
> >>>> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> >>>> To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> >>>> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> >>>> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> >>>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> >>>>
> >>>>
> >>>> oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
> >>>>
> >>>> I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
> >>>>
> >>>> beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> >>>> Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> >>>> talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
> >>>> and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
> >>>>
> >>>> 80bpm * 60 percent = 80 * .6 = 48
> >>>> 80 + 48 = 128 = max tempo for record A: 128bpm
> >>>>
> >>>> 160 * 60 % = 160 * .6 = 96
> >>>> 160bpm - 96bpm = 64bpm = lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm
> >>>>
> >>>> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> >>>> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> >>>> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> >>>> play them both at house tempo.
> >>>>
> >>>> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
> >>>> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> >>>> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
> >>>> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
> >>>> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
> >>>>
> >>>> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> >>>> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
> >>>> about is
> >>>> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
> >>>> an 80
> >>>> > bpm
> >>>> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
> >>>> all due
> >>>> > to
> >>>> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or
> >>>> slow
> >>>> > it
> >>>> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> >>>> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
> >>>> "true"
> >>>> > as
> >>>> > Ableton.

> >>>> the
> >>>> > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?

> >>>> > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
> >>>> > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the

> >>>> > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!

> >>>> it's

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

--0-428166624-1133486655=:11447
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Live is actually very good with any tracks that are layered without very strong kick-drums. There is a number of tools, but the bottom line is - when you edit the clip for playing it later, you can choose to warp (time-stretch) the clip in any way you desire. In other words, if you want the funk track to be at 120 BPM, you just set up the markers within clip editing, warp the track, and voila. You can also set the track up to be 4/4, 3/6, or whatever the hell else your heart desires. In addition to that, Live has various ways of how it time-stretches the tracks depending on the size of sound "grains" you want to use. Beats are easiest to time-stretch, but other options such as textures, complex sounds, etc. are available. Hope this help!

Acid Totem <acidtotem@gmail.com> wrote:  So how does Ableton Live adapt to something like an old school funk or disco
track where a drum machine was not used, hence the BPM fluctuates all
over???

> >>> The only thing is, pitch-corrected time stretching in real time often
> >>> sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
> >>> hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
> >>> "Master Pitch", it's just laughable! Ewwy.
> >>>
> >>> Certainly "close enough for jazz" though for mashup/remix on the fly
> >>> usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
> >>> tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.
> >>>
> >>> Cheers,
> >>> -GC
> >>>
> >>> --- "Marc(O)" wrote:
> >>>
> >>>> You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just
> >>>> vinyl.
> >>>>
> >>>> For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it
> >>>> to
> >>>> 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch
> >>>> it down
> >>>> to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
> >>>>
> >>>> With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and
> >>>> vice
> >>>> versa).
> >>>>
> >>>> The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the
> >>>> beats...unless
> >>>> someone has put out decks that take care of that too. (aside from
> >>>> the
> >>>> Pioneer CDJ's)
> >>>> ----- Original Message -----
> >>>> From: "Giles Soundwave" 
> >>>> To: "Marc(O)" 
> >>>> Cc: 
> >>>> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> >>>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> >>>>
> >>>>
> >>>> oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
> >>>>
> >>>> I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
> >>>>
> >>>> beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> >>>> Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> >>>> talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
> >>>> and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
> >>>>
> >>>> 80bpm * 60 percent = 80 * .6 = 48
> >>>> 80 + 48 = 128 = max tempo for record A: 128bpm
> >>>>
> >>>> 160 * 60 % = 160 * .6 = 96
> >>>> 160bpm - 96bpm = 64bpm = lowest achievable speed for record B: 64bpm
> >>>>
> >>>> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> >>>> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> >>>> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> >>>> play them both at house tempo.
> >>>>
> >>>> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
> >>>> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> >>>> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
> >>>> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
> >>>> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
> >>>>
> >>>> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) wrote:
> >>>> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
> >>>> about is
> >>>> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
> >>>> an 80
> >>>> > bpm
> >>>> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
> >>>> all due
> >>>> > to
> >>>> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or
> >>>> slow
> >>>> > it
> >>>> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> >>>> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
> >>>> "true"
> >>>> > as
> >>>> > Ableton.
> >>>> > ----- Original Message -----
> >>>> > From: "Giles Soundwave" 
> >>>> > To: 
> >>>> > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
> >>>> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> >>>> >
> >>>> >
> >>>> > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's
> >>>> music, you
> >>>> > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal. Sick of the
> >>>> lazy
> >>>> > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook,
> >>>> calling it
> >>>> > > a
> >>>> > > live set, and it being other people's music.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
> >>>> > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
> >>>> > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
> >>>> > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
> >>>> > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources
> >>>> of
> >>>> > meaningful output.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock
> >>>> it
> >>>> > til you've tried it.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
> >>>> > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
> >>>> > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
> >>>> > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus
> >>>> sixty
> >>>> > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
> >>>> > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
> >>>> > possibility.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > anyway back to needling Andy:
> >>>> >
> >>>> > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or
> >>>> skill. It's
> >>>> > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not
> >>>> their
> >>>> > > work.
> >>>> > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of
> >>>> communication
> >>>> >
> >>>> > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen
> >>>> people
> >>>> > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with
> >>>> vinyl,
> >>>> > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
> >>>> > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
> >>>> > going to crash.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a
> >>>> frikking
> >>>> > > tune
> >>>> > > already. You already have the notebook and the software, now
> >>>> pony up
> >>>> > > and
> >>>> > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to
> >>>> the
> >>>> > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
> >>>> >
> >>>> > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
> >>>> > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the
> >>>> ease-of-use
> >>>> > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science,
> >>>> you
> >>>> > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
> >>>> > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> >>>> > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's
> >>>> like,
> >>>> > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string
> >>>> words
> >>>> > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading,
> >>>> let
> >>>> > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> >>>> > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd
> >>>> rather
> >>>> > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> >>>> > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
> >>>> >
> >>>> > anyhoo!
> >>>> >
> >>>> > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> >>>> > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you
> >>>> can't
> >>>> > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
> >>>> > that, what's the point?
> >>>> >
> >>>> > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a
> >>>> drum
> >>>> > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> >>>> > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
> >>>> > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out
> >>>> some
> >>>> > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> >>>> > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
> >>>> >
> >>>> > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because
> >>>> it's
> >>>> > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> >>>> > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> >>>> > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
> >>>> >

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

> <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you 
> think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This 
> question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me 
> about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to 
> understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is: 
> 'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it 
> doesn't, it is of no use."
> -Don Juan
>
> "A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
> -Edward R. Murrow
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

well, wtf do I know. these conversations always devolve into status
wars anyway. ninety percent of the time it's some idiot posting
senseless madness just to get people to look at him. we might as well
just be whipping our dicks out and lining up to measure them with a
ruler. or a yardstick. or, in my case, satellite photography.

I had this one dude, one time, posting to a list I was on, like three
days after I praised Event Trias, and he's posting all about how
nobody who knew what they were doing would ever use Event monitors of
any kind for any reason ever ever ever. he sidestepped my post, and
then dissed it when I wasn't looking, like some kind of cowardly
little bitch. so the next day I see "Scratch," and in the scene where
Q-Bert and DJ Shadow are scratching, like in a jam session, guess what
their monitor system is? Event Tria. same shit I got in my room right
here.

every time, man. every fucking time.

some people just get the monkey. you even give them a shot, but no,
the monkey is the only thing they're willing to earn. you're like,
hey, I could give you some props, you want some props? and they're
like, give me the monkey! and you're like, you're sure? I got all
these props right here, some of them would fit you perfectly, I mean
look at these ones here, they even match your t-shirt, same shade of
blue, brings out the color of your eyes -- and they just interrupt you
like, fuck you! the monkey! hand it over now!

it's like, ok, ok, here's your monkey. take it, go.

anyway, the Korg Prophecy -- I sold my Prophecy too. one of the worst
mistakes I ever made. when I said it was complex I meant the
programming -- getting sound out of it was easy. in fact it was
incredibly easy, unbelievable expressive power, the thing had this
ribbon board you could push, pull, and slide your fingers around on in
a thousand different ways. if you switched from fingertips to
fingernails? different sound. that was where the interface they
eventually used on the Kaoss Pad initially came from. but they put it
on a mod wheel, so you could simultaneously work in additional
dimensions (i.e., modulate resonance with your fingertips, and filter
pitch with the wheel). it also had a regular mod wheel, and the
standard pitch bend wheel as well. that thing was so nice. I get
wistful just thinking about it. I probably have more affection for the
Prophecy I sold than I do for most of my ex-girlfriends.

sold my Tria, too, but I had enough sense to get a new one. nearly got
rid of that, too, but luckily I recovered my senses. (luckily for me
at least.)


Giles


On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> My friend Don just sold a Prophecy. I don't recall it ever being especial=
ly
> complicated - but maybe he could correct me.
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> To: "georgeC | origami" <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
> Cc: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:34 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
>
>
> "Close enough for jazz"? My experience is that jazz guys are the
> pickiest, least prone to corner-cutting guys on the planet. Classical
> musicians are mercenaries by comparison. I mean look at Carl Craig. As
> far as I can tell the only electronic music gear that was ever close
> enough for jazz was the Korg Prophecy. Programming that thing requires
> multiple graduate degrees in korgprophecyology.
>
> Sorry, I just don't understand what you mean.
>
> On 12/1/05, georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > The only thing is, pitch-corrected time stretching in real time often
> > sounds pretty nasty on Live, Acid, Traktor or the like- on a piece of
> > hardware like a CDJ or one of those fruity Stanton turntables with
> > "Master Pitch", it's just laughable!  Ewwy.
> >
> > Certainly "close enough for jazz" though for mashup/remix on the fly
> > usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
> > tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.
> >
> > Cheers,
> > -GC
> >
> > --- "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > > You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using just
> > > vinyl.
> > >
> > > For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch it
> > > to
> > > 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitch
> > > it down
> > > to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
> > >
> > > With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (and
> > > vice
> > > versa).
> > >
> > > The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the
> > > beats...unless
> > > someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from
> > > the
> > > Pioneer CDJ's)
> > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > > To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> > > Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> > > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> > >
> > >
> > > oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
> > >
> > > I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
> > >
> > > beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> > > Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> > > talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degree,
> > > and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
> > >
> > > 80bpm * 60 percent =3D 80 * .6 =3D 48
> > > 80 + 48 =3D 128 =3D max tempo for record A: 128bpm
> > >
> > > 160 * 60 % =3D 160 * .6 =3D 96
> > > 160bpm - 96bpm =3D 64bpm =3D lowest achievable speed for record B: 64=
bpm
> > >
> > > this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm and
> > > 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle record
> > > and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, or
> > > play them both at house tempo.
> > >
> > > I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined it
> > > to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> > > dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with more
> > > sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you're
> > > describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
> > >
> > > On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > > > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
> > > about is
> > > > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - like
> > > an 80
> > > > bpm
> > > > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> > > >
> > > > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
> > > all due
> > > > to
> > > > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up (or
> > > slow
> > > > it
> > > > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Other
> > > > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth and
> > > "true"
> > > > as
> > > > Ableton.
> > > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > > From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > > > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > > > Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 11:54 AM
> > > > Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > > I think if you're using Ableton Live to play other people's
> > > music, you
> > > > > should go get fucked by a large barnyard animal.  Sick of the
> > > lazy
> > > > > mashups, sick of the inherent lie in playing off a notebook,
> > > calling it
> > > > > a
> > > > > live set, and it being other people's music.
> > > >
> > > > Andy, whatever. realistically you're assessing the output with your
> > > > ears or you're just filling those ears with the sound of your own
> > > > voice. you can do anything you want with your laptop on stage, play
> > > > Solitaire, look at porn, IM your mother and ask her how she's been,
> > > > who gives a shit? the speakers and the crowd are the only sources
> > > of
> > > > meaningful output.
> > > >
> > > > also, about getting fucked by a large barnyard animal: don't knock
> > > it
> > > > til you've tried it.
> > > >
> > > > also, this is just technical, but all that stuff somebody else was
> > > > saying about beat-matching hip-hop with hardcore? technically that
> > > > **is** something you can achieve with vinyl. I've done it just to
> > > > irritate my neighbors. the Vestax PDX2000s can do plus or minus
> > > sixty
> > > > percent. I'm not saying it's a good idea, I'm just saying that even
> > > > within the context of a vinyl-only set, it is still a technical
> > > > possibility.
> > > >
> > > > anyway back to needling Andy:
> > > >
> > > > > It's DJing without the immediacy, intensity, physicality or
> > > skill.  It's
> > > > > like the intimacy of a producer playing live, except it's not
> > > their
> > > > > work.
> > > > > More and more, sets are more polished, and less a form of
> > > communication
> > > >
> > > > mmm, ok, but what's that got to do with Live? you've never seen
> > > people
> > > > doing that the old-school way? I have. I've seen it done with
> > > vinyl,
> > > > and I've seen it done with traditional instruments too, for that
> > > > matter. one way or another, if you're asleep at the wheel, you're
> > > > going to crash.
> > > >
> > > > > Like, get over your omgpwnz0rRmXsK1LLZ and learn to write a
> > > frikking
> > > > > tune
> > > > > already.  You already have the notebook and the software, now
> > > pony up
> > > > > and
> > > > > do the part that makes it creative, that makes it an addition to
> > > the
> > > > > world, that makes it um... >yours< maybe?
> > > >
> > > > just to play devil's advocate, screw making it yours. first make it
> > > > **good**. then make it yours. that's the downside with the
> > > ease-of-use
> > > > with all this crap. back when it was like fucking rocket science,
> > > you
> > > > wouldn't get people being like, look, I made a beat, hooray for me!
> > > > but with the massively reduced learning curve, everybody and their
> > > > mama can make some crap without even breaking a sweat. but it's
> > > like,
> > > > look at authors, look at novels. anybody in the world can string
> > > words
> > > > together, how many people write sentences that are worth reading,
> > > let
> > > > alone remembering or quoting to somebody else? minimal creation
> > > > overhead doesn't mean an increased volume of masterpieces. I'd
> > > rather
> > > > hear somebody play somebody else's music well, rather than playing
> > > > their own badly. take the time to get it right.
> > > >
> > > > anyhoo!
> > > >
> > > > Live vs. Traktor? for live performance, I still say MPC, or
> > > > traditional instruments. if you can't put your body in it, you
> > > can't
> > > > synchronize with the crowd's physical response, and if you can't do
> > > > that, what's the point?
> > > >
> > > > also, I made an absolute fool of myself with a Yamaha CS2X and a
> > > drum
> > > > machine one time, but afterwards I figured out how to get the MIDI
> > > > sync right (duh), and it sounded great. anybody who saw that dismal
> > > > fiasco is unlikely to believe me, but I think you could kick out
> > > some
> > > > incredible techno with a CS2X, an MPC, and a couple Roland V-Drums
> > > > hooked up to a sampler (hardware, software, either one).
> > > >
> > > > but, if I had to take one or the other, I'd go with Live, because
> > > it's
> > > > much more powerful, and it's much better to use a subset of the
> > > > functionality of an extremely powerful tool than to be pushing a
> > > > minimally-effective tool to its limits.
> > > >
> > > > --
> > > > Giles Soundwave =3D Giles Goat Boy
> > > > http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/
> > > >
> > > >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ

Getting things warped correctly in live involves dragging "warp
markers" which denote bar /beat locations onto their appropriate
locations over the waveform itself.  In this way, you can actually
make an off-time drummer as rigid as a drum machine, if desired.



On 12/1/05, Acid Totem <acidtotem@gmail.com> wrote:
> So how does Ableton Live adapt to something like an old school funk or di=
sco
> track where a drum machine was not used, hence the BPM fluctuates all
> over???

y
> > >>> usage as long as the bed track that's really supplying the boom and
> > >>> tizz is left at optimal speed/pitch.
> > >>>
> > >>> Cheers,
> > >>> -GC
> > >>>
> > >>> --- "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > >>>
> > >>>> You cannot achieve the same thing and keep the same pitch using ju=
st
> > >>>> vinyl.
> > >>>>
> > >>>> For instance - if a vocal track sound perfect at 120, if you pitch=
 it
> > >>>> to
> > >>>> 160, now the vocals sound like the frickin' chipmunks. If you pitc=
h
> > >>>> it down
> > >>>> to 80bpm, it sounds like Barry White. (you get the point)
> > >>>>
> > >>>> With Live, it sounds exactly as it did at 120 at 160, 180 or up (a=
nd
> > >>>> vice
> > >>>> versa).
> > >>>>
> > >>>> The +/- features on turntables only allow you to match the
> > >>>> beats...unless
> > >>>> someone has put out decks that take care of that too.  (aside from
> > >>>> the
> > >>>> Pioneer CDJ's)
> > >>>> ----- Original Message -----
> > >>>> From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
> > >>>> To: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> > >>>> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > >>>> Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 12:05 PM
> > >>>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] ableton Live vs Traktor DJ
> > >>>>
> > >>>>
> > >>>> oh no no no no. you do not understand me.
> > >>>>
> > >>>> I will say it again -- plus or minus sixty percent.
> > >>>>
> > >>>> beat-matching 80pm with 160bpm was my challenge back when Kruder &
> > >>>> Dorfmeister did their K7 DJ Kicks thingy. late 90s shit. no, I'm
> > >>>> talking about pitch-shifting an 80bpm record up to an absurd degre=
e,
> > >>>> and pitch-shifting a 160bpm record down to an absurd degree.
> > >>>>
> > >>>> 80bpm * 60 percent =3D 80 * .6 =3D 48
> > >>>> 80 + 48 =3D 128 =3D max tempo for record A: 128bpm
> > >>>>
> > >>>> 160 * 60 % =3D 160 * .6 =3D 96
> > >>>> 160bpm - 96bpm =3D 64bpm =3D lowest achievable speed for record B:=
 64bpm
> > >>>>
> > >>>> this means that the two records can match anywhere between 64bpm a=
nd
> > >>>> 128bpm. this means you can take a hip-hop record and a jungle reco=
rd
> > >>>> and play them both at dub tempo, play them both at hip-hop tempo, =
or
> > >>>> play them both at house tempo.
> > >>>>
> > >>>> I'm not saying it's a good idea. I'm just saying I have determined=
 it
> > >>>> to be technically feasible, beyond a shadow of a doubt. I'm not
> > >>>> dissing Live, either -- I'm sure you'd get smoother results with m=
ore
> > >>>> sophisticated technology -- but for the sake of accuracy, what you=
're
> > >>>> describing can be accomplished in some cases using only vinyl.
> > >>>>
> > >>>> On 12/1/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > >>>> > It's not beatmathcing hip-hop and hardcore - what you're talking
> > >>>> about is
> > >>>> > just matching a half time track with a full time (?) track - lik=
e
> > >>>> an 80
> > >>>> > bpm
> > >>>> > track w/ a 160 bpm track - that's pretty easy.
> > >>>> >
> > >>>> > I'm talking about taking stuff that could NOT be beat matched at
> > >>>> all due
> > >>>> > to
> > >>>> > tempo/bpm, and using the time stretching feature to speed it up =
(or
> > >>>> slow
> > >>>> > it
> > >>>> > down), but still retaining the original pitch of the track. Othe=
r
> > >>>> > programs/gear, etc. will allow this - but none quite as smooth a=
nd
> > >>>> "true"
> > >>>> > as
> > >>>> > Ableton.

Greets,

Well Konvolve was a nice event last week. For a moment there was a bit of 
hard techno in the SF.. ;)  DJ Amok is a very cool dude and I had the 
opportunity to throw down with him the morning after the event on KZSU 
Stanford radio. The recording came out great and is available here:
http://www.egregious.net/events/2005/konvolve/#livemix

I look forward to attempting to kick start a hard techno / rhythmic 
industrial / powernoise scene here in SF geared more towards the 
underground outside the clubs.  Hope to see you out next time...

Best,

"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

	format=flowed

CLUB SCENE GROWS UP

The party isn't over in S.F. -- it has just moved on to smaller,  
mellower places. Nights of excess in huge venues give way to calmer  
gatherings in more intimate settings.

Carolyne Zinko, Chronicle Staff Writer
Friday, December 2, 2005

On a Thursday night at Mars Bar, at the corner of Seventh and Brannan  
streets, Carla Eggleston, 40, stood on the patio, smoking a cigarette  
and contemplating her surroundings.

Music from the dance floor wafted outside. Strands of colored lights  
twinkled over tables where people mingled. Men were dressed as if  
inspired by Gap commercials. Women favored halter tops or halter  
dresses atop jeans with high heels, their arms bare despite a chill  
in the air.

For Eggleston, a decorative painter who used to go to cavernous dance  
clubs where talking was less important than bumping and grinding  
until 2 a.m., the subdued scene was just fine.

"I was just at a large club last Saturday, and it was a mosh scene,"  
she said. "I got pushed around and spilled on. ... It's no fun for us  
adults. I'm so happy to be here -- it's nice and mellow. I know  
everybody.''

Raving with the masses is out. Sipping in selective company is in. A  
downbeat economy, the aging of Generation X and the pendulum-like  
swing of fashion (and of fashionable drugs) are spurring a trend away  
from the previous decade's favorite way to party -- DJ dance fests  
for 1,000 or more -- toward gatherings at small bars and clubs where  
people can talk without shouting, drink without being spilled on and  
spare themselves exorbitant cover charges.

Ever since the dot-com bust flushed thousands of well-paid young  
people -- and their money -- out of the Bay Area faster than a bar's  
last call, it also has been closing the door on partying to excess.  
Some dance clubs have closed, and the bigger ones are lucky to fill  
up once a week, several party promoters said.

"Big clubs were an era that was very important -- it was a time of  
celebration and the evolution of the big-name DJ as entertainer,''  
said Audrey Joseph, vice president of the San Francisco Entertainment  
Commission, who ran Club Townsend on Harrison Street for 10 years.

Now, she said, "there's a move to a lounge society -- and to people  
staying at home, Tivo-ing shows, playing videos and meeting people  
online. Lounges are easier to access, less expensive and so numerous  
that they tend to develop their own little crowds. You can pick and  
choose where you want to go.''

In the 1990s and early 2000s, it was not unusual for clubs to have  
cover charges of $35, $40 or even $50 -- necessary to fly in DJs from  
London, Amsterdam or even Ibiza and pay them the going rate of  
$35,000 for a night's work.

But now, customers can't -- or won't -- pony up for high cover  
charges plus drinks at $10 apiece for a night's entertainment.

MORE:

http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/12/02/ 
MNGSNG1SQH1.DTL



MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times  
as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one  
question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My  
benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was  
too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I  
will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does  
the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-1-636691763--

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Uberzone and Carbon Community - SATURDAY @ Studio Z

yes, there are two seperate parties.  two seperate entrances.  two
seperate lineups.  both in one night.

DIRTY is 21+ and will be in the main room of Studio Z.  all breaks.=20
thrown by Evil Breaks.

Black Magik is 18+ and will be in the back room.  breaks and trance.=20
thrown by Evil Breaks and Electrosorcery.

Uberzone and Carbon Community will be doing full, live PAs at DIRTY.=20
they will be doing laptop sets at Black Magik.

we did this because Evil Breaks has kinda been living in two worlds.=20
we play at and have thrown many all ages parties and have a following
among the younger ravers.  we also play at and throw many 21+ parties
and have a following among older clubbers, burners and geriatric
ravers.  so since we were bringing in these two fantastic acts, we
wanted everyone to have a chance to see them in their own, comfortable
setting.  DIRTY will be very much what our older crowd expects.  Black
Magik, in association with Electrosorcery, will be very much "rave."

we hope folks aren't too confused!  we just want everyone to come out,
have a good time, and enjoy some really fucking awesome music!

-b

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Uberzone and Carbon Community - SATURDAY @ Studio Z

My $10 went to the adult party. Plus we get to see the acts w/ drumemrs and 
gear. Much better than the laptop sets!!!
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
To: "Sean G" <rationalhatter@gmail.com>
Cc: "haters" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, December 02, 2005 2:40 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Uberzone and Carbon Community - 
SATURDAY @ Studio Z


yes, there are two seperate parties.  two seperate entrances.  two
seperate lineups.  both in one night.

DIRTY is 21+ and will be in the main room of Studio Z.  all breaks.
thrown by Evil Breaks.

Black Magik is 18+ and will be in the back room.  breaks and trance.
thrown by Evil Breaks and Electrosorcery.

Uberzone and Carbon Community will be doing full, live PAs at DIRTY.
they will be doing laptop sets at Black Magik.

we did this because Evil Breaks has kinda been living in two worlds.
we play at and have thrown many all ages parties and have a following
among the younger ravers.  we also play at and throw many 21+ parties
and have a following among older clubbers, burners and geriatric
ravers.  so since we were bringing in these two fantastic acts, we
wanted everyone to have a chance to see them in their own, comfortable
setting.  DIRTY will be very much what our older crowd expects.  Black
Magik, in association with Electrosorcery, will be very much "rave."

we hope folks aren't too confused!  we just want everyone to come out,
have a good time, and enjoy some really fucking awesome music!

-b

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Uberzone and Carbon Community - SATURDAY @ Studio Z

a word on presales.

we are currently at 80 tickets sold online for Dirty.  judging from
how our past shows have done, this is a sign that this party may
actually sell out!

if you want to make sure you get in, i'd suggest getting a presale or
show up early.

i know, that sounds like a bunch of marketting hoo-ey...but that's a
lot of ticket sales for a venue with a capacity of about 400.  that
and the fact that we gave away a LOT of free tickets via our email
lists, radio shows, etc.

you can still grab yours on Groovetickets.com until midnight tonight!


On 12/2/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> My $10 went to the adult party. Plus we get to see the acts w/ drumemrs a=

> gear. Much better than the laptop sets!!!
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
> To: "Sean G" <rationalhatter@gmail.com>
> Cc: "haters" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Friday, December 02, 2005 2:40 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Uberzone and Carbon Community -
> SATURDAY @ Studio Z
>
>
> yes, there are two seperate parties.  two seperate entrances.  two
> seperate lineups.  both in one night.
>
> DIRTY is 21+ and will be in the main room of Studio Z.  all breaks.
> thrown by Evil Breaks.
>
> Black Magik is 18+ and will be in the back room.  breaks and trance.
> thrown by Evil Breaks and Electrosorcery.
>
> Uberzone and Carbon Community will be doing full, live PAs at DIRTY.
> they will be doing laptop sets at Black Magik.
>
> we did this because Evil Breaks has kinda been living in two worlds.
> we play at and have thrown many all ages parties and have a following
> among the younger ravers.  we also play at and throw many 21+ parties
> and have a following among older clubbers, burners and geriatric
> ravers.  so since we were bringing in these two fantastic acts, we
> wanted everyone to have a chance to see them in their own, comfortable
> setting.  DIRTY will be very much what our older crowd expects.  Black
> Magik, in association with Electrosorcery, will be very much "rave."
>
> we hope folks aren't too confused!  we just want everyone to come out,
> have a good time, and enjoy some really fucking awesome music!
>
> -b
>

From: Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Cc: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <93FC9353-1A12-4F25-9922-5C7ADFAFD65B@speakeasy.org>

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline
