X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] CLUB SCENE GROWS UP

Yes, I've seen this already, and I have my skepticism about it. (Of
course.) Number one thing -- a lot of the most interesting things in
the SF music scene, you're more likely to spot if you buy London drum
and bass fanzines for the breaks reviews than you are if you're
getting your news from the local SF paper. Audio Angel did all the
vocals for the new Influx album; the Violence crew just finished an
album too (very popular d&b label based in SF, with one London member
who moved to SF to record the album and then went home). Zero blips on
the SF local media radar, pages of coverage in London. And you guys
are hearing it from a guy in Santa Fe.

Weird, huh?

Anyway, I have to tell you, I've seen this exact article before, in
the Chicago Reader, in 1993. You'll see it again in ten years' time,
somewhere. There's an inevitability to this sort of thing,
particularly since the type of people who write for magazines and
papers generally think of themselves as cooler than they actually are,
and thus **always** interpret trends in their own social circles as
the future of society in general. What actually happened is some
writer observed to some other writer that neither of them really felt
like going to big clubs any more, and behold! they discovered the
future of nightlife. All this means is that we're underground again,
as if we needed somebody to tell us that.

If you're really feeling threatened? Don't. Lounge scenes never last
long -- it's like having a "scene" that revolves around wallpaper and
sofas -- and for some reason their musical output is rarely
competitive even with elevator muzak in terms of quality. Back when
lounge was allegedly cool in Chicago, I picked up some tracks by 18th
Street, the guys who eventually became Thievery Corporation. I threw
the CD away after I took a cab downtown and recognized an 18th Street
track on the cabbie's easy listening radio station. I just wasn't
ready to be part of that demographic.

DJs shouldn't read the paper anyway. Does a bird need a weatherman to
tell it the direction of the wind? But if you do read the paper, read
a paper like Knowledge, ATM, or Mofo (which is hard to get in the
States, but worth it.)

On 12/2/05, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> CLUB SCENE GROWS UP
>
> The party isn't over in S.F. -- it has just moved on to smaller,
> mellower places. Nights of excess in huge venues give way to calmer
> gatherings in more intimate settings.
>
> Carolyne Zinko, Chronicle Staff Writer
> Friday, December 2, 2005
>
> On a Thursday night at Mars Bar, at the corner of Seventh and Brannan
> streets, Carla Eggleston, 40, stood on the patio, smoking a cigarette
> and contemplating her surroundings.
>
> Music from the dance floor wafted outside. Strands of colored lights
> twinkled over tables where people mingled. Men were dressed as if
> inspired by Gap commercials. Women favored halter tops or halter
> dresses atop jeans with high heels, their arms bare despite a chill
> in the air.
>
> For Eggleston, a decorative painter who used to go to cavernous dance
> clubs where talking was less important than bumping and grinding
> until 2 a.m., the subdued scene was just fine.
>
> "I was just at a large club last Saturday, and it was a mosh scene,"
> she said. "I got pushed around and spilled on. ... It's no fun for us
> adults. I'm so happy to be here -- it's nice and mellow. I know
> everybody.''
>
> Raving with the masses is out. Sipping in selective company is in. A
> downbeat economy, the aging of Generation X and the pendulum-like
> swing of fashion (and of fashionable drugs) are spurring a trend away
> from the previous decade's favorite way to party -- DJ dance fests
> for 1,000 or more -- toward gatherings at small bars and clubs where
> people can talk without shouting, drink without being spilled on and
> spare themselves exorbitant cover charges.
>
> Ever since the dot-com bust flushed thousands of well-paid young
> people -- and their money -- out of the Bay Area faster than a bar's
> last call, it also has been closing the door on partying to excess.
> Some dance clubs have closed, and the bigger ones are lucky to fill
> up once a week, several party promoters said.
>
> "Big clubs were an era that was very important -- it was a time of
> celebration and the evolution of the big-name DJ as entertainer,''
> said Audrey Joseph, vice president of the San Francisco Entertainment
> Commission, who ran Club Townsend on Harrison Street for 10 years.
>
> Now, she said, "there's a move to a lounge society -- and to people
> staying at home, Tivo-ing shows, playing videos and meeting people
> online. Lounges are easier to access, less expensive and so numerous
> that they tend to develop their own little crowds. You can pick and
> choose where you want to go.''
>
> In the 1990s and early 2000s, it was not unusual for clubs to have
> cover charges of $35, $40 or even $50 -- necessary to fly in DJs from
> London, Amsterdam or even Ibiza and pay them the going rate of
> $35,000 for a night's work.
>
> But now, customers can't -- or won't -- pony up for high cover
> charges plus drinks at $10 apiece for a night's entertainment.
>
> MORE:
>
> http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=3D/c/a/2005/12/02/
> MNGSNG1SQH1.DTL
>
>
>
> MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>
> Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times
> as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one
> question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My
> benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was
> too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I
> will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does
> the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
> -Don Juan
>
> "A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
> -Edward R. Murrow
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of
> the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will
> gradually become visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>
>
>

http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

Subject: [sfraves] all this talk about a diminishing scene and my recent comment about breaks

------=_NextPart_000_0007_01C5F761.9FE2B390
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

After I said "wtf $10 for breaks no thanks", I couldn't help but think =
about how ridiculous a comment that was.  First off, back in the day, we =
had our choice of parties and people were falling over themselves to get =
you to one of their events.

Now it's like "wtf am I saying '$10 for breaks no thanks' for?"  I =
should be so thankful that people are keeping it going strong.  Because =
when had my head shaved except for my bangs (some ASR kids remember =
that), all I kept saying was "omg diversity, we need different kinds of =
sets for a night".

Diversity is now spread over several weeks or months.  And I should be =
going to everything I like because that's in most of our nature as =
ravers.  To support what we like and cherish what we love.

with love unconditional

n i c o
------=_NextPart_000_0007_01C5F761.9FE2B390--

and salsa and happy hour drinks. Open decks from 6-7 every week, please 
email. Located @ Luna Lounge 8th St. and 1192 Folsom St. SF, CA 94103.

Dick Gail; Hardcore Room: Ballistic Ali, Chance, 1up; 18+ to enter, 21 + 
to drink, Music Starts at 9pm. Located at the stoney inn 1320 del paso 
blvd, Sacramento, CA 95628. $6 cover doors open at 9, Drink specials all 
night. Info Line 415-267-6924

Featuring Deep Voices (Noys Records), Mars (Frequency8, Alienaided), 
Dyloot (Deep Voices, Ajusted, NOYS, SkillsDJ), Enemy (SkillsDJ), John 
Beaver (Skills/XL Promotions). Located @ Club Avalon 777 Lawrence 
Expressway; Santa Clara, CA 95051. 21+ 9pm-2am. Free parking. $20 door.

Nocturnalism Entertainment *

This will be Nocturnalism's 2 year Anniversary celebration party!!  This 
is an ALL 80's Cartoon Themed Event! So break out the 80's cartoon themed 
appearal and costumes to receive $5 off at the door!!  Room 1: Hardcore: 
Mike Hemp (Hardcore Junkies/H2OH, Los Angeles), Daywalker (Pitched Up 
Recordings PA), The Nice Guys (K12/KFA), Go-Zania (HCFTP/Hard Science) vs

Joshuah, Cracker Jack (Hard Heads/Nu Vision), Kid Orange (Nocturnalism/Nu 
Vision) vs DJ 2QT (HCFTP/Nu Vision), Precision (Hard Heads/Atomic NRG), 
Rye Bread (DTS); Room 2: House / Breaks / Trance: DJ Fixx (Bottom-End 
Records FL), Carlos Alfonzo (Bayraves/YuccaTribe/Wild 94.9 
HouseNation/Zapatista's) vs Doza (Zapatista's/Bayraves), Orionz 
(NLP/Bayraves), Nick Nyquil (Oneiromancy), Andy P (Nocturnalism/DTS), 
Vinyl Junkies (Zapatista's), On-It (Audio Metamorphosis/Cal Trance), ill-D 
the DJ (Nocturnalism/Ill Behavior/Modified), DJ PM (Nocturnalism), Durty 
(Nocturnalism); Room 3: D&B & a lil more Hard Stuff: Infiltrata 
(Metalheadz/Barcode/ Imperial Los Angeles) w/XYZ (45 psi), The Doctor 
(Bayraves/Rythm Method/DTS) w/MC Fader (Bayraves/DTS), Arize (Imperial 
Recordings/DTS) w/ MC Dre (Barcode/Imperial), RiFF RaFF (Zapatista's/Hard 
Heads/Bayraves) vs Ballistic Ali (Distorted Trauma/NBR), Yagi (OTC/HCFTP) 
vs Cubehead (OTC) w/MC Ax1om; Reclipse (Drum Syndicate/Bayraves), H-Rock 
(Distorted Trauma/NBR) vs Elektroholic (Distorted Trauma/NBR), Joey Frisco 
(Nocturnalism/DTS), Jolan Ray (Nocturnalism's Newest Resident), Bemaniac 
(Nocturnalism). 800+ person capacity. Bay Area location (CA). All ages. 
8pm-5am. Infoline 415.289.2002

and Evil Breaks *

Join us in San Francisco for a dark night of bass and beats as 
Elektrosorcery and Evil Breaks combine energy and bring forth the spirits 
of Dance, Art, and Revelry.  Dress up in BLACK for this dark theme event.

415.267.6921 and 415.267.1800

Saturday, December 10, 2005 * Orbit presented by Kings Entertainment and 
Tunnel-Vizions *

Prepare yourself for another fun night as we take you on a journey through 
the stars!! - Expect nothing but the best in house and trance from the bay 
area and abroad! Your guides for the evening are as follows: Trance - 
Gamma, Kid Wicked, Wavelength, Epsilon, Apot, Leon Cook and Psyan. House - 
Filter Frequency, Carlos Alfonzo, Nick Nyquil, Deft, Andy P, Delro and

Vending By Omni Era, Poi Performance by the lovely Spam.We'll be going 
strong from 8:30 PM until 4 AM in the morning. Opening Dj'z get 1.5 
hours... $15 door. Infoline 925.806.8810  rave link flyer

Thursday, December 15, 2005 * Inbox *

Featuring House, Trance and Breaks. With Rotating Resident Djs: Aaron Jae, 
Amber, Denise, Aleks, Achillies, Apot, Dave Conlan and Hoovie. Free Chips 
and salsa and happy hour drinks. Open decks from 6-7 every week, please 
email. Located @ Luna Lounge 8th St. and 1192 Folsom St. SF, CA 94103.

Thursday, December 15, 2005 * Nocturnal Beats (Sacramento) *

Quality Electronic music every Thursday. D&B room... Soul Survivor, 
Damien, Dick Gail; Trance Room: Koroma, Da Gru, Bob-O; 3rd Room Opened - 
Christina's Birthday Party: Kenny Young, Robbie G, Lurid, Entrigue w. MC 
Mic, Digital E; 18+ to enter, 21 + to drink, Music Starts at 9pm; Located 
at the stoney inn 1320 del paso blvd, Sacramento, CA 95628, $6 cover doors 
open at 9, Drink specials all night. Info Line 415-267-6924

Saturday, December 17, 2005 * Lost In Space presented by Collective 
Conscious and Hardfloor Movement (Sacramento) *

Featurin Cantos (Urban Breaks, selekta), Dutch (Thump Radio), DJ Rigatony 
(Sagitarium Pra), DJ Daddy (Windowpaneinfinity), DJ Ohm (Saturated mind), 
Cybertribe (Cybertribe) , Justin Roth (Hardfloor movement, floor funk),

Officer Bunch, Leroy Biggs, Bob O, Mek-Gamma-Dirt, Friction, Phokus (Live 
PA), Malachi, Mr. Rogers. New Venue! There will be free fruit and candy. 
No markers, weapons, or alcohol. 9pm  whenever. $10 Before 10:30pm, $14 
After. All Responsible Ages Welcomed. In or Around Sacramento. Infoline 
916.346.7148

Thursday, December 22, 2005 * Stilldream presented by Techno Truth 
(Sacramento) *

Come Join us on this joyous night as we get ready to start the holiday 
season on the right foot. What better way then to party it up with our 
friends and family while doing something good for the community. HOUSE / 
BREAKS: David Aaron, Cantos, St. Nick Nyquil, Channelz DJ's, Dj Rizin, 
Tupperware Blue; TECHNO / PSY: G.A.M.M.A., Mek, Jyant, Dirt, Korpus 
Kallosum, Mr. Rogers & Officer Bunch, Covert; JUNGLE: Hysterisis Loop, 
Atom One, Digital E, Mercedes, Deft_One, Bionix; 7pm - 2am. 18+ to party, 
21+ to drink. Full bar with drink specials ALL night long! Serving dinner 
until 10pm. Admission to this special event: $10 or $5 with 2 cans of food 
Donations will go to the sacramento food bank. Location: The Stonney Inn, 
1320 Del Paso Blvd, Sacramento, Ca 95628 rave link flyer

Stony Inn (Sacramento) *

Area #1 (Progressive House & Breaks), Dj Dan (Los Angeles), Dj Doza, Dj 
Rockit, Undecided, Brandon Reese, More TBA. Area #2: Jungle / Drum N Bass:

Saturday, December 31st, 2005 Saturday, December 31st: New Years Eve 2006

Opel presents Infuse NYE: The Rekindling of Hope

After 4 years of being involved in NYE parties, we've managed to inoculate 
ourselves from the lemon/amateur factor by keeping the party focused on 
being a vibe centric community gathering, with a reasonable cover and our 
neo-hippy values in full effect. This NYE, will look forward to creating a 
wonderful, friendly, intimate party environment where we can all go big 
together. A sanctuary of music, vibe, and people on NYE. w/ special 
guests: Lee Coombs (Thrust / Perfecto / Fingerlickin', UK) Dylan Rhymes 
(Kingsize / Lot 49, UK) Bassbin Twins (Belgian Breaks/ Skint/ Southern 
Fried Records, SF) + Jondi & Spesh (Qool / Looq) Syd Gris (Opel / Opulent 
Temple) Ethan Miller v. ViaJay (Friends n' Family) Hoj (Opel / djhoj.com) 
Melyss (Opel / Sister SF) Fred Funk (Brass Tax) Aaron Jae v. Bam (Evil 
Breaks / sfbreaks.org) Shanti (Triple Power / Rhythm Society). + more tba 
All the NYE goodies and some surprises...9pm- till you stop dancing DNA 
Lounge 375 11th St. @ Harrison St. Pre-sales start at only $25 friends, on 
sale now @ www.opelproductions.com. Let's take a conscious, purposeful 
step together into the New Year, and have an absolutely rockin time doing 
it. That sounds like a proper end to a proper beginning....

2005-12-02 : SFRaves Calendar Stats:

-------------------------------------------------
Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.
To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

If you have events to add to the SFRaves calendar, please publish them by
Friday @ Noon to be included in the SFR Calendar Weekly Edition Mailing.

SFRaves is a not for profit entity serving the Bay Area & all forms of
electronic music for 13 years.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] CLUB SCENE GROWS UP


I still dig the track Lebonese Blonde and that other
one on the same record...

A few weeks back I had dinner at Levende Lounge which
I guess is part of the scene the article refers to. 
It was a decent (not great) dinner and the music was
decent too.  Some DJ jamming with a live guitarist and
a live bongo player.  It was a pleasant evening but we
didn't stay long enough for dancing.  I'd definitely
go back though.  I sort of like the idea of having a
nice dinner, and then loungng around, and then
dancing.  IMO there's room for both the lounge and the
large super club/rave.  They're two totally different
experiences.

Peter

> 
> A few weeks back I had dinner at Levende Lounge which
> I guess is part of the scene the article refers to. 
> It was a decent (not great) dinner and the music was
> decent too.  Some DJ jamming with a live guitarist and
> a live bongo player.  It was a pleasant evening but we
> didn't stay long enough for dancing.  I'd definitely
> go back though.  I sort of like the idea of having a

Subject: Re: [sfraves] CLUB SCENE GROWS UP

Well hey I am part of the "house-oriented crowd" then
I guess ;)

Right Mirror Conspiracy is the record.  The track
Indra was the other one I was thinking about.  Its
also a classic I think.

I think we might have seen Late Night Sneaky actually.
 I knew the DJ looked familiar but I couldn't place
him.

The next night was a Pink Mammoth anniversary with
Kevin Yost, and I'm a big fan of his music.  I should
have planned my babysitting for that night but oh
well.

I thought Levende was pretty nice, the music was good,
the crowd was mixed and having fun, and the drinks
were great.  Really the only complaint I had was that
the menu was a bit spotty; some things we had were
really good and others not so much.

In sum, I'd go back for sure.

Peter

Karina - happy almost your birthday!
   
  I would suggest going to see Rosie Thomas at Bottom of the Hill tonight, Sunday at 9:00. 
   
  http://www.rosiethomas.com/ is terrific - kind of a folk-rocky singer, but totally individual and with an odd and hilarious sense of humor. She's just a great song writer. She also does stand-up and tells little stories - her show could be anything. I don't know anything about the other two bands playing with her, but Rosie Thomas alone is worth more than $10. I wish I could go so I hope she does a great performance if you decide to check her out. 
   
  Kleiner

Subject: [sfraves] RE: [events] Other Artists Petition


Personally, I am really pushing for the new build outs! I tear down
places like this everyday and build more efficient living communities.
IE Solar, Better energy efficiency in materials, safer communities. If
the owners want to sell it or develop it......... LET THEM! It's THEIRS,
NOT YOURS! If you want it to stay the community that it is, well buy it!
The amount of people living and using that facility.......... should be
very simple to crate a trust and buy it! If ya need help on organizing
the trust......... I am totally down! Remember......... Everything
happens for a reason, maybe this will be the push to find a perfect spot
that should be owned and never torn down or taken away from the artists!
Quit bitching and start doing something if your sick of loosing spaces!=20

Being a large land owner, having let the community use my spaces, and
EVERY TIME had issues! Reckless DRUG Use, damage to the building, damage
to neighbors, car accidents, assaults etc..... Maybe the community
should better police itself so the rest of the world has a better VIEW
of the Artists! Just my thoughts.... Take it for what you will!

Matt

Subject: [sfraves] thanks from Evil Breaks

now that i've managed to sneak in a short nap after taking Uberzone to
the airport...

thanks to everyone who came out and partied their asses off!

huge thanks to Q and Davey Dave of Uberzone and Dave and Pete of
Carbon Community. fucking mashed up the place and we had a great time
getting down with them. super dope performances. super great guys. i
can't say enough good things about them!

thank you to the DJs! Smoove, Janaka and Rockit. it's always a
pleasure to have our local talent on the lineup. i'd especially like
to say that Janaka rocked it hard. f-kin wicked set following Uberzone
and kept it going til close. and Smoove has great taste in clothes.

thanks to everyone who volunteered for setup and breakdown and those
who helped out at the door. we absolutely cannot do it without all of
you and you have our gratitude.  delia, osby, tom, hillary, jen and
everyone...thank you.

thanks to Ripple and Jason for lending their equipment. everything
looked and sounded fantastic.

and a HUGE thanks to Viberation for the sick visual setup. to Terry,
Ryan and crew...you guys went above and beyond the call of duty. it
was incredible.

thanks to anyone who i may have forgotten and thanks to the folks in
san francisco who are supporting the sound and scene of breaks. can't
wait for the next one!

on behalf of Evil Breaks, we thank you.

--

  i saw lots of familiar faces, including my boys from dallas which was a  treat. i found out after the fact that cradlerock had me on the list,  but evil breaks already had my money so oh well. special props to the  door staff for letting me act da fool during the pat-downs (unrelated).  much love to marco as well for the drinks!
  
  did the black majik party up the road ever heat up? i had some friends  playing over there and popped in a couple times, but it seemed fairly  dead. the studio z party, on the other hand, was tearing the roof off. 
  
  good times!
  
  love,
  mo

Subject: [sfraves] yay

Thanks to everyone who came out and made my birthday fun on Friday, it
really felt like a partay.  There was spanking AND flogging and a Miles
Maeda appearance and birthday shots and Ambient Mafia t-shirts and various
assorted other things afoot.

George and I played 1.5 hours of our music and it was the first time I
felt like playing all our own stuff really worked as a full set going
through peaks and valleys and different styles just like as if we were
playing other people's music.  The sfr dancefloor support was mucho
appreciated, Anu was as a rockin' as it gets.

So yay, thanks, and get ready for George's special day next month, shhh
it's a secret don't tell anyone but I hear he's hitting a milestone with
this one so let's make sure to blow it out. ;)

A

Subject: [sfraves] Tim Exile: how to do a live PA

------=_Part_8920_8142179.1133893419100
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

I haven't been to big on contemporary DnB, maybe I'm stuck in the past
listening to all the old stuff by Good Lookin Label, Moving Shadow, Seba &
Pariah, Roni Size Reprazent, Johnny L, and Goldie.  I was recently visiting
the native instruments website and came across Exile, who was doing a low
budget demo video for NI's Reaktor.  What he did in the video was pretty
amazing, when you consider the newbreed of laptop "live PA's" who do little
more than tweek a few knobs cuing premade samples/loops/productions.  This
guy makes songs in realtime, and adds the ability to improv and remix live-
a lot more than just playing a cued loop or sound effect too!   Judging fro=
m
his other music I've checked out and the reviews from his shows- somebody
needs to book this guy soon!  -And this is a house/techno head saying this.

------=_Part_8920_8142179.1133893419100--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tim Exile: how to do a live PA

His shit is indeed amazing - he uses a custom Reaktor ensemble, I
believe.   There's a 10min-ish video of one of his live sets floating
around... i keep watching it over and over and cursing the brits for
getting to see him play all the time.

Some of his released tracks are a bit too undanceable squarepusher for
me (i love squarepusher, just not usually for the dancefloor) but on
the whole, the man is bringing a nice slice of glitch to the dnb
wurld.

plenary |plenr| |plnri| |plinri|
adjective
1 unqualified; absolute : crusaders were offered a plenary indulgence
by the pope.
2 (of a meeting) to be attended by all participants at a conference
or assembly, who otherwise meet in smaller groups : a plenary session
of the European Parliament.

Subject: [sfraves] chill-out meditation-friendly dvds and cds :)





hello sfravers  :)

(yo, Marc(0)! wassup! come home! ;)

system recordings, the dance music label, has a new line of
meditation-friendly, yoga-friendly cds and dvds called nature's balance
which are lovely.

the music is by john hazen, a sound designer for film, who has created
beautiful ambient soundscapes which are soothing, centering, healing.

waterfalls, snowfalls and forest rays ...  (and if i had an ipod i could
download them from itunes, lol).

http://www.systemrecordings.com/naturesbalance/

am putting out word because i realized these are a good gift idea for the
spiritually inclined or for peeps who just need to chill out and breathe
for a while.

am also a long-time big fan of system recordings.  :)

happy holidays!

peace,
mary :)

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

bODY eLECTRIC 
Saturday December 10th - 10 PM to 6AM 
@ Gingerbread Warehouse 

The celebrated tag-team duo East Coast Boogiemen, made up of partners Ken Christensen and Juan Zapata, have received critical praise across the globe for their innovative brand of funky house music. 
Zapata and Christensen use their exceptional musical talent to weave diverging elements into an amazing listening experience. 

Joining them for this all night affair at Gingerbread, Adnan & Laird will be doing a tagteam session, plus Carlos and Dhyan, Ramiro (Uniotng Souls) and LU ROB doing their magic. 

Be sure to check out Garth's 3 hour set upstairs. 

Room 1: 
EAST COAST BOOGIEMAN 
Adnan & Laird (Forward / Get YER Freak ON) 
Carlos (SFbyDEF) 
Dhyan (Free Radicals) 
Ramiro & Lu Rob (Uniting Souls / Planet East) 


Room 2: 
3hr set by GARTH (Grayhound) 
Alonso (SJ) 
Arturo (SJ) 

Gingerbread Warehouse - Connecticut @ Cezar Chaves - SF 
10PM to 6AM - 21+ - 10 bucks before midnight | 15 bucks after 


MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_31281953==.ALT--

> doesn't, it is of no use."

even had my first cup of coffee. my brain doesn't function until it's
had about seven or eight. I fucked up, shouldn't have said a word,
won't have the time to make it happen, or, more importantly, the
partners, so you'll all just have to wait until somebody with better
connections, better follow-through, and nothing else on their mind has
the same idea. sorry! just forget I ever brought it up. won't happen.
never gonna be. don't think about it. don't wonder about it. don't sit
around speculating as to what it might be. the whole thing is just a
smokescreen to distract you from those terrible rumors so you won't
think about me at all. the product is inevitable anyway, somebody else
will create it, it will be massively nifty, and you will all buy these
things, even though you'll never guess, when it happens, that this is
what I was talking about. in fact I didn't have any business idea at
all, I don't have an entrepreneurial bone in my body, I don't know a
thing about how to make money, and I have to go write lists of women
I'd like to bone, so, terribly sorry, but I've got a very full plate
right now. bye!

Subject: [sfraves] sort of BSP  Re: [sfraves] the haps for this coming weekend???any bsp's??

Folded is just the 1st Friday of the month, hoss!  COME FOR THE JANUARY
6TH EDITION PLZ KTHX.  AndyW, Fingermonsters, MY BIRTHDAY, whooty!  

Folded this month was Andrew, Jessi, and Stacey's birthday blowout. 
People got straight FLOGGED..  It was rather ill.

Anyway, I hate writing anything that smacks of BSP but I have to say,
my last b-day Folded was one of the more insane party nights I've had
in a while, and this year I turn.. uh... old, so I plan to do it up
crazier, even.

The thing is, to make merry, I need HELP.  Your help.  Your hip flask's
help.  Your arms to hold me up while swigging from that hip flask.

Anyhow, the FingerMonsters will be repping in full force for the first
time since OW Halloween.  I am really stoked on that.  How will we fit
our gear?  What will we dress like?  Will my moustache fall off halfway
through?

Who knows..  I guess you'll hafta just come.

Bloush

From sfraves-return-127103-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Dec 08 21:09:50 2005

Message-ID: <BAY101-F10190D49115E6BF0789547A3420@phx.gbl>
X-Originating-IP: [156.39.1.11]

Bcc: 
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 21:09:45 +0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 08 Dec 2005 21:09:46.0210 (UTC) FILETIME=[B7845420:01C5FC3B]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Late weekend review!!

I know im a bit late on this review I have been lagging for the most part 
but here goes.

Came out of my shell for a few parties this past weekend and damn it was 
well worth it!!

Let me start off by saying the Evil breaks boys know how to GET the F@#$ 
down!! I stepped into studio Z and the walls were banging  people all over 
the place just getting down to the wicked grooves of carbon community first 
time at an all breaks party and it was going off hard. They made the live PA 
fun to watch and interactive with the drumming.. Carbon tore the floor.. got 
a few drinks and whehhhhh the party was flowing Uberzone.... What could be 
said they ripped they are freakin awesome.. if you missed it  well you truly 
missed out rocking hard.. Ok time for the random spotting..

Got to see and talk to old peeps I don't normally see..

Terry (Viberation) oh yea and of course Terry had the visuals on lock... 
expect nothing but the best from terry and crew.

Ryan (Innocentchild) Yea our SFR poster boy is back in the country for a 
quick minute :-)
Philip Diaz.. See him post often but hardly ever see him..
Hello 2 day... That needs no intro ya'll know the man the legend!!
Lance.. some dood that I have known since JR high.. He actually posted my 
Jr. high yearbook picture to this list about 9 years back funny shit y0!!!
Dina dragn'fly, Terry "Buglady" Jared majere  And a few others that im 
missing off the top of my dome so please forgive me if I forgot to mention 
seeing you


Then it was over to Black majik which was a bit more mellow but still 
banging with people rocking the floor. Denise and Dina were rocking the 
crowd hung out there for a bit then back to Ubbbbberzone.. to finish off my 
night..


Before that was a trip to tripendecular.. Nice younger party with a thick 
vibe 3 rooms packed to the rim and funny thing that one of the DJ's pointed 
out was there was NO trance in any of the 3 rooms and the crowd was still 
working up a frenzy and up for the House and Dnb Good to see a younger crowd 
into multi genre's  Got to love UG warehouse locations.. nice big space with 
about 800 heads or so up in there.. Good time with decent sound systems and 
solid DJ's


Overall it was a good night for partys thanks to all the promoters that let 
me promote at your events I had a good time!

PS: If you have never been to an "evil breaks" I highly suggest you do if 
you have the means..



One,

Macadio



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Late weekend review!!

Yeah man.. me 2.. i meant 2 post something sooner.. but blah... that's
another story.. LoL... but b4 another weekend of Groove does start.. gotta
talk about the last 1... :)

Friday night was folded & I had a damn Groovy time!  House, dance floor,
Family, all of it, YUMMY!!!  Again.. Happy hardcore Birthday 2 The Lovie
Ones.. Stave, Andrew, & Jessi!

then there was that outdoor breaks thing, Hello 2day... got broken up like
1/2 an hour after i got there... oh well... but it was fun dippin' in the
underground that night... 4 a bit... la la la

Saturday... OK.. I was fuckin' Dirty & proud of it!!!  OK. I have 2 say..
the Smoove/ Bam tag set... ooh shit.. they dropped it hard, smooth, sweet,
& yummy!!! OUtta all the DJ sets that night... I did Love that the best..
no offense 2 Aaron Jamon, Moddie, & all the other DJs.. but they did it 4
me hardcore!!!  Y'all were Groovy 2.. but that was my DJ set 4 the night! 
Hello 2day.. & there were soooo Cute!!!  They were all decked out in the
Cango's, Addias, Wow... it was lke looking in a mirror if U looked @ them!
:)

OK. now Live acts... I do admit... Uber Zone was Dope!!  But I dunno.. I'm
more of a huge fan of Carbon Community.. honestly... I mean.. the way he
did his live shit... & the way the live drummer did his thang... just
fuckin' Sick... it's hard 2 explain... but I meran.. I did Love Uber
totally... & I did Groovy 2 their set longer than 20 minutes.. but lol.. I
did Love the 3 hours of Carbon I got 'cause i did hop over 2 Black Majik 4
bits here & there.. Oh.. yeah.. Dina, Terri, Denise.. YAY!!!

The vibe all around... Wicked.. there was alota good energy, Loved it!!! 
Moe kept showing me her boobs & i swear, she looks so YUM now!  I did meet
alota SFRers over the weekend actually... Hey.. if your reading this..
email me a private so we can Groove somemore on the floor :)  Yeah... then
my weekend settled down w/ a family dinner in the Sunset :)  Wow.. So
Dope!

Love U Evil Breaks!!!  Love U Folded!  Love U Aryck!  Love U SFR! :) <3

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)




Macadio G. wrote:

> I know im a bit late on this review I have been lagging for the most part
> but here goes.
>
> Came out of my shell for a few parties this past weekend and damn it was
> well worth it!!
>
> Let me start off by saying the Evil breaks boys know how to GET the F@#$
> down!! I stepped into studio Z and the walls were banging  people all over
> the place just getting down to the wicked grooves of carbon community
> first
> time at an all breaks party and it was going off hard. They made the live
> PA
> fun to watch and interactive with the drumming.. Carbon tore the floor..
> got
> a few drinks and whehhhhh the party was flowing Uberzone.... What could be
> said they ripped they are freakin awesome.. if you missed it  well you
> truly
> missed out rocking hard.. Ok time for the random spotting..
>
> Got to see and talk to old peeps I don't normally see..
>
> Terry (Viberation) oh yea and of course Terry had the visuals on lock...
> expect nothing but the best from terry and crew.
>
> Ryan (Innocentchild) Yea our SFR poster boy is back in the country for a
> quick minute :-)
> Philip Diaz.. See him post often but hardly ever see him..
> Hello 2 day... That needs no intro ya'll know the man the legend!!
> Lance.. some dood that I have known since JR high.. He actually posted my
> Jr. high yearbook picture to this list about 9 years back funny shit y0!!!
> Dina dragn'fly, Terry "Buglady" Jared majere  And a few others that im
> missing off the top of my dome so please forgive me if I forgot to mention
> seeing you
>
>
> Then it was over to Black majik which was a bit more mellow but still
> banging with people rocking the floor. Denise and Dina were rocking the
> crowd hung out there for a bit then back to Ubbbbberzone.. to finish off
> my
> night..
>
>
> Before that was a trip to tripendecular.. Nice younger party with a thick
> vibe 3 rooms packed to the rim and funny thing that one of the DJ's
> pointed
> out was there was NO trance in any of the 3 rooms and the crowd was still
> working up a frenzy and up for the House and Dnb Good to see a younger
> crowd
> into multi genre's  Got to love UG warehouse locations.. nice big space
> with
> about 800 heads or so up in there.. Good time with decent sound systems
> and
> solid DJ's
>
>
> Overall it was a good night for partys thanks to all the promoters that
> let
> me promote at your events I had a good time!
>
> PS: If you have never been to an "evil breaks" I highly suggest you do if
> you have the means..
>
>
>
> One,
>
> Macadio

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: [KONTROL] with Daniel Bell aka DBX! - Sat.Dec.17th

------=_Part_365_14054202.1134150561756
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Saturday, December 17th

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 3rd Saturday at Rx Gallery


Featuring from Berlin, Germany:

DANIEL BELL aka DBX
* Extended 3 hour set! *

Plus 8 - Accelerate - 7th City - Peacefrog
Tresor - Novamute - Transmat - Perlon
Poker Flat -  M_nus - Palette - Telegraph

>From his Detroit beginnings on Plus 8 Records with partners Richie Hawtin
and John Acquaviva, to his current status as world-renowned producer and DJ=
,
Daniel Bell is one of the most important and respected names in the history
of dance music.  His stripped-down funky style, epitomized in his
underground hit "Losing Control", influenced a generation of producers and
helped launch a new "minimal" aesthetic in dance music. Having lived in
Berlin since 2000 and spent the last 2 years touring around the world, we
are honored to present this true pioneer in his first SF appearance in over
5 years.

with resident DJs:
SAMMY D  ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
CRAIG KUNA  ( concept sf . esdjco )
ALLAND BYALLO ( nightlight . epsionlab . mo's ferry )

Rx Gallery art exhibition by Michael Thrush
http://www.rxgallery.com  (great art this month!)

Digital video art by Econ.net
Drink specials by JINRO soju

________________________________________________

Rx Gallery / 132 Eddy @ Mason, SF / 415.474.7973
9pm-2am / 21+ / $10 until 11pm - $15 after

Check our website for full bios, pics and free audio!
http://www.kontrolsf.com

View the flyer here:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K07flyer.jpg

________________________________________________

Daniel Bell's Biography:  (courtesy of Telegraph Records)

Born in Sacramento, California, Daniel Bell grew up outside of Toronto ,
Canada, and then moved to Detroit where he collaborated with Richie Hawtin
as Cybersonik for three years on +8 Records. In 1991, he started his own
label, Accelerate, on which he released his influential releases as DBX.
Based on nearby Chicago "track" records, he reduced that sound further into
funky, streamlined grooves. The formula proved to be successful and helped
launch a new aesthetic in techno and house music known as "minimal".

With the overwhelming success of his "Losing Control" single in 1994, Danie=
l
set up 7th City Distribution in order to assist smaller Midwest labels to
get distribution in overseas markets. He also created three new labels - 7t=
h
City, Elevate and Harmonie Park . In 2000, he relocated to Berlin, Germany =
,
and released his first mix CD, "The Button-Down Mind of Daniel Bell", on
Tresor Records, followed in 2003 by "The Button-Down Mind Strikes Back!"
He since has produced a series of remixes for a diverse range of artists,
includng John Tejada, Pantytec, Akufen and Martin Landsky. He has spent the
last 2 years traveling and DJing around the world, and is currently touring
the U.S. and preparing to hunker down in the studio in the coming year.

Daniel Bell's web site
http://www.daniel-bell.com

Daniel Bell's discography
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Daniel Bell

Daniel's discography as DBX
http://www.discogs.com/artist/DBX

A recent interview with Dan Bell from InTheMix.com
http://www.inthemix.com.au/features/23336/

A longer Daniel Bell bio from Outlar.com
http://www.outlar.com/artist.php?artist=3D576&name=3DDanielBell

DBX - Losing Control  (audio sample)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF127285-01-01-03.mp3

DBX - Phreak  (audio sample)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF127285-01-01-02.mp3

This is gonna be another hot one!!!
Early arrival is strongly suggested to assure entry.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] good rekkid stores for breaks in SF?

Reverb is good. If you're nice to Icon, she'll hella hook you up.
Addictech is technically online, but it's based in SF, and totally
busts ass for Teh Skene. Plus you can get a breakbeat CD which
features a jungle track by ME! on that site. So of course that site
must be Teh Rawk.

http://www.addictech.com/store/product_info.php?products_id=3D935

My track is DJ Soundwave "Fuzzy Ballistics," the "Maja Shook" remix
right after it is better though. I think that's Odeed and Wish? Or
something?

Yes, what were we talking about. Oh, right, ME! Oh wait, no. Record
stores. Right.

BPM is good. They make you do some crate-digging, but they're good.
Skills in Berkeley, well, they've really only got like this tiny tiny
pile of records in the very very corner for breaks. Can't really
recommend them so much. Solid Grooves in San Jo actually had a pretty
great selection last time I was in there, like a thousand times
improved after the move from Santa Clara or wherever, but they were in
transition so who knows whether that's still the case or not. Amobea,
not so good. Primal, Primal hides from me every time I look for it.
I'm serious. it like hides and wears dark sunglasses so I won't
recognize it. wtf.

hmm. yeah.

Marco, whatever on the dissing local stores, but credit where credit
is due, Marco can find records like a fucking bloodhound. Crazy.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] good rekkid stores for breaks in SF?

is that what happened? balls. a lot of stores are doing that now.

I actually think that's the wave of the future. look at Dogs On Acid.
started as a forum, added on a store and a label. people don't hang
out in record stores as much as they used to, and the real purpose of
a record store is to serve as a focal point for a musical community.
if the musical community finds its focal point on the Internet, that's
where the store should be. just logic.

Yes, what were we talking about. Oh, right, ME! Oh wait, no. Record
stores. Right.

BPM is good. They make you do some crate-digging, but they're good.
Skills in Berkeley, well, they've really only got like this tiny tiny
pile of records in the very very corner for breaks. Can't really
recommend them so much. Solid Grooves in San Jo actually had a pretty
great selection last time I was in there, like a thousand times
improved after the move from Santa Clara or wherever, but they were in
transition so who knows whether that's still the case or not. Amobea,
not so good. Primal, Primal hides from me every time I look for it.
I'm serious. it like hides and wears dark sunglasses so I won't
recognize it. wtf.

hmm. yeah.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] good rekkid stores for breaks in SF?

To be honest - I have been to so few record stores that have been able to 
keep current on anything other than house or trance, that I typically never 
shop in stores for my breakbeats anyway. It's always some store in bumfuck 
Egypt that has good records, and I'm not travelling an hour to dig through 
crates for shit I can buy from the relative comfort of my cubicle or on my 
PC at home. Plus, moving towards dj downloads of MP3's - who'd want to go to 
a store for that?

If anyone wants me to do my semi regular posting of online stores that I buy 
from (which is quite a few), say the word...
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Giles Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>

Sent: Friday, December 09, 2005 11:40 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] good rekkid stores for breaks in SF?


is that what happened? balls. a lot of stores are doing that now.

I actually think that's the wave of the future. look at Dogs On Acid.
started as a forum, added on a store and a label. people don't hang
out in record stores as much as they used to, and the real purpose of
a record store is to serve as a focal point for a musical community.
if the musical community finds its focal point on the Internet, that's
where the store should be. just logic.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] good rekkid stores for breaks in SF?

here's my problem - I *love* the idea of buying rekkids and mp3s
online ( and have been doing so exclusively for at least a year)  but
i often find a) i dont get a really good sense for a record from the
tinny low-bitrate clips online stores use and b)  there's just
something about holding a rekkid in your hand.  i *still* have a hard
time associating what a song sounds like to its text name in Final
Scratch.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] good rekkid stores for breaks in SF?

I hear ya - but I make it a point to search several diff. sites for the same 
samples because I find that the samples differ. Sometimes in tempo, 
sometimes in length, and sometimes (and most importantly) in quality. Then I 
weigh out whether or not the tracks kept it's intrigue - and go from there.

I rarely wind up disappointed that way.

Mac Vaughn (AKA DJ Uphonic) Bruce from the "F-8" famed days agreed to do a 
exclusive old school DJ set for our party.. You don't want to miss him for 
those that remember his awesome sets from back in the day.

Micron (Viberation/FnF) Yes old school micron has agreed to drop a phat 
techno/acid techno set.. For those that remember him from way back when will 
not be disapointed in his set.

Denise (DJ Denise.com) No intro needed here you all know and love denise she 
is just rocking.. She will be playing an exclusive old school hard trance 
set.

Disconnect (DEFSF) Disconnect has been droping unique techno all over the 
bay area and is one of the main driving force's of the DEF parties this guy 
can rock the party or play his timeslot and "Take you on that ride"

Macadio (First Light) One of the founding members of First light will be 
droping some unique sounds on ya.. maybe some prog house, maybe some trance, 
possible techno you will just have to come to see.



ROOM 2
Evil Breaks Sylie

Aaron Jae (Aaron jae.com) One of the founding members of Evil Breaks this 
guy is going to rock the house fo sho!

Alxndr (Downlow)

DJ Bam (Evil Breaks) This man needs no intro he has been ripping up sweaty 
warehouses and clubs around the area for a while know.

Chris Jackson (Resource records,refined music) Chris has aggread to drop an 
old school early 90's Acid Breaks set. This dood has alot of records you 
will want to peep his set for sho..

Greg J (www.kidbippy.com,Funky Cactus) Some of ya'll may remember kid bippy 
from back in the planet rock days at homebase.. He use to rock in back then 
and is still rocking the funky breaks till this day.

M.O.D Vs. Thomas Kent (Evil Breaks Modified productions) MOD is the prog 
breaks masta. and thomas kent of modified Need I say more?? You don't want 
to miss these two guys doing what they do best... Destroying the dance floor 
with there awesome breaks.

Shazbot (Moksha Tribe, DEFSF) since the early Moksha days Shazbot has been 
leaving people amazed with his wicked style of laying down the funky tracks.


****We are also trying to secure a Well known international DJ for the evil 
breaks room and you will not want to miss this headliner if they can be 
secured check the VM to see if the person has been secured or not****

for updates. If not it will be $12 on the door

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Mary Morris" <morrism@washpost.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, December 09, 2005 2:50 PM
Subject: [sfraves] dj jen lasher: no more tears


>
>
>
>
> fyi ...
>
> dj jen lasher spins house, breaks, industrial, and has a new cd out with 
> dj
> baby anne on system recordings which hit #32 on the billboard
> dance/electronica chart for 11/6.  :)
>
> you can hear a sample of her new single "no more tears"
> (industrial/electro) here
>
>
> http://www.jenlasher.com/audio/singles/No_More_Tears/Jen_Lasher_-_No_More_Tears.mp3
>
>
> full disclosure:  i have known jen lasher from the time she was about 17
> and am thrilled to have seen her grow from a popular local dj into a
> popular national dj.  she is smart, enthusiastic, energetic, kind and
> thoughtful - when i brought my 15-year old and her friends to an all-ages
> event jen played last march, she gave them each a copy of her latest mix.
> they were talking about her and her mix-cd for weeks after.  they probably
> related to her set most of all the djs they heard that day because of her
> stage presence and energy. :)
>
>
> respectfully,
>
>
> mary :)
>
> DJ JEN LASHER:  NO MORE TEARS
>
> Lost in concentration, Jen Lasher adjusts a knob, shifts the fader and
> smiles at what she hears. She sings with the vocals, her magenta and black
> mane shimmering under the flashing lights. Her slender body, in a white
> long-sleeved Shakespearean blouse and black gathered floor-length skirt
> swishing over 4-inch platform shoes, sways to the music, her hands
> gesturing poetically over her head. Its a Thursday night in November at
> Alchemy at Nation, DCs infamous longest running weekly industrial party
> where Jen has a bi-weekly residency, and the dancers mostly dressed in
> black who fill the dance floor gyrate with abandon.
>
> Just 23, DJ/producer Jen Lasher of Annapolis, Maryland, is living out her
> DJ dreams. In October she celebrated the release of her third single, No
> More Tears, which she wrote and sings on, and which is featured on her
> national debut double mix-CD set Assault & Battery co-released with 
> funky
> breaks Bass Queen DJ Baby Anne on System Recordings. Baby Anne, whos
> like a big sister to Jen, rocks her signature deep bass groove on her CD,
> and Jens mix is an artfully paced dark edgy industrial/electro set that
> glides with buoyant energy from track to track. To Jen and Baby Annes
> delight, Assault & Battery hit #32 on Billboards Dance/Electronica 
> chart
> for the week ending November 6.
>
> Jen, who played piano as a child, and her younger brother who plays 
> guitar,
> are the only musicians in their family. I dont know where we get it
> from, Jen, whose dad is a dentist and whose mother is an accountant,
> laughs. I first saw turntables when I was 13, at a friends house. I
> practiced for hours on his and had so much fun that I got my own Technic
> 1200s from Chuck Levins in Wheaton for my 14th birthday. My parents are
> so supportive. My mom used to drive me all the way from Port Tobacco,
> Maryland to MusicNow in DC just to get records.
>
> I didnt know that different things didnt mix, Jen laughs. I had
> hip-hop, and jump-up by Aphrodite, and I got old Fever mix-tapes by
> Feelgood, Scott Henry and Dieselboy and tried to find all the records on
> them. When she went to high school (McDonough HS) all the kids in her
> neighborhood were seniors with cars so she went with them to an all-ages
> party hosted by Feelgood and Scott Henry called Sunday Mass at the Paradox
> in Baltimore and sometimes snuck into their weekly, Fever. Scott Henry 
> and
> Feelgood were the whole reason I went. I used to trainspot really bad,
> asking people around the booth what that song was. I loved it.
>
> Before I started going out I liked Marilyn Manson, Nine Inch Nails, Lords
> of Acid and older industrial stuff that was very techno/electronic
> influenced. Hearing that stuff at Sunday Mass on the loud sound system and
> in the HFStival techno tent, I realized I wanted to play that style. Its
> very exciting.
>
> The first time I played out was in Ocean City at the Common Grounds 
> coffee
> shop at an all-ages party with a smart bar. I think I was 15. I was 
> playing
> out before I knew what I was doing, she laughs. It took me two years to
> figure out beat-matching because I didnt have anybody showing me what I
> was supposed to do. Later DJ Sinestro (Chris Baggett) explained counting 
> in
> electronic music. Its pretty much the same as counting with classical
> music. He helped me learn all that stuff.
>
> For her 17th birthday, Jen, a member of the breakdance collective DC
> Freestylers, asked her mom if she could have a party and invited the email
> list. Over 300 people showed up at my parents house. My mom made
> sandwiches and hamburgers. CyberQuest did the dcor. Liquid Lounge did the
> lighting. I didnt organize it but it turned out great. We had 30 acres of
> land in the middle of nowhere then so it was a good spot. Jen got a turn
> at the decks, of course. Her goal then was to dance in music videos, which
> might explain the physicality of her DJing now.
>
> Jen was 18 when she met legendary breaks DJ and producer Icey, now a 
> friend
> and mentor, at Cubik (then Buzz) at Nation. Icey played an unreleased
> Plump DJs song, The Scram, that Id heard about and was looking for.
> After his set I ran up to him and asked where hed got it. He was shocked
> that I knew what it was and we started talking about music on the 
> Internet.
> Hes encouraged and supported me, put in a good word for me with 
> promoters,
> gave people my mixes, told me whom to send my mixes to. He is a huge
> influence and is very helpful to a lot of people. He wants to see his
> friends do well and he cares a lot about the music scene.
>
> About being more flamboyant than your average DJ, Jen laughs, I 
> definitely
> go crazy behind the turntables. I cant help it. I used to jump up and 
> down
> and skip my records or get so much into dancing that the record would end
> on me. Its terrible when that happens! As for her bold sense of style
> (Jen and Baby Anne pose super-hero stylee on their new album) she grins, 
> I
> used to dye my hair purple when I was 12. Id buy stuff at the mall and
> sneak it home. My parents would want to kill me. Its nice that they do
> punk colors at salons now so it looks professional. I decided on pink 
> three
> years ago. If youre on stage, your makeup and clothes are part of the 
> art.
> You can wear crazy stuff you could never wear walking down the street to
> the bank. I take full advantage. She designs and sews some of her outfits
> and loves to shop for wild artsy fashions in San Francisco and Los 
> Angeles.
>
> Jen made the leap from trainspotter to DJ at Cubik and Five in DC, and
> Sonar in Baltimore, and locally can also boast playing Starscape and the
> HFStival. This year she played the San Francisco Love Parade, has spun
> across North America solo and is currently touring with Baby Anne to
> promote Assault & Battery.
>
> Alchemy promoter, DJ and nightlife legend Anthony Tribby aka 2501 explains
> how Jen Lashers residency came about: Jen spun breaks for ALIAS (John
> Tab's drum 'n' bass and breaks party upstairs at Nation on the same nights
> as Alchemy) a few times when they were still on the deck. Several of the
> Alchemy staff met her and were really impressed with her enthusiasm for
> music and her great positive attitude. Jen was working toward mixing in
> electro stuff into her sets and we struck up a conversation about her 
> doing
> a guest spot on one of the Alchemy floors to see how the crowd went for 
> it.
> She was very excited because she had a bunch of EBM, 80s and even gothy
> stuff she never got to play at her usual gigs, so it was an opportunity 
> for
> her to play around with a very different style of sets and mixing.
>
> It turned out Jens sets were warmly received by the Alchemy crowd. A few
> months later when we were looking to create a group of DJs to fill every
> other week resident spots, I asked her if she wanted to give it a go and
> she enthusiastically said yes. It has been just over a year and Jen
> continues to bring that same enthusiasm to her sets every time she spins
> for us.
>
> Jen is the hardest-working DJ I have ever met. She has spent years
> developing her skills, and building a name and reputation by being willing
> to spin at all kinds of events all over the country, taking on booking,
> travel routing, burning thousands of mix-CDs and all kinds of other 
> things
> herself, all the while managing to maintain an almost obsessive enthusiasm
> for the music she spins. At just about every event she plays she also 
> helps
> to promote. The reason she has been so successful is that she has never
> once believed that anyone else owed her anything, which I think is a
> problem too many aspiring DJs and musicians have these days.
>
> Being female in a mostly male industry, I think she is also aware that
> jealous people may want to assume that she has obtained her success based
> on something other than hard work and talent, but that only makes her work
> harder to earn everything she gets. Jen is simply one of the greatest
> people I know.
>
> As a genre-crossing DJ and fan of bands, Jen would love to see the dance
> and band scenes mix it up more. I hear the exact same music at the 9:30
> Club, Sonar, Black Cat and Nation as I hear at Alchemy. People who go to
> one club might not be caught dead at another, but its the same style of
> music. I want to bring different crowds together so people can see its 
> not
> that different, just the clothes and style of dancing. At a rave-style
> event in Seattle, Jen says, A club owner said, theres a lot of 
> industrial
> kids out, they never come here. Theres a cross-over in my style that
> brings out people in the indie-rock scene, too.
>
> Jens first foray into producing was Different Day co-written with Icey.
> I wrote the lyrics and melody, sang it, put in on a CD and sent it to 
> him.
> He worked on it and sent it back. We collaborated from a distance. They
> worked in the studio together on Rain, her second release, and her new
> single No More Tears, an intense, dissonant, angry, pulsating industrial
> diatribe.
>
> At Alchemy Jens fans sing along to No More Tears. Jen has been amazed 
> at
> the dedication of some of her fans. I have fans who travel from city to
> city to hear me play. When Baby Anne and I played the Love Parade, two 
> fans
> from Portland came down to San Francisco, then up to Seattle, and theyre
> coming to Orlando. I have a fan in Boston coming to Orlando, too. Some 
> fans
> Ill see in North Carolina, then Florida and Tennessee.
>
> Jen is currently expanding her home studio as she focuses on writing more
> music. She has two new songs finished and is working toward putting out an
> artist album. Even in the busiest times I write music on the plane. I
> write my best music when Im stressed and depressed, she laughs.
> Mainstream media controls a lot of what people like. I think the bigger
> the underground scene the better because every musician and artist 
> deserves
> the chance to express themselves. I feel privileged to be a part of it on
> an independent label and putting out vinyl.
>
> Jen Lasher loves her life. Ive always been a night person. As soon as 
> the
> sun goes down, I wake up. The nightlife is important. Its where a lot of
> people meet and have fun, and bringing joy to people makes me 
> happy. --MIM
>
> mary ishimoto morris
> music monthly
> december 2005
>
> www.musicmonthly.com 

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Dear SFRaves Community

I am writing to inquire if you or anyone you know is a Zope Guru who might 
be interested in becoming involved with the next generation of the SFRaves 
Calendar Project.

The SFRaves Calendar is located @ 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2

More information about Zope is located here: http://www.zope.org

All interested parties should have a solid understanding of and 
development experience with authoring and building applications using the 
Zope language.

Please send responses to karina@hyperreal.org

Alternative solutions are also being considered for the next generation of 
this codebase.  This includes other languages specific to the development 
of applications in a web environment.

Thanks and regards

Karina Powers

-- 
**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

-----------------------------------------------------------------
                                The SFRaves Calendar
             Upcoming Parties and Events in the San Francisco Bay Area
                   http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/
-----------------------------------------------------------------


Friday, December 09, 2005 * Winter Wonderland *

DJ's: DJ Turbine, Kelly Kane, Ismael Rodriguez, Shawn Yapa. 9:30pm till 2am, 
Location Club Prive, 651 Howard St. $10. Genres: Progress Trance, Electro-Tech 
House. rave link flyer

Saturday, December 10, 2005 * Orbit presented by Kings Entertainment and 
Tunnel-Vizions *

Prepare yourself for another fun night as we take you on a journey through the 
stars!! - Expect nothing but the best in house and trance from the bay area and 
abroad! Your guides for the evening are as follows: Trance - Gamma, Kid Wicked, 
Wavelength, Epsilon, Apot, Leon Cook and Psyan. House - Filter Frequency, 
Carlos Alfonzo, Nick Nyquil, Deft, Andy P, Delro and Jo-Beatz. Sound by Kings 
Entertainment and Hardscience, 2 rooms of lighting by Stimulights, Decorations 
by Kings ent. and TunnelVizions, Vending By Omni Era, Poi Performance by the 
lovely Spam.We'll be going strong from 8:30 PM until 4 AM in the morning. 
Opening Dj'z get 1.5 hours... $15 door. Infoline 925.806.8810  rave link flyer

Thursday, December 15, 2005 * Inbox *

Featuring House, Trance and Breaks. With Rotating Resident Djs: Aaron Jae, 
Amber, Denise, Aleks, Achillies, Apot, Dave Conlan and Hoovie. Free Chips and 
salsa and happy hour drinks. Open decks from 6-7 every week, please email. 
Located @ Luna Lounge 8th St. and 1192 Folsom St. SF, CA 94103.

Thursday, December 15, 2005 * Nocturnal Beats (Sacramento) *

Quality Electronic music every Thursday. D&B room... Soul Survivor, Damien, 
Dick Gail; Trance Room: Koroma, Da Gru, Bob-O; 3rd Room Opened - Christina's 
Birthday Party: Kenny Young, Robbie G, Lurid, Entrigue w. MC Mic, Digital E; 
18+ to enter, 21 + to drink, Music Starts at 9pm; Located at the stoney inn 
1320 del paso blvd, Sacramento, CA 95628, $6 cover doors open at 9, Drink 
specials all night. Info Line 415-267-6924

Saturday, December 17, 2005 * Lost In Space presented by Collective Conscious 
and Hardfloor Movement (Sacramento) *

Featurin Cantos (Urban Breaks, selekta), Dutch (Thump Radio), DJ Rigatony 
(Sagitarium Pra), DJ Daddy (Windowpaneinfinity), DJ Ohm (Saturated mind), 
Cybertribe (Cybertribe) , Justin Roth (Hardfloor movement, floor funk), Soul 
Tripper (Live PA), Joey Antix, AtoMikDoG (Live PA), Zapper (Live PA), Officer 
Bunch, Leroy Biggs, Bob O, Mek-Gamma-Dirt, Friction, Phokus (Live PA), Malachi, 
Mr. Rogers. New Venue! There will be free fruit and candy. No markers, weapons, 
or alcohol. 9pm  whenever. $10 Before 10:30pm, $14 After. All Responsible Ages 
Welcomed. In or Around Sacramento. Infoline 916.346.7148

Thursday, December 22, 2005 * Stilldream presented by Techno Truth (Sacramento) 
*

Come Join us on this joyous night as we get ready to start the holiday season 
on the right foot. What better way then to party it up with our friends and 
family while doing something good for the community. HOUSE / BREAKS: David 
Aaron, Cantos, St. Nick Nyquil, Channelz DJ's, Dj Rizin, Tupperware Blue; 
TECHNO / PSY: G.A.M.M.A., Mek, Jyant, Dirt, Korpus Kallosum, Mr. Rogers & 
Officer Bunch, Covert; JUNGLE: Hysterisis Loop, Atom One, Digital E, Mercedes, 
Deft_One, Bionix; 7pm - 2am. 18+ to party, 21+ to drink. Full bar with drink 
specials ALL night long! Serving dinner until 10pm. Admission to this special 
event: $10 or $5 with 2 cans of food Donations will go to the sacramento food 
bank. Location: The Stonney Inn, 1320 Del Paso Blvd, Sacramento, Ca 95628 rave 
link flyer

Wednesday, December 28, 2005 * Electro Revolution presented by The Stony Inn 
(Sacramento) *

Area #1 (Progressive House & Breaks), Dj Dan (Los Angeles), Dj Doza, Dj Rockit, 
Undecided, Brandon Reese, More TBA. Area #2: Jungle / Drum N Bass: Dieselboy 
(Philadelphia), Mc J Messinian (Philadelphia), Digital E, Atom One, More Tba; 
Area #3 (Uk Hard House / Techno / Hard Trance): Dj Zenu (Romania), Dj Rustique, 
Kid Wicked, more TBA. 3 ROOMS OF MUSIC. 8pm-2am. 18+ Located at: The Stoney Inn 
1320 Del Paso Blvd Sacramento, Ca 95628. $25 @ door.

Thursday, December 29, 20055 * Submerged Thursdays presented by Elev8 
Collective *

Get ready for the new year with djs.... Lexxus (Turntablaze ), Femme Fatale 
(Sleeveless Sf), Miss Haze (Elev8 Collective/Turntablaze Sf/Crackhaus NY), more 
TBA. Located at The El Rincon, 2700 16TH STREET (corner of 16th and harrison) 
downtown San Francisco CA 18 AND UP/ FULL BAR FOR 21 AND UP FREE before 11/ 2$ 
after

Thursday, December 29, 2005 *Nocturnal Beats (Sacramento) *

Quality Electronic music every Thursday; D&B room... Undecided, El Gaupo, Dick 
Gail; Main Room: Thomas Kent, Bill the survey guy, Bob-O; 18+ to enter, 21 + to 
drink, Music Starts at 9pm; Located at the stoney inn 1320 del paso blvd, 
Sacramento, CA 95628. $6 cover doors open at 9, Drink specials all night, Info 
Line 415-267-6924


Friday, December 30th, 2005 - Adam Freeland, Lee Coombs, Bassbin Twins, Dylan 
Rhymes and more in the course of 2 nights! Gotta love this town.

Friday, December 30th 'The Closing Party of 2005'

Opel, Spundae, Mighty & Marine Parade present a special night w/

~Adam Freeland (!) ~performing w/ MC Juice Aleem + Laird (Get Yer Freak On) 
Shissla vs. Alibi (House of Lotus) Syd Gris (Opel / Opulent Temple) Kramer 
(Deep End / djkramer.com / United Tribal) Aaron Pope (Deep End / Mixed 
Elements) Dirtyhertz (Looq / Pangea) Vinklemann (Opulent Temple) + more tba! 
10pm-4am @ Mighty: 119 Utah @ 15th Save your duckets, pre-sales will start at 
only $10!

Saturday, December 31st, 2005 Saturday, December 31st: New Years Eve 2006

Opel presents Infuse NYE: The Rekindling of Hope

After 4 years of being involved in NYE parties, we've managed to inoculate 
ourselves from the lemon/amateur factor by keeping the party focused on being a 
vibe centric community gathering, with a reasonable cover and our neo-hippy 
values in full effect. This NYE, will look forward to creating a wonderful, 
friendly, intimate party environment where we can all go big together. A 
sanctuary of music, vibe, and people on NYE. w/ special guests: Lee Coombs 
(Thrust / Perfecto / Fingerlickin', UK) Dylan Rhymes (Kingsize / Lot 49, UK) 
Bassbin Twins (Belgian Breaks/ Skint/ Southern Fried Records, SF) + Jondi & 
Spesh (Qool / Looq) Syd Gris (Opel / Opulent Temple) Ethan Miller v. ViaJay 
(Friends n' Family) Hoj (Opel / djhoj.com) Melyss (Opel / Sister SF) Fred Funk 
(Brass Tax) Aaron Jae v. Bam (Evil Breaks / sfbreaks.org) Shanti (Triple Power 
/ Rhythm Society). + more tba All the NYE goodies and some surprises...9pm- 
till you stop dancing DNA Lounge 375 11th St. @ Harrison St. Pre-sales start at 
only $25 friends, on sale now @ www.opelproductions.com. Let's take a 
conscious, purposeful step together into the New Year, and have an absolutely 
rockin time doing it. That sounds like a proper end to a proper beginning....

Saturday, December 31, 2005 * Fitter Happier presented by Modified*

Second Annual Modified New Years Eve 2006! [Breaks + Drum and Bass + Electro + 
House + Hardcore + Progressive + Techno + Trance] Your talent for the evening: 
Yagi (OTC/HCFTP), Thomas Kent (Ill Behavior/Modified), Shard (OTC), Molly Mush 
(OTC/HCFTP), Macadio (First Light/DEFSF), Kris Kent (Ill Behavior), Kid Wicked 
(Tunnel-Vizions), John Econ (Breaks - Chico, Ca), Joey Antix (Bionic Bubbles), 
ill-d theDJ (Thoughtcrime Inc.), Hyjinx (Modified), Go-Zania (HCFTP/Hard 
Science), G.A.M.M.A. (Stilldream/Techno Truth), Eric Foard (Stretch 
Entertainment), Durty (Nocturnalism), Dulce Vita 
(Wink@butter/DefinitionofhouseSF), DJ Owl (Electro - SF, Ca), DJOrionZ 
(brproductions/N.L>P.), DJ 2QT (HCFTP/Nu Vision), Cubehead (Subscience/OTC) 
with MC Enhale (Fab 5 Battle Crew), Cmos vs Juave (Antiserum), Christhejunglist 
(Primitive-Science/KCRH 89.9 FM), Chel-C Faith (DEFSF) - Live PA!, Carlos 
Alfonzo (brproductions/YuccaTribe/Wild 94.9 HouseNation/Zapatista's), Element 
(Modified) <> Remodified venue <> 4 areas of music - including an outdoor 
heated patio area and loft chill room <> Laser light show by Stimulights <> 
Nationally renowned light sculptures by Analogia <> Patrolled parking <>  All 
ages <> 10pm till 6am+ <> $15 <> Infoline: 415-820-1518

Saturday, December 31, 2005 * All Together presented by Plays Kool *

Join us for ALL TOGETHER as we celebrate the memories of 2005 and party the 
night away. Welcome in the new year with a fun filled night of music, dancing, 
friends, art, and entertainment. Special prizes for dancers in costume! Dress 
up and shine like a star! Bring a date for a special new years countdown and 
midnight kiss! Trance Sand Box: Dyloot (Adjusted, Noys, Deep Voices, Skills), 
Mystre (Reverb), Majere (Elektrosorcery), Taj (1015), Brett James vs. Sal DJ 
vs. Plate Tektonics (Cal Trance), Kid Wicked (Tunnel Visionz), and Owl (Seekr). 
Jungle and Breaks Gym: Channel Surfer (F-8, Firetribe), The Doctor (Bayraves), 
DOS, Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks), Nick Nyquil (Oneiromancy), Reclipse (Drum 
Syndicate), and BAM (Evil Breaks). Happy Play Ground: D-Unit vs. Riff Raff 
(Zapatistas/Hard Heads), Secondbase, Happy Freaks (Hi-C, vs. Kid Orange, vs. 
Crackerjack), Sideshow (HCFTP), Rye Bread (HCFTP), DJ Spell (Hard Heads), and 
Precision (Hard Heads). $20 at the door, 9pm-5am, All ages, San Francisco. Info 
line: 415.267.6921

SFRaves Calendar Stats:

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/

2005-12-02 : SFRaves Calendar Stats:

* User Registration has skyrocketed to 372 groups and 2797 people as of
December 2005!

-------------------------------------------------
Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.
To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

If you have events to add to the SFRaves calendar, please publish them by
Friday @ Noon to be included in the SFR Calendar Weekly Edition Mailing.

SFRaves is a not for profit entity serving the Bay Area & all forms of
electronic music for 13 years.

to a good start! It is, afterall, the season to be jolly!

party.     Impossible, you say?  Try this:  shake it to the the
dirty grooves of Denver's LITTLE MIKE and TY TEK, plus their
cohorts, the TRIBALSOULS crew and a couple of gritty local djs:
JEFFREY ALLEN and WILL SPENCER 'til the break of dawn.     Then,
while you're gettin' your groove on, take comfort in the fact
that part of the proceeds for this here party will go to NEXTAID
a dance-centric organization dedicated to aiding African orphans
affected by the AIDS epidemic.     What better way to get on
Santa's NICE list, eh?     So here are the details:

WHAT: A Holiday Mistletoe Jam
WHERE: Club Six (6th between Market and Mission)
WHEN: Saturday, December 10, 10pm 'til late

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Just a goddamned piece of paper... 

GOP leaders told Bush that his hardcore push to renew the more onerous 
provisions of the act could further alienate conservatives still mad at 
the President from his botched attempt to nominate White House Counsel 
Harriet Miers to the Supreme Court.

"I don't give a goddamn,"; Bush retorted. "I'm the President and the 
Commander-in-Chief. Do it my way."

"Mr. President," one aide in the meeting said. "There is a valid case 
that the provisions in this law undermine the Constitution."

"Stop throwing the Constitution in my face," Bush screamed back. "It's 
just a goddamned piece of paper!

Subject: RE: [sfraves] SFRaves Calendar Dev

To clarify - Zope is actually an framework. We are also seeking an 
individual who likes to code in ZPT, Python, PHP, MYSQL, Plone and other 
languages that might be used to enhance the SFR Calendar Application.

Please note if you are seeing issues with the current calendar incarnation 
(bugs, errors, etc) please note that I am aware of them and am currently 
in the process of addressing / fixing these issues.


Thanks

Karina
  --

>> application framework.

Subject: [sfraves] anyone else see tosca at mezzanine?

is that what counts for a 'live' show these days?  where was the  
grand piano that was promised?  at no point were both members of  
tosca on the stage at the same time.  less than an hour after they  
started, dorfmeister was playing a gorillaz track, which was actually  
a pretty good remix and had me moving for sure, but also wondering,  
is this his 'three hour dj set' which was supposed to follow the  
'live' show?  45 minutes into the show?  it went downhill from  
there.  i had more fun listening to the new album on the ipod in the  
car on my way back to berkeley.  pretty lame.  not worth my $26.50,  
or the time spent away from studying for finals for that matter.   
anyway, that's my .02.  anybody else have a review?

Bam:
>>um, that's because there was a video circulating the internet of Jen
>>Lasher and a certain high profile drum and bass DJ having sex.

Marco:
>Yes. And let's leave it at that...

dude, whatever. publicity stunt. image consultant. Paris Hilton.
monkey see, monkey do.

#32 on the Billboard chart.

and listen to the track! a guy I grew up with sings opera for a living
worldwide. ok? the man can give you goosebumps with his vocal chords.
and he was doing it when we were 13. fast forward to the modern day,
and Giles foolishly clicks a link and listens to that mp3. suddenly
his ears are bleeding! polka beats with a vocal from a dead cat
possessed by the ghost of Tori Amos! wtf?

I don't know what the fuck is up with that shit, but if you're posting
that, somebody's going to have to say *something*.

and as for that bullshit article, the promoter who's like "her success
is due entirely to talent and hard work" -- at least some of her
present fame comes from fucking Dara and "accidentally" recording it
on video. the only logical implication is that making pornography, for
a woman DJ, is just another form of talent and hard work. THAT
IMPLICATION IS FALSE.

god! so much bullshit I need boots!

> at least some of her
> present fame comes from fucking Dara and "accidentally" recording it
> on video.


I have to point out something: They both had sex. He was holding the camera=
,
there were two people involved. If you try to moralize one, you must do it
to the other.

Anyone who wants to get all high and mighty about this tape: I bet you've
had sex too, so shut up. Recording sex acts doesn't suddenly demoralize and
invalidate them.


> the only logical implication is that making pornography, for
> a woman DJ, is just another form of talent and hard work. THAT
> IMPLICATION IS FALSE.


Making pornography does take talent and hard work, at least to make good
porn. (A film about fucking is still a film.) That's why there is an over
abundance of shitty "gonzo" style porn that spends a maximum of two days in
post-production. (For laughs, here is a big list of all the things wrong
with it: http://newyork.craigslist.org/about/best/bos/50001396.html )

And that "logical implication" makes no sense. The only logical implication
I can see is that two people fucked and videotaped it, and are unfortunatel=
y
well known enough in some circles that the tape is gossip worthy and made i=
t
onto the net. They aren't the only people to have done this, and I'll bet
you money that outside of any club/rave/electronic music social circles
no-one knows about this nor gives a fuck.

ps, upset person, it isn't the porn that bugged me, it's just that
somebody made the mistake of telling me not to talk about something.
I've actually spent hours and hours and hours re-editing porn and
putting digital effects on it because a girlfriend and I once made the
mistake of watching bad porn together on psychedelics. that's why it's
called "acid porn." you can take bad porn under normal circumstances,
but not on psychedelics. (trust me on this one.)

acid porn here:

http://pics.livejournal.com/dreamstooloud/gallery/00002ytz

aqui:
