Subject: [sfraves] Weekend Review

Friday Night - Modified :)

It was a really Good night!  I mean.. honestly, I seriously wasn't even
thinkin' about goin' out like all day 'cause OK.. I'm slakin n my current
class.. ditchin' my 1 night a week class on Wed 2 go 2 an art show wasn't
the smartest thing 2 do 'cuase I was like mentally fuxed up 4 some
reason... but la la la.. Hello 2Day... Adrianna persuaded me.. so i went
:)  Love U Girl!

When we got 2 the Modi-sindig.. it was like sooo totally Mondo Hella
Modi-Dope!  :)  Like I saw Groovers & ain't seen in like a loooooong
time.. so it was Wicked... throughout the night, there was House, Jungle,
Breaks, Breakcore, & Hardcore!  I danced my ass of in both rooms & I did
get "proper mashed" that night... LoL... yeah... having an excuse  havin a
mentally fuckedup weak is always a good reason 2 get fucked up.. LoL..
Hello2day.. even is dancing & Groovy people is all i need.. but all the
extras were oooooooh my gooosh... oh yeah... LOLOLMAO! :)

Party got broken up like an hour early 'cause some Oakland hood rats
decided it be fun to go around piching girls asses, bumping in2 people
while there were standing or dacning, and just being these Oakland ghetto
mondo drama thugs... 3 fights broke out, from what i saw, & me & Mz. Kitty
were like outta there! LoL

Saturday NIght: Drive & Rhythm Method

So I get down 2 Berk & again, hook up w/ Mz Kitty Litter.. we trek down 2
SOMA.. LoL.. as soon as we got walked over 2 the corner of Folsum & 9th...
Ranger's walki' down the street yellin' something.. YAAAAAAAAAY!!!  But b4
entering Shadow 4 some jungle... me & Ranger head over 2 Club 6 for Drive
shindig MissleToe Jam (I"ve always hated that name for a Christmas
party).. I mean.. ok.. so like we get in there... Proggy HOuse is goin' on
downstairs.... some like Chicago HOuse up stairs.. Dope!  Get downstairs..
Wil & ummm... ?Jack? (not Triumph) was spinning (well.. if Jack was his
name.. i couldn't hear down there... it Wicked... I mean... it was still
early there.. but the night was packin' in good so far...

I wanted to go 2 The Drive thingie mainly 'cause the headlining DJ  was Ty
Tek from Denver.. & like me & him have all out Homegirl Lauren (aka Ms
Vicious) in common & I wanted 2 ask him about her... but yeah man.. he's a
Dope DJ.. i heard his stuff like b4.. but didn't really stay there 4 his
set... dud catch up w/ Wil (Yaya, he misses u 2)... oh yeah.. bumped in2
like some Homies while there.. so that was also fun.. i was also told that
Mr Bamdon was gonna show up... but i kinda didn't hang out there 2 long
after a lil' dancey dancey...

Anywaze.. Ranger & I kinda like split up @ Club 6.. he kinda ditched me
(jk.. Love U Ranger) & well.. i knew that Evol Intent was like spinning
already @ Shadow.. so i went back there... OK... like 4 the 1st hour @
Rhythm Method i was there... oh yeah.. Evol Intent was on already spinning
& started out like playin' some liquidie kinda dubby stuff i guess... but
i dunno.. the vibe was kinda weird.. I felt all kindza like mixed... & i
dunno... but it took a while 2 settle in 'til i felt like right... or
maybe all the bad energy left... but definetly something just didn't feel
like mondo right wheni was there...

But Evol Intent's like set.. OK.. YUM!!  I know for sure he dropped alota
fresh tunes... ummm... after the liquid.. it got so much more harder..
like I wouldn't even know lik what sub genre 2 define it, but it was HARD
HARD jungle.. then went 2 HARDCORE!!!!  YUM!!!  Then went back 2 hard but
not as hard as like the middle hard of their set... so yeah... Hello
2day.. u follow?  LOLOLMAO... buyt yeah.. it was a sick set!  Oooh..
Hardcore in the middle of Jungle... Oh fuckin' shit man.. Hell Yeah!

After that... E$KR & Kompressah did this tag set... LoL.. OK.. this was
like somewhat of a Historic set as like alota the up & coming dnb
producers in the Bay Area had their tracks played that last set!  Ummmm...
 like Diatrybe, E$KR, Geoff, oh gosh.. i can't remember who else, all had
their new shit played & it was SIIIIIIIIICK!!  Loved it!

LoL.. it was fun like the night there @ the last RM... I mean.. heeeeeella
people showed up.. LoL. there's gonna be alota pics online soon 2 show all
the trouble that Knick from Evol Intent was causing!!  LoL.. oh yeah.. he
also picked me up & licked my eyeball.. Hello 2Day...

Yeah... I know Mz Kitty had some fun!  3 Seconds! HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!! 
Heeeeeeeello 2daaaaaay!

But yeah... Wow... I"m still like bubbley & high from the weekend still...
ok.. i really gotta do homework...

Love U all!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Well duh.  Growing up in Berkeley in the 70s does have
some educational advantages I'm finding.  

FWIW just try watching Deep Throat or even just
listening to the soundtrack when you are tripping. 
You won't even be able to listen to the entire song on
the opening credits without running outside to find a
tree to hug or something.  

Really. Try it yerself...

Peter

P.S For those of you who are too young to even know
about this movie:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_Throat_(movie)

even bad porn is good porn on psychedelics.  Making porn on psychedelics is
pretty cool too.

The best porn to watch on lots of acid is.....*drum roll*

Caligula

There is nothing better then lots of sex, blood and an insane tyrannical
roman emporer.  My life long dream is to build a sex boat and sail it acros=
s
the atlantic.

I'm still trying to determine if i was warped before or after Caligula on 1=
0
hits of acid.

Best movie to follow up Caligula on said night, is LA Blue Girl 2.

"FEEL MY ROOTS OF LUST!!!"

--
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

I've known for a long time. She made the mistake of dating some high profile 
DJ's here and there - and as a result people like to toss out all sorts of 
BS stories about how she jump started her career that way, etc. etc. 
Personally I think people just hate on her cuz they're jealous little 
bitches.

Hot damn!

I just wanted to give a quick thanks and mini-review of "QUALITY BURL", =
the party I spun at on Friday night.=20

1st off - big props to the crew for all the revamps they made of the =
venue. It looked fantastic!!! Sound was MUCH better then last time I was =
in there too. I was VERY impressed with the amount of work that had gone =
into the place.

The party was pretty damn off the chain. I heard a ton of reaalllllly =
good music in there. Ill-D the DJ, Hyjinx, Kris Kent, Alain Octavo - =
they ALL threw down bangin' ass sets.I never caught the names of the =
DJ's that kept dropping jungle amidst the hardcore, but they were pretty =
decent as well.=20

Saw a lot of SFR heads out and about, and met quite a few really cool =
folks as well. It was a really fun way to spend my Friday night for =
sure.

Special thanks to Jon (Hyjinx) and Chris (Element) for giving me the =
opportunity to play. I had a blast, and my services are yours, free of =
charge, any time you need them!!!!=20

Can't wait for the next soiree!!!

~Marc(O)

variables and have my client delete a whole thread without even reading it

Gmail rocks my socks too though :)

Subject: [sfraves] SFRaves 'Net  Archives


Searching archives of data on the internet resulted in some internet 
nuggets ... I'll post them to this thread when I find more...


Going back in time:

http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/2.07/net_surf.html?pg=5

Wired  - On the Newstands Now (Then)
Issue 2.07 | July 1994

Rec.Rave

Attention surf-ravers! All you ever wanted to know about hardcore, 
ambient, jungle beat, smart drinks, and amp hacks is yours for the picking 
from alt.rave. This is a chockablock gold mine, but be prepared for a 
fistful of Net.flyers from the UK, Belgium, San Francisco, and every other 
techno Mecca. (Hey -- a promoter is a promoter is a promoter....) Also 
catering to your techno-groove thang are the SFRaves Mailing List and 
Calendar. The calendar offers a complete listing of weekly and monthly 
events in Northern California. The list is a high-traffic dialogue of rave 
reviews (ar ar) and posts about upcoming gatherings. The address for 
subscribing and unsubscribing to the list and the calendar are the same -- 
send e-mail to majordomo@sfraves.stanford.edu. The subscriber should type 
(in the body of the message) the line subscribe sfraves for the main list, 
or subscribe sfraves-calendar for the calendar-only list. Subscribers to 
the main list automatically get the calendar, so they need not subscribe 
to both. E-mail Brian Behlendorf (http://wired.com/~brian/) at 
sfraves-owner@sfraves.stanford.edu with specific questions and be sure to 
check out the Web site. Rave down!

"The tree of liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the  
blood of patriots and tyrants. ... God forbid we should ever be  
twenty years without such a rebellion; what country can preserve its  
liberties if their rulers are not warned from time to time that their  
people preserve the spirit of resistance?  Let them take arms."

-- Thomas Jefferson to William Stephens Smith, 1787

Osby Oi Oi Jamz <osby@viberation.com> wrote:
  Friday Night - Modified :)

It was a really Good night! I mean.. honestly, I seriously wasn't even
thinkin' about goin' out like all day 'cause OK.. I'm slakin n my current
class.. ditchin' my 1 night a week class on Wed 2 go 2 an art show wasn't
the smartest thing 2 do 'cuase I was like mentally fuxed up 4 some
reason... but la la la.. Hello 2Day... Adrianna persuaded me.. so i went
:) Love U Girl!

When we got 2 the Modi-sindig.. it was like sooo totally Mondo Hella
Modi-Dope! :) Like I saw Groovers & ain't seen in like a loooooong
time.. so it was Wicked... throughout the night, there was House, Jungle,
Breaks, Breakcore, & Hardcore! I danced my ass of in both rooms & I did
get "proper mashed" that night... LoL... yeah... having an excuse havin a
mentally fuckedup weak is always a good reason 2 get fucked up.. LoL..
Hello2day.. even is dancing & Groovy people is all i need.. but all the
extras were oooooooh my gooosh... oh yeah... LOLOLMAO! :)

Party got broken up like an hour early 'cause some Oakland hood rats
decided it be fun to go around piching girls asses, bumping in2 people
while there were standing or dacning, and just being these Oakland ghetto
mondo drama thugs... 3 fights broke out, from what i saw, & me & Mz. Kitty
were like outta there! LoL

Saturday NIght: Drive & Rhythm Method

So I get down 2 Berk & again, hook up w/ Mz Kitty.. we trek down 2
SOMA.. LoL.. as soon as we got walked over 2 the corner of Folsum & 9th...
Ranger's walki' down the street yellin' something.. YAAAAAAAAAY!!! But b4
entering Shadow 4 some jungle... me & Ranger head over 2 Club 6 for Drive
shindig MissleToe Jam (I"ve always hated that name for a Christmas
party).. I mean.. ok.. so like we get in there... Proggy HOuse is goin' on
downstairs.... some like Chicago HOuse up stairs.. Dope! Get downstairs..
Wil & ummm... ?Jack? (not Triumph) was spinning (well.. if Jack was his
name.. i couldn't hear down there... it Wicked... I mean... it was still
early there.. but the night was packin' in good so far...

I wanted to go 2 The Drive thingie mainly 'cause the headlining DJ was Ty
Tek from Denver.. & like me & him have all out Homegirl Lauren (aka Ms
Vicious) in common & I wanted 2 ask him about her... but yeah man.. he's a
Dope DJ.. i heard his stuff like b4.. but didn't really stay there 4 his
set... dud catch up w/ Wil (Yaya, he misses u 2)... oh yeah.. bumped in2
like some Homies while there.. so that was also fun.. i was also told that
Mr Bamdon was gonna show up... but i kinda didn't hang out there 2 long
after a lil' dancey dancey...

Anywaze.. Ranger & I kinda like split up @ Club 6.. he kinda ditched me
(jk.. Love U Ranger) & well.. i knew that Evol Intent was like spinning
already @ Shadow.. so i went back there... OK... like 4 the 1st hour @
Rhythm Method i was there... oh yeah.. Evol Intent was on already spinning
& started out like playin' some liquidie kinda dubby stuff i guess... but
i dunno.. the vibe was kinda weird.. I felt all kindza like mixed... & i
dunno... but it took a while 2 settle in 'til i felt like right... or
maybe all the bad energy left... but definetly something just didn't feel
like mondo right wheni was there...

But Evol Intent's like set.. OK.. YUM!! I know for sure he dropped alota
fresh tunes... ummm... after the liquid.. it got so much more harder..
like I wouldn't even know lik what sub genre 2 define it, but it was HARD
HARD jungle.. then went 2 HARDCORE!!!! YUM!!! Then went back 2 hard but
not as hard as like the middle hard of their set... so yeah... Hello
2day.. u follow? LOLOLMAO... buyt yeah.. it was a sick set! Oooh..
Hardcore in the middle of Jungle... Oh fuckin' shit man.. Hell Yeah!

After that... E$KR & Kompressah did this tag set... LoL.. OK.. this was
like somewhat of a Historic set as like alota the up & coming dnb
producers in the Bay Area had their tracks played that last set! Ummmm...
like Diatrybe, E$KR, Geoff, oh gosh.. i can't remember who else, all had
their new shit played & it was SIIIIIIIIICK!! Loved it!

LoL.. it was fun like the night there @ the last RM... I mean.. heeeeeella
people showed up.. LoL. there's gonna be alota pics online soon 2 show all
the trouble that Knick from Evol Intent was causing!! LoL.. oh yeah.. he
also picked me up & licked my eyeball.. Hello 2Day...

Yeah... I know Mz Kitty had some fun! 3 Seconds! HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!! 
Heeeeeeeello 2daaaaaay!

But yeah... Wow... I"m still like bubbley & high from the weekend still...
ok.. i really gotta do homework...

Love U all!

Subject: [sfraves] On the Dead and Dying, Part 2: Arnold's Choice:

--------------070606040409050900090609
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit


      12/13/2005

*On the Dead and Dying, Part 2: Arnold's Choice*:
Man, the Rude Pundit wants Arnold Schwarzenegger 
<http://www.imdb.com/gallery/ss/0088247/Terminator_PUB01.jpg> to be in 
charge of all decisions of life or death. He wants that deep thinkin' 
demi-Nazi to walk from cell to cell at San Quentin and mark a chalk X 
outside each door. Because Arnold Schwarzenegger 
<http://www.imdb.com/gallery/ss/0093773/6098_16_12.jpg> is just who we 
all want tellin' us who should live or die, who deserves mercy and who 
deserves death. Goddamn, what an easy world it'll be havin' Arnold 
Schwarzenegger <http://www.imdb.com/gallery/ss/0088944/6030_16_3.JPG> 
make all those decisions.

Fuck, let's not limit Arnold Schwarzenegger 
<http://webfantasy.info/Arnold_Schwarzenegger/Images/Arnold_Schwarzenegger_Conan_01.jpg> 
to the executable on death row; send Arnold Schwarzenegger 
<http://www.imdb.com/gallery/ss/0111503/6767_3_1.jpg> into hospitals so 
he can give the thumbs up or thumbs down to each person on life support. 
The Rude Pundit wants us to entrust Arnold Schwarzenegger 
<http://www.angelfire.com/celeb/Schwarzenegger/images/arnie03.jpg> with 
that shit. Let's not stop with amendin' the Constitution so Arnold can 
lead us all. The Rude Pundit wants Arnold Schwarzenegger 
<http://www.angelfire.com/celeb/Schwarzenegger/images/arnie01.jpg> on 
the left hand of God, Jesus, Allah, who the fuck ever, sayin' to that 
big ass deity where to toss lightnin', where to unleash a plague, where 
to make the waters rise, and where to make the land dry out.

'Cause no one knows how to judge the worth of a soul like Arnold 
Schwarzenegger <http://www.imdb.com/gallery/ss/0110216/1-15.jpg>, man. 
No one could tell whether or not someone's more valuable dead than 
alive, no one can say how many lives will be saved if Stanley "Tookie" 
Williams had been allowed to live 
<http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/LegalCenter/wireStory?id=1400266>, no one is 
full of unbiased, apolitical consideration more than Arnold Fuckin' 
Schwarzenegger <http://www.imdb.com/gallery/ss/0420678/electionnight.jpg>.

Arnold Fuckin' Schwarzenegger? Ya gotta be fuckin' kiddin'. Who's been 
indirectly responsible for more violence since the early 1980s, Tookie 
or the Terminator 
<http://www.media-awareness.ca/english/issues/violence/violence_entertainment.cfm>? 
Tough question, no?

For, if nothing else, the Williams case has laid clear the absurdity of 
the governorship of Arnold Schwarzenegger. If you spend your life acting 
like an amoral, gun-firing buffoon, why should anyone expect you to act 
differently as the governor? That would require an act of clemency by 
the voting public, that might require you to say you wanted to redeem 
yourself for your past sins.

Meanwhile, last night, the Rude Pundit flipped between CNN and Fox 
"News" to watch coverage of the execution of Stanley Williams. CNN went 
with the more intellectually stimulating CNN International (motto: Other 
countries are smarter than the United States, and we prove it every day) 
for its reporting, and Fox went with the usual Murdoch spooge buckets.

A couple of brief observations: whoever the pro-death penalty guy on 
CNNi was, he was one creepy motherfucker, speaking in perfectly even 
tones about the need for "justice," and apocalyptically quoting the 
Bible. When confronted by the anchor (possibly Todd Benjamin) with the 
notion of turning the other cheek, creepy pro-death guy calmly short 
circuited as he tried to shoehorn that bromide into his kill 'em all 
mentality. Then he took out a cute little lamb and ate it alive. Truly 
stunning TV for 3 a.m.

Fox "News" took every opportunity, which meant every time someone opened 
his or her mouth, to talk about Williams' murder conviction, the 
victims' families, or the Crips. Fox had a reporter witnessing the 
execution. He was roughly the tenth media witness to speak, and the 
first to say that Williams had stared at the media section as if trying 
to "intimidate" them. Fox stuck to the script, man, of Tookie the 
monster, as if to grant clemency meant that Williams would be set free 
to rape white children, not simply live out his life in prison without 
parole.

And the most disheartening thing of all was how little was mentioned, in 
the cruel march to the death chamber, of how the ex-wife of one of 
Williams' alleged victims, Albert Owens (whose family is entirely 
fucked-up in conflict 
<http://www.modbee.com/local/v-dp_morning/story/11566867p-12300721c.html>over 
the execution), called <http://www.naacp.org/news/2005/2005-12-09.html> 
for support of Williams' efforts to redeem himself for his gang-building 
past: "I, Linda Owens want to build upon Mr. Williams' peace initiative. 
I invite Mr. Williams to join me in sending a message to all communities 
that we should all unite in peace. This position of peace would honor my 
husband's memory and Mr. Williams work."

A call for peace to honor the dead? What fuckin' country does Linda 
Owens think she's living in? Not in George Bush's America, where more 
must die in Iraq to make sure the dead are honored. And certainly not in 
Arnold Schwarzenegger's California.
// posted by Rude One @ 9:51 AM 
<http://rudepundit.blogspot.com/2005/12/on-dead-and-dying-part-2-arnolds.html>

--------------070606040409050900090609--

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I quit going to most parties in '94. the day i heard house music in a public shoe store on haight street was the day i knew the scene was starting a downward spiral. there wasn't much attitude back then. every once in a while i will go to a party but i am pretty picky. so no, the parties i go to i don't have to deal with rave drama. this scene has been a part of my life for over 15 years now but it is just one part of my life. it doesn't define who i am therefore there is no reason for drama.

Giles Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com> wrote: oh come on. you've never heard of rave drama?

On 12/12/05, matthew johnson  wrote:
> this is a new phenomena. this is a bullshit statement. has the scene changed this much over the years? so much for taking care of your peers. what's happened?
>
> If you can't handle drama, you don't belong on stage. You go
> into the rave scene expecting to live a drama-free existence, the only
> way that can happen is if nobody realizes you're there.
>
>
>
>
> ---------------------------------
> Yahoo! Shopping
>  Find Great Deals on Holiday Gifts at Yahoo! Shopping
>

Giles Soundwave = Giles Goat Boy
http://www.gilesgoatboy.org/

Subject: [sfraves] rave ban provokes rioting in rennes, france





http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article332471.ece

Ravers clash with French police after party ban

 By John Lichfield in Paris
Published: 12 December 2005

More than 500 people rioted for 12 hours in the centre of Rennes, the
capital of Brittany, to protest at the banning of a rave party.

They smashed shop windows, burned dustbins and showered police with pav=
ing
stones and bottles. Two policemen were hurt and 30 people arrested. Tea=
r
gas and water cannon were used to sweep the last of the rioters off the=

streets just before dawn yesterday.

The party, on the fringe of the Transmusicales rock festival, had been
authorised by the mayor of Rennes, who provided a field on the edge of =
the
city. The all-night, open-air dance and music event had been banned on
Tuesday by Bernadette Malgorn, the prefect - or senior national governm=
ent
administrator - for Brittany. She complained the likely number of teufe=
urs,
or ravers, was a threat to public safety.

The violence began on Saturday afternoon when youths marched through Re=
nnes
chanting "freedom" and "we want a field". Confrontations with riot poli=
ce
turned into running battles. The violence came a month after riots by y=
oung
people in poor suburbs of French cities. On this occasion, the rioters =
were
mostly middle-class and from universities in Rennes and other parts of
France.

The socialist mayor of Rennes, Edmond Herv=E9, accused the prefect of
provoking the violence. "The ban was a mistake and we've suffered the
consequences," he said. The field was safe and hosted a rave three year=
s
ago, he said.

Mme Malgorn said there was "enormous uncertainty" about the possible
numbers of ravers. The organisers had promised 10,000 but the authoriti=
es
calculated 30,000 might turn up.

Subject: NRR: Re: [sfraves] On the Dead and Dying, Part 2: Arnold's Choice:
 ***WARNING GRAPHIC***

It was pretty sickening to have the governator cite the dedications in 
Tookie's book as evidence that he hasn't redeemed himself.  Almost all 
of those cited were people of color.  Here's a snippet from 
http://www.counterpunch.org/gasper12132005.html

"In the days leading up to the execution, new evidence that Stan was 
framed emerged and was simply ignored. Having dismissed questions about 
the conviction, the Governor then concludes that since Stan will not 
apologize for crimes he has always denied committing, "there can be no 
redemption."

Even more outrageous, however, is the following passage:

"The dedication of Williams' book "Life in Prison" casts significant 
doubt on his personal redemption. This book was published in 1998, 
several years after Williams' claimed redemptive experience. 
Specifically, the book is dedicated to "Nelson Mandela, Angela Davis, 
Malcolm X, Assata Shakur, Geronimo Ji Jaga Pratt, Ramona Africa, John 
Africa, Leonard Peltier, Dhoruba Al-Mujahid, George Jackson, Mumia 
Abu-Jamal, and the countless other men, women, and youths who have to 
endure the hellish oppression of living behind bars." The mix of 
individuals on this list is curious. Most have violent pasts and some 
have been convicted of committing heinous murders, including the killing 
of law enforcement.

But the inclusion of George Jackson on this list defies reason and is a 
significant indicator that Williams is not reformed and that he still 
sees violence and lawlessness as a legitimate means to address societal 
problems."


Of those convicted of "committing heinous murders" on this list, two 
(Geronimo Ji Jaga Pratt and Dhoruba Al-Mujahid) were later found to have 
been wrongfully convicted after serving a combined forty-six years 
behind bars, and four (Assata Shakur, John Africa, Leonard Peltier and 
Mumia Abu-Jamal) have always proclaimed their innocence and are widely 
believed to have been framed. George Jackson, who Schwarzenegger 
apparently regards as the epitome of "violence and lawlessness" was 
convicted of stealing $71 in 1960 at the age of 18, sentenced to an 
indeterminate sentence of 1 year to life, became a Black Panther and 
political leader in prison (which Schwarzenegger equates with forming a 
gang), charged but never convicted of killing a prison guard, and 
assassinated by guards in 1971."


Who do you suppose is responsible for inciding more violence, Tookie or 
The Terminator?


Evidence Points to Frame-Up in Tookie Williams Case
Commentary, Clive Leeman,
New America Media, Dec 07, 2005

Editor's Note: Focusing on Stanley "Tookie" Williams' good works while 
on death row misses the inconsistencies, lack of physical evidence and 
questionable stories spun by informants that ultimately convicted him, 
says the writer, who calls for a death penalty moratorium.

OJAI, Calif.--If Stanley Tookie Williams is executed on Tuesday, Dec. 
13, poisoned to death by the State of California, his fame will have 
doomed him. We may well have killed an innocent man without even 
realizing it.

On the other hand, if Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger grants clemency to 
Williams because he has rehabilitated himself, his fame will have saved 
him, and the crucial question of his innocence will simply fade away.

At a time when more and more Americans are turning against the death 
penalty because of increasing evidence that innocent people have been 
executed, we have allowed ourselves to be so bedazzled by the celebrity 
hype surrounding the Tookie Williams case that one important truth has 
been ignored: Stanley Williams may be innocent of the crimes for which 
he was convicted.

Was Williams truly proven "guilty beyond a reasonable doubt"? A careful 
reading of attorney Verna Wefald's 88-page appeal to the California 
Supreme Court to reopen Williams' case strongly suggests that Tookie was 
framed and railroaded in a trial riddled with inconsistencies, 
contradictions, lack of physical evidence and false stories spun by a 
parade of informers trying to save their own necks.

As a founder of the Crips gang, Williams was assumed to be guilty before 
he was even charged with four murders. He was the Black Man Rampant, the 
Black Bogeyman, the Bigger Thomas of South Central Los Angeles. Williams 
was convicted by his notoriety, not by the evidence.

According to Wefald and federal courts that reviewed Williams' case, 
Williams' 1981 trial for the murder of Albert Owens, a convenience store 
clerk in Whittier, and Los Angeles motel owners Yen-I Yang, Tsai-Shaic 
Yang and their daughter, Yee Chen Lin was based on flimsy circumstantial 
evidence; the fabricated testimony of five informants having "incentives 
to lie in order to obtain leniency from the state...." (according to the 
Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals); and the perjury of at least one police 
officer.

Physical evidence such as fingerprints and a bloody boot-print could not 
be traced to Williams.

Only one shotgun shell was found at the motel. It ostensibly came from a 
shotgun purchased legally five years before by Williams, but the gun 
itself was actually found under the bed of informants James Garrett and 
his wife, Ester. The Browning shotgun shell was sold at only two local 
stores, one of which, a Big Five, had been robbed of guns and ammunition 
by Garrett the year before.

The Garretts were both being investigated for the murder of their crime 
partner, Gregory Wilbon. This investigation was dropped, according to 
Wefald, after they testified that Williams "volunteered" a confession to 
them.

Deputy Gilbert Gwaltney perjured himself when he supported Garrett by 
testifying that the informant had a sound alibi at the time his crime 
partner Wilbon was murdered. Wilbon's body was so badly decomposed, 
Williams' lawyers write, that it was impossible to establish a time of 
death and thus impossible to establish an alibi.

Another informant also claimed that Williams had "volunteered" a 
confession to him -- but only after a police officer had left the police 
file on Williams overnight in the informant's cell for him to read 
before he testified the next day, according to Wefald.

The prosecutor, who had already been censured twice by the California 
Supreme Court for discriminatory behavior, threw three African-Americans 
off the jury, leaving a majority-white jury with few or no blacks (at 
least one juror's racial identity is in dispute).

Wefald's appeal was turned down by the California Supreme Court on Nov. 
30 by a 4-2 vote. This is not uncommon, especially in cases which do not 
involve DNA evidence.

Every appeal to the California Supreme Court made by wrongfully 
convicted prisoner Gloria Killean was routinely denied for 16 years, 
until a federal court overturned her life sentence. And Thomas Goldstein 
filed repeated appeals to the court for 24 years before being exonerated 
by a federal court.

And the California Supreme Court's divided vote "indicates the 
seriousness of the issues that were raised by the motion," Williams' 
attorney Jonathan Harris said.

But the railroading never ceases. The moment the Dec. 13 execution date 
was announced last month, authorities rushed Williams to the holding 
cell next to the death chamber, three weeks before the usual holding 
period begins.

Now the ultimate humiliation is being required of Tookie Williams. Like 
the innocent women at the Salem witch trials, he is being told he should 
confess in order to save his own life, a Catch-22 if ever there was one. 
This he refuses to do. He says he will not compromise his dignity and 
integrity, the most powerful and precious forces in his life today.

One of the most compelling arguments against the death penalty is that 
we inevitably kill innocent people. Britain abolished capital punishment 
in 1965 after Timothy Evans, hanged for strangling his young daughter, 
was later found to be innocent.

Now, new developments like DNA evidence are leading to the release of 
significant numbers of innocent people from death rows and prisons 
across the United States, and support for the death penalty is steadily 
declining.

In 2000, the same year that Illinois Governor George Ryan declared a 
moratorium on executions in his state, a California Field Poll showed 
that 73 percent of Californians supported a similar moratorium. The 
number is probably higher today.

Instead of spending hours agonizing over Tookie Williams' fate (and his 
own political future), Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger should do the right 
thing and suspend the executions of all 637 death row inmates 
immediately.

PNS contributor Clive Leeman lives in Ojai, Calif., and writes about 
human rights issues.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Lick The DJ on An Epiphany Of Sound thur.

Hey folks,
This thursday I promise not to let any hangups about money cloud my 
judgement as to what's fun and moral (or maybe a little immoral. ;) ) 
(Yeah, I'm no Libertarian. :) ) Instead, I'll be bringing you someone 
who prefers his tracks with a good acid line, Lick The DJ.

Lick The DJ has been hanging with the likes of FnF, so you know he knows 
his acid lines.  He's also part of Lost Tribe (the Sweet parties) and 
he's part of Lick The Micron (a tagteam duo with Micron.)  Peep him at 
http://www.lickthedj.com to find out more.

The main thing is that you tune in to the show this Thur.  You can 
expect to hear things in the tech-house, house and techno realms, mainly 
with that good acid line!!  We're at 90.1 FM and online at 
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Namaste.

In-Reply-To: <20051213132728.X66313@kzsu.stanford.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline
References: <96e151a20512131244w635281c5ta24b65b06092472f@mail.gmail.com>
	 <20051213132728.X66313@kzsu.stanford.edu>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: NRR: Re: [sfraves] On the Dead and Dying, Part 2: Arnold's Choice: ***WARNING GRAPHIC***

One thing I'd like to say to this:

I understand that under some circumstances, the law is wrong when it
comes to capital punishment. Regardless of whether or not he redeemed
himself, he was still a bad, bad man.

When you do something, you are to take responsibility for your
actions. He was a drug dealer, a founding member of the crips, and
probably did things much worse than the actions he was found guilty
of, regardless of whether he was actually guilty of those crimes he
was convicted of or not.

That's like saying that hitler was not guilty of crimes against
humanity, just because he didn't physically pull the trigger.

Anyhoo, as much as I'd want to think that the guy is innocent of those
crimes, the thought in the back of my head that he most likely did
much worse things, and that the organization he started has done
terrible things, nearly tearing LA apart, makes me really go against
saving this man's life.

I dunno, maybe I'm just jaded with my outsider views on the whole
situation. Maybe he was really reformed. No matter what, what's done
is done, and my life will go on. My life is unaffected by his death.

On 12/13/05, J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:
> It was pretty sickening to have the governator cite the dedications in
> Tookie's book as evidence that he hasn't redeemed himself.  Almost all
> of those cited were people of color.  Here's a snippet from
> http://www.counterpunch.org/gasper12132005.html
>
> "In the days leading up to the execution, new evidence that Stan was
> framed emerged and was simply ignored. Having dismissed questions about
> the conviction, the Governor then concludes that since Stan will not
> apologize for crimes he has always denied committing, "there can be no
> redemption."
>
> Even more outrageous, however, is the following passage:
>
> "The dedication of Williams' book "Life in Prison" casts significant
> doubt on his personal redemption. This book was published in 1998,
> several years after Williams' claimed redemptive experience.
> Specifically, the book is dedicated to "Nelson Mandela, Angela Davis,
> Malcolm X, Assata Shakur, Geronimo Ji Jaga Pratt, Ramona Africa, John
> Africa, Leonard Peltier, Dhoruba Al-Mujahid, George Jackson, Mumia
> Abu-Jamal, and the countless other men, women, and youths who have to
> endure the hellish oppression of living behind bars." The mix of
> individuals on this list is curious. Most have violent pasts and some
> have been convicted of committing heinous murders, including the killing
> of law enforcement.
>
> But the inclusion of George Jackson on this list defies reason and is a
> significant indicator that Williams is not reformed and that he still
> sees violence and lawlessness as a legitimate means to address societal
> problems."
>
>
> Of those convicted of "committing heinous murders" on this list, two
> (Geronimo Ji Jaga Pratt and Dhoruba Al-Mujahid) were later found to have
> been wrongfully convicted after serving a combined forty-six years
> behind bars, and four (Assata Shakur, John Africa, Leonard Peltier and
> Mumia Abu-Jamal) have always proclaimed their innocence and are widely
> believed to have been framed. George Jackson, who Schwarzenegger
> apparently regards as the epitome of "violence and lawlessness" was
> convicted of stealing $71 in 1960 at the age of 18, sentenced to an
> indeterminate sentence of 1 year to life, became a Black Panther and
> political leader in prison (which Schwarzenegger equates with forming a
> gang), charged but never convicted of killing a prison guard, and
> assassinated by guards in 1971."
>
>
> Who do you suppose is responsible for inciding more violence, Tookie or
> The Terminator?
>
>
> Evidence Points to Frame-Up in Tookie Williams Case
> Commentary, Clive Leeman,
> New America Media, Dec 07, 2005
>
> Editor's Note: Focusing on Stanley "Tookie" Williams' good works while
> on death row misses the inconsistencies, lack of physical evidence and
> questionable stories spun by informants that ultimately convicted him,
> says the writer, who calls for a death penalty moratorium.
>
> OJAI, Calif.--If Stanley Tookie Williams is executed on Tuesday, Dec.
> 13, poisoned to death by the State of California, his fame will have
> doomed him. We may well have killed an innocent man without even
> realizing it.
>
> On the other hand, if Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger grants clemency to
> Williams because he has rehabilitated himself, his fame will have saved
> him, and the crucial question of his innocence will simply fade away.
>
> At a time when more and more Americans are turning against the death
> penalty because of increasing evidence that innocent people have been
> executed, we have allowed ourselves to be so bedazzled by the celebrity
> hype surrounding the Tookie Williams case that one important truth has
> been ignored: Stanley Williams may be innocent of the crimes for which
> he was convicted.
>
> Was Williams truly proven "guilty beyond a reasonable doubt"? A careful
> reading of attorney Verna Wefald's 88-page appeal to the California
> Supreme Court to reopen Williams' case strongly suggests that Tookie was
> framed and railroaded in a trial riddled with inconsistencies,
> contradictions, lack of physical evidence and false stories spun by a
> parade of informers trying to save their own necks.
>
> As a founder of the Crips gang, Williams was assumed to be guilty before
> he was even charged with four murders. He was the Black Man Rampant, the
> Black Bogeyman, the Bigger Thomas of South Central Los Angeles. Williams
> was convicted by his notoriety, not by the evidence.
>
> According to Wefald and federal courts that reviewed Williams' case,
> Williams' 1981 trial for the murder of Albert Owens, a convenience store
> clerk in Whittier, and Los Angeles motel owners Yen-I Yang, Tsai-Shaic
> Yang and their daughter, Yee Chen Lin was based on flimsy circumstantial
> evidence; the fabricated testimony of five informants having "incentives
> to lie in order to obtain leniency from the state...." (according to the
> Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals); and the perjury of at least one police
> officer.
>
> Physical evidence such as fingerprints and a bloody boot-print could not
> be traced to Williams.
>
> Only one shotgun shell was found at the motel. It ostensibly came from a
> shotgun purchased legally five years before by Williams, but the gun
> itself was actually found under the bed of informants James Garrett and
> his wife, Ester. The Browning shotgun shell was sold at only two local
> stores, one of which, a Big Five, had been robbed of guns and ammunition
> by Garrett the year before.
>
> The Garretts were both being investigated for the murder of their crime
> partner, Gregory Wilbon. This investigation was dropped, according to
> Wefald, after they testified that Williams "volunteered" a confession to
> them.
>
> Deputy Gilbert Gwaltney perjured himself when he supported Garrett by
> testifying that the informant had a sound alibi at the time his crime
> partner Wilbon was murdered. Wilbon's body was so badly decomposed,
> Williams' lawyers write, that it was impossible to establish a time of
> death and thus impossible to establish an alibi.
>
> Another informant also claimed that Williams had "volunteered" a
> confession to him -- but only after a police officer had left the police
> file on Williams overnight in the informant's cell for him to read
> before he testified the next day, according to Wefald.
>
> The prosecutor, who had already been censured twice by the California
> Supreme Court for discriminatory behavior, threw three African-Americans
> off the jury, leaving a majority-white jury with few or no blacks (at
> least one juror's racial identity is in dispute).
>
> Wefald's appeal was turned down by the California Supreme Court on Nov.
> 30 by a 4-2 vote. This is not uncommon, especially in cases which do not
> involve DNA evidence.
>
> Every appeal to the California Supreme Court made by wrongfully
> convicted prisoner Gloria Killean was routinely denied for 16 years,
> until a federal court overturned her life sentence. And Thomas Goldstein
> filed repeated appeals to the court for 24 years before being exonerated
> by a federal court.
>
> And the California Supreme Court's divided vote "indicates the
> seriousness of the issues that were raised by the motion," Williams'
> attorney Jonathan Harris said.
>
> But the railroading never ceases. The moment the Dec. 13 execution date
> was announced last month, authorities rushed Williams to the holding
> cell next to the death chamber, three weeks before the usual holding
> period begins.
>
> Now the ultimate humiliation is being required of Tookie Williams. Like
> the innocent women at the Salem witch trials, he is being told he should
> confess in order to save his own life, a Catch-22 if ever there was one.
> This he refuses to do. He says he will not compromise his dignity and
> integrity, the most powerful and precious forces in his life today.
>
> One of the most compelling arguments against the death penalty is that
> we inevitably kill innocent people. Britain abolished capital punishment
> in 1965 after Timothy Evans, hanged for strangling his young daughter,
> was later found to be innocent.
>
> Now, new developments like DNA evidence are leading to the release of
> significant numbers of innocent people from death rows and prisons
> across the United States, and support for the death penalty is steadily
> declining.
>
> In 2000, the same year that Illinois Governor George Ryan declared a
> moratorium on executions in his state, a California Field Poll showed
> that 73 percent of Californians supported a similar moratorium. The
> number is probably higher today.
>
> Instead of spending hours agonizing over Tookie Williams' fate (and his
> own political future), Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger should do the right
> thing and suspend the executions of all 637 death row inmates
> immediately.
>
> PNS contributor Clive Leeman lives in Ojai, Calif., and writes about
> human rights issues.
>
>
>
> So your picture below is relevant how???
>
>
> On 13 December 2005, Steve Osteen wrote:
>
> > **** WARNING GRAPHIC SHIT AHEAD****
> >
> > Hey Alex,
> >
> > You forgot to put this picture in your blog:
> >
> > http://www.homestead.com/prosites-prs/tookievictim3adweb.jpg
> >
> >
>
>
> http://www.jcthedj.com
> http://byebyeus.tribe.net (The U.S. is finished.)
> AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)
>
> "Art and Sex are the same thing."
> -- Pablo Picasso

> "Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
> KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: Re: NRR: Re: [sfraves] On the Dead and Dying, Part 2: Arnold's Choice: ***WARNING GRAPHIC***

Or maybe you're just a white guy from the burbs seeing only one side of the 
coin.

Not a diss on you man - but very few people actually take any REAL time even 
ATTEMPTING to think of the environment folks like that come out of. Can they 
rise above that? YES. But some (like in Tookie's case) may not get that 
chance til after they've already made a serious mistake. Does that make them 
any less worthy of of life? I mean - the guy has obviously turned a corner 
and found ways to give back to the community he helped damage. That shows 
remorse on many levels. Correct me if I'm wrong, but prison is SUPPOSED to 
rehabilitate, not be a holding pen for people on the way to the slaughter.

When you reduce people's lives to nothing more than cattle in a 
slaughterhouse, you are playing god.

One thing I'd like to say to this:

I understand that under some circumstances, the law is wrong when it
comes to capital punishment. Regardless of whether or not he redeemed
himself, he was still a bad, bad man.

probably did things much worse than the actions he was found guilty
of, regardless of whether he was actually guilty of those crimes he
was convicted of or not.

That's like saying that hitler was not guilty of crimes against
humanity, just because he didn't physically pull the trigger.

crimes, the thought in the back of my head that he most likely did

terrible things, nearly tearing LA apart, makes me really go against

situation. Maybe he was really reformed. No matter what, what's done

> contradictions, lack of physical evidence and false stories spun by a
> parade of informers trying to save their own necks.
>
> As a founder of the Crips gang, Williams was assumed to be guilty before
> he was even charged with four murders. He was the Black Man Rampant, the
> Black Bogeyman, the Bigger Thomas of South Central Los Angeles. Williams
> was convicted by his notoriety, not by the evidence.
>
> According to Wefald and federal courts that reviewed Williams' case,
> Williams' 1981 trial for the murder of Albert Owens, a convenience store
> clerk in Whittier, and Los Angeles motel owners Yen-I Yang, Tsai-Shaic
> Yang and their daughter, Yee Chen Lin was based on flimsy circumstantial

> to lie in order to obtain leniency from the state...." (according to the
> Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals); and the perjury of at least one police
> officer.
>
> Physical evidence such as fingerprints and a bloody boot-print could not
> be traced to Williams.
>
> Only one shotgun shell was found at the motel. It ostensibly came from a
> shotgun purchased legally five years before by Williams, but the gun
> itself was actually found under the bed of informants James Garrett and
> his wife, Ester. The Browning shotgun shell was sold at only two local
> stores, one of which, a Big Five, had been robbed of guns and ammunition
> by Garrett the year before.
>
> The Garretts were both being investigated for the murder of their crime
> partner, Gregory Wilbon. This investigation was dropped, according to
> Wefald, after they testified that Williams "volunteered" a confession to
> them.
>
> Deputy Gilbert Gwaltney perjured himself when he supported Garrett by
> testifying that the informant had a sound alibi at the time his crime
> partner Wilbon was murdered. Wilbon's body was so badly decomposed,
> Williams' lawyers write, that it was impossible to establish a time of
> death and thus impossible to establish an alibi.
>
> Another informant also claimed that Williams had "volunteered" a
> confession to him -- but only after a police officer had left the police
> file on Williams overnight in the informant's cell for him to read
> before he testified the next day, according to Wefald.
>
> The prosecutor, who had already been censured twice by the California
> Supreme Court for discriminatory behavior, threw three African-Americans
> off the jury, leaving a majority-white jury with few or no blacks (at
> least one juror's racial identity is in dispute).
>
> Wefald's appeal was turned down by the California Supreme Court on Nov.
> 30 by a 4-2 vote. This is not uncommon, especially in cases which do not
> involve DNA evidence.
>
> Every appeal to the California Supreme Court made by wrongfully
> convicted prisoner Gloria Killean was routinely denied for 16 years,
> until a federal court overturned her life sentence. And Thomas Goldstein
> filed repeated appeals to the court for 24 years before being exonerated
> by a federal court.
>
> And the California Supreme Court's divided vote "indicates the
> seriousness of the issues that were raised by the motion," Williams'
> attorney Jonathan Harris said.
>
> But the railroading never ceases. The moment the Dec. 13 execution date
> was announced last month, authorities rushed Williams to the holding
> cell next to the death chamber, three weeks before the usual holding
> period begins.
>
> Now the ultimate humiliation is being required of Tookie Williams. Like
> the innocent women at the Salem witch trials, he is being told he should
> confess in order to save his own life, a Catch-22 if ever there was one.
> This he refuses to do. He says he will not compromise his dignity and
> integrity, the most powerful and precious forces in his life today.

> One of the most compelling arguments against the death penalty is that
> we inevitably kill innocent people. Britain abolished capital punishment
> in 1965 after Timothy Evans, hanged for strangling his young daughter,
> was later found to be innocent.
>
> Now, new developments like DNA evidence are leading to the release of
> significant numbers of innocent people from death rows and prisons
> across the United States, and support for the death penalty is steadily
> declining.
>

> moratorium on executions in his state, a California Field Poll showed
> that 73 percent of Californians supported a similar moratorium. The
> number is probably higher today.

Subject: Re: NRR: Re: [sfraves] On the Dead and Dying, Part 2: Arnold's Choice: ***WARNING GRAPHIC***

That is so irrelevent. Every single one of us grew up with some
hardship in some form or another. It's how you overcome that hardship
and what you make of yourself that counts. So many people love to
follow the racist Malcolm X'es footsteps into blaming someone else so
much that they forget about their personal responsibility.

Yes. You can choose to overcome. Yes yours is harder then others.

MAN WAS NOT CREATED EQUAL and EQUAL TALENT AND HARD WORK ALWAYS
DESERVES EQUAL OPPORTUNITIES.

On 12/13/05, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> Or maybe you're just a white guy from the burbs seeing only one side of t=
he
> coin.
>
> Not a diss on you man - but very few people actually take any REAL time e=
ven
> ATTEMPTING to think of the environment folks like that come out of. Can t=
hey
> rise above that? YES. But some (like in Tookie's case) may not get that
> chance til after they've already made a serious mistake. Does that make t=
hem
> any less worthy of of life? I mean - the guy has obviously turned a corne=

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "John Dee" <antitux@gmail.com>
> To: "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>
> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Tuesday, December 13, 2005 3:13 PM
> Subject: Re: NRR: Re: [sfraves] On the Dead and Dying, Part 2: Arnold's
> Choice: ***WARNING GRAPHIC***
>
>
> One thing I'd like to say to this:
>
> I understand that under some circumstances, the law is wrong when it
> comes to capital punishment. Regardless of whether or not he redeemed
> himself, he was still a bad, bad man.
>
> When you do something, you are to take responsibility for your
> actions. He was a drug dealer, a founding member of the crips, and
> probably did things much worse than the actions he was found guilty
> of, regardless of whether he was actually guilty of those crimes he
> was convicted of or not.
>
> That's like saying that hitler was not guilty of crimes against
> humanity, just because he didn't physically pull the trigger.
>
> Anyhoo, as much as I'd want to think that the guy is innocent of those
> crimes, the thought in the back of my head that he most likely did
> much worse things, and that the organization he started has done
> terrible things, nearly tearing LA apart, makes me really go against
> saving this man's life.
>
> I dunno, maybe I'm just jaded with my outsider views on the whole
> situation. Maybe he was really reformed. No matter what, what's done
> is done, and my life will go on. My life is unaffected by his death.
>
> On 12/13/05, J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:
> > It was pretty sickening to have the governator cite the dedications in
> > Tookie's book as evidence that he hasn't redeemed himself.  Almost all
> > of those cited were people of color.  Here's a snippet from
> > http://www.counterpunch.org/gasper12132005.html
> >
> > "In the days leading up to the execution, new evidence that Stan was
> > framed emerged and was simply ignored. Having dismissed questions about
> > the conviction, the Governor then concludes that since Stan will not
> > apologize for crimes he has always denied committing, "there can be no
> > redemption."
> >
> > Even more outrageous, however, is the following passage:
> >
> > "The dedication of Williams' book "Life in Prison" casts significant
> > doubt on his personal redemption. This book was published in 1998,
> > several years after Williams' claimed redemptive experience.
> > Specifically, the book is dedicated to "Nelson Mandela, Angela Davis,
> > Malcolm X, Assata Shakur, Geronimo Ji Jaga Pratt, Ramona Africa, John
> > Africa, Leonard Peltier, Dhoruba Al-Mujahid, George Jackson, Mumia
> > Abu-Jamal, and the countless other men, women, and youths who have to
> > endure the hellish oppression of living behind bars." The mix of
> > individuals on this list is curious. Most have violent pasts and some
> > have been convicted of committing heinous murders, including the killin=
g
> > of law enforcement.
> >
> > But the inclusion of George Jackson on this list defies reason and is a
> > significant indicator that Williams is not reformed and that he still
> > sees violence and lawlessness as a legitimate means to address societal
> > problems."
> >
> >
> > Of those convicted of "committing heinous murders" on this list, two
> > (Geronimo Ji Jaga Pratt and Dhoruba Al-Mujahid) were later found to hav=
e
> > been wrongfully convicted after serving a combined forty-six years
> > behind bars, and four (Assata Shakur, John Africa, Leonard Peltier and
> > Mumia Abu-Jamal) have always proclaimed their innocence and are widely
> > believed to have been framed. George Jackson, who Schwarzenegger
> > apparently regards as the epitome of "violence and lawlessness" was
> > convicted of stealing $71 in 1960 at the age of 18, sentenced to an
> > indeterminate sentence of 1 year to life, became a Black Panther and
> > political leader in prison (which Schwarzenegger equates with forming a
> > gang), charged but never convicted of killing a prison guard, and
> > assassinated by guards in 1971."
> >
> >
> > Who do you suppose is responsible for inciding more violence, Tookie or
> > The Terminator?
> >
> >
> > Evidence Points to Frame-Up in Tookie Williams Case
> > Commentary, Clive Leeman,
> > New America Media, Dec 07, 2005
> >
> > Editor's Note: Focusing on Stanley "Tookie" Williams' good works while
> > on death row misses the inconsistencies, lack of physical evidence and
> > questionable stories spun by informants that ultimately convicted him,
> > says the writer, who calls for a death penalty moratorium.
> >
> > OJAI, Calif.--If Stanley Tookie Williams is executed on Tuesday, Dec.
> > 13, poisoned to death by the State of California, his fame will have
> > doomed him. We may well have killed an innocent man without even
> > realizing it.
> >
> > On the other hand, if Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger grants clemency to
> > Williams because he has rehabilitated himself, his fame will have saved
> > him, and the crucial question of his innocence will simply fade away.
> >
> > At a time when more and more Americans are turning against the death
> > penalty because of increasing evidence that innocent people have been
> > executed, we have allowed ourselves to be so bedazzled by the celebrity
> > hype surrounding the Tookie Williams case that one important truth has
> > been ignored: Stanley Williams may be innocent of the crimes for which
> > he was convicted.
> >
> > Was Williams truly proven "guilty beyond a reasonable doubt"? A careful
> > reading of attorney Verna Wefald's 88-page appeal to the California
> > Supreme Court to reopen Williams' case strongly suggests that Tookie wa=
s
> > framed and railroaded in a trial riddled with inconsistencies,
> > contradictions, lack of physical evidence and false stories spun by a
> > parade of informers trying to save their own necks.
> >
> > As a founder of the Crips gang, Williams was assumed to be guilty befor=
e
> > he was even charged with four murders. He was the Black Man Rampant, th=
e
> > Black Bogeyman, the Bigger Thomas of South Central Los Angeles. William=
s
> > was convicted by his notoriety, not by the evidence.
> >
> > According to Wefald and federal courts that reviewed Williams' case,
> > Williams' 1981 trial for the murder of Albert Owens, a convenience stor=
e
> > clerk in Whittier, and Los Angeles motel owners Yen-I Yang, Tsai-Shaic
> > Yang and their daughter, Yee Chen Lin was based on flimsy circumstantia=
l
> > evidence; the fabricated testimony of five informants having "incentive=
s
> > to lie in order to obtain leniency from the state...." (according to th=
e
> > Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals); and the perjury of at least one police
> > officer.
> >
> > Physical evidence such as fingerprints and a bloody boot-print could no=
t
> > be traced to Williams.
> >
> > Only one shotgun shell was found at the motel. It ostensibly came from =
a
> > shotgun purchased legally five years before by Williams, but the gun
> > itself was actually found under the bed of informants James Garrett and
> > his wife, Ester. The Browning shotgun shell was sold at only two local
> > stores, one of which, a Big Five, had been robbed of guns and ammunitio=
n
> > by Garrett the year before.
> >
> > The Garretts were both being investigated for the murder of their crime
> > partner, Gregory Wilbon. This investigation was dropped, according to
> > Wefald, after they testified that Williams "volunteered" a confession t=
o
> > them.
> >
> > Deputy Gilbert Gwaltney perjured himself when he supported Garrett by
> > testifying that the informant had a sound alibi at the time his crime
> > partner Wilbon was murdered. Wilbon's body was so badly decomposed,
> > Williams' lawyers write, that it was impossible to establish a time of
> > death and thus impossible to establish an alibi.
> >
> > Another informant also claimed that Williams had "volunteered" a
> > confession to him -- but only after a police officer had left the polic=
e
> > file on Williams overnight in the informant's cell for him to read
> > before he testified the next day, according to Wefald.
> >
> > The prosecutor, who had already been censured twice by the California
> > Supreme Court for discriminatory behavior, threw three African-American=
s
> > off the jury, leaving a majority-white jury with few or no blacks (at
> > least one juror's racial identity is in dispute).
> >
> > Wefald's appeal was turned down by the California Supreme Court on Nov.
> > 30 by a 4-2 vote. This is not uncommon, especially in cases which do no=
t
> > involve DNA evidence.
> >
> > Every appeal to the California Supreme Court made by wrongfully
> > convicted prisoner Gloria Killean was routinely denied for 16 years,
> > until a federal court overturned her life sentence. And Thomas Goldstei=
n
> > filed repeated appeals to the court for 24 years before being exonerate=
d
> > by a federal court.
> >
> > And the California Supreme Court's divided vote "indicates the
> > seriousness of the issues that were raised by the motion," Williams'
> > attorney Jonathan Harris said.
> >
> > But the railroading never ceases. The moment the Dec. 13 execution date
> > was announced last month, authorities rushed Williams to the holding
> > cell next to the death chamber, three weeks before the usual holding
> > period begins.
> >
> > Now the ultimate humiliation is being required of Tookie Williams. Like
> > the innocent women at the Salem witch trials, he is being told he shoul=
d
> > confess in order to save his own life, a Catch-22 if ever there was one=
.
> > This he refuses to do. He says he will not compromise his dignity and
> > integrity, the most powerful and precious forces in his life today.
> >
> > One of the most compelling arguments against the death penalty is that
> > we inevitably kill innocent people. Britain abolished capital punishmen=
t
> > in 1965 after Timothy Evans, hanged for strangling his young daughter,
> > was later found to be innocent.
> >
> > Now, new developments like DNA evidence are leading to the release of
> > significant numbers of innocent people from death rows and prisons
> > across the United States, and support for the death penalty is steadily
> > declining.
> >
> > In 2000, the same year that Illinois Governor George Ryan declared a
> > moratorium on executions in his state, a California Field Poll showed
> > that 73 percent of Californians supported a similar moratorium. The
> > number is probably higher today.
> >
> > Instead of spending hours agonizing over Tookie Williams' fate (and his
> > own political future), Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger should do the right
> > thing and suspend the executions of all 637 death row inmates
> > immediately.
> >
> > PNS contributor Clive Leeman lives in Ojai, Calif., and writes about
> > human rights issues.
> >
> >
> >
> > So your picture below is relevant how???
> >
> >
> > On 13 December 2005, Steve Osteen wrote:
> >
> > > **** WARNING GRAPHIC SHIT AHEAD****

>
> One thing I'd like to say to this:
>
> I understand that under some circumstances, the law is wrong when it
> comes to capital punishment. Regardless of whether or not he redeemed
> himself, he was still a bad, bad man.
>
> When you do something, you are to take responsibility for your
> actions. He was a drug dealer, a founding member of the crips, and
> probably did things much worse than the actions he was found guilty
> of, regardless of whether he was actually guilty of those crimes he
> was convicted of or not.
>
> That's like saying that hitler was not guilty of crimes against
> humanity, just because he didn't physically pull the trigger.
>
> Anyhoo, as much as I'd want to think that the guy is innocent of those
> crimes, the thought in the back of my head that he most likely did
> much worse things, and that the organization he started has done
> terrible things, nearly tearing LA apart, makes me really go against
> saving this man's life.
>
> I dunno, maybe I'm just jaded with my outsider views on the whole
> situation. Maybe he was really reformed. No matter what, what's done
> is done, and my life will go on. My life is unaffected by his death.
>
> On 12/13/05, J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:
> > It was pretty sickening to have the governator cite the dedications in
> > Tookie's book as evidence that he hasn't redeemed himself.  Almost all
> > of those cited were people of color.  Here's a snippet from
> > http://www.counterpunch.org/gasper12132005.html
> >
> > "In the days leading up to the execution, new evidence that Stan was
> > framed emerged and was simply ignored. Having dismissed questions about
> > the conviction, the Governor then concludes that since Stan will not
> > apologize for crimes he has always denied committing, "there can be no
> > redemption."
> >
> > Even more outrageous, however, is the following passage:
> >
> > "The dedication of Williams' book "Life in Prison" casts significant
> > doubt on his personal redemption. This book was published in 1998,
> > several years after Williams' claimed redemptive experience.
> > Specifically, the book is dedicated to "Nelson Mandela, Angela Davis,
> > Malcolm X, Assata Shakur, Geronimo Ji Jaga Pratt, Ramona Africa, John
> > Africa, Leonard Peltier, Dhoruba Al-Mujahid, George Jackson, Mumia
> > Abu-Jamal, and the countless other men, women, and youths who have to
> > endure the hellish oppression of living behind bars." The mix of
> > individuals on this list is curious. Most have violent pasts and some
> > have been convicted of committing heinous murders, including the killing
> > of law enforcement.
> >
> > But the inclusion of George Jackson on this list defies reason and is a
> > significant indicator that Williams is not reformed and that he still
> > sees violence and lawlessness as a legitimate means to address societal
> > problems."
> >
> >
> > Of those convicted of "committing heinous murders" on this list, two
> > (Geronimo Ji Jaga Pratt and Dhoruba Al-Mujahid) were later found to have
> > been wrongfully convicted after serving a combined forty-six years
> > behind bars, and four (Assata Shakur, John Africa, Leonard Peltier and
> > Mumia Abu-Jamal) have always proclaimed their innocence and are widely
> > believed to have been framed. George Jackson, who Schwarzenegger
> > apparently regards as the epitome of "violence and lawlessness" was
> > convicted of stealing $71 in 1960 at the age of 18, sentenced to an
> > indeterminate sentence of 1 year to life, became a Black Panther and
> > political leader in prison (which Schwarzenegger equates with forming a
> > gang), charged but never convicted of killing a prison guard, and
> > assassinated by guards in 1971."
> >
> >
> > Who do you suppose is responsible for inciding more violence, Tookie or
> > The Terminator?
> >
> >
> > Evidence Points to Frame-Up in Tookie Williams Case
> > Commentary, Clive Leeman,
> > New America Media, Dec 07, 2005
> >
> > Editor's Note: Focusing on Stanley "Tookie" Williams' good works while
> > on death row misses the inconsistencies, lack of physical evidence and
> > questionable stories spun by informants that ultimately convicted him,
> > says the writer, who calls for a death penalty moratorium.
> >
> > OJAI, Calif.--If Stanley Tookie Williams is executed on Tuesday, Dec.
> > 13, poisoned to death by the State of California, his fame will have
> > doomed him. We may well have killed an innocent man without even
> > realizing it.
> >
> > On the other hand, if Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger grants clemency to
> > Williams because he has rehabilitated himself, his fame will have saved
> > him, and the crucial question of his innocence will simply fade away.
> >
> > At a time when more and more Americans are turning against the death
> > penalty because of increasing evidence that innocent people have been
> > executed, we have allowed ourselves to be so bedazzled by the celebrity
> > hype surrounding the Tookie Williams case that one important truth has
> > been ignored: Stanley Williams may be innocent of the crimes for which
> > he was convicted.
> >
> > Was Williams truly proven "guilty beyond a reasonable doubt"? A careful
> > reading of attorney Verna Wefald's 88-page appeal to the California
> > Supreme Court to reopen Williams' case strongly suggests that Tookie was
> > framed and railroaded in a trial riddled with inconsistencies,
> > contradictions, lack of physical evidence and false stories spun by a
> > parade of informers trying to save their own necks.
> >
> > As a founder of the Crips gang, Williams was assumed to be guilty before
> > he was even charged with four murders. He was the Black Man Rampant, the
> > Black Bogeyman, the Bigger Thomas of South Central Los Angeles. Williams
> > was convicted by his notoriety, not by the evidence.
> >
> > According to Wefald and federal courts that reviewed Williams' case,
> > Williams' 1981 trial for the murder of Albert Owens, a convenience store
> > clerk in Whittier, and Los Angeles motel owners Yen-I Yang, Tsai-Shaic
> > Yang and their daughter, Yee Chen Lin was based on flimsy circumstantial
> > evidence; the fabricated testimony of five informants having "incentives
> > to lie in order to obtain leniency from the state...." (according to the
> > Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals); and the perjury of at least one police
> > officer.
> >
> > Physical evidence such as fingerprints and a bloody boot-print could not
> > be traced to Williams.
> >
> > Only one shotgun shell was found at the motel. It ostensibly came from a
> > shotgun purchased legally five years before by Williams, but the gun
> > itself was actually found under the bed of informants James Garrett and
> > his wife, Ester. The Browning shotgun shell was sold at only two local
> > stores, one of which, a Big Five, had been robbed of guns and ammunition
> > by Garrett the year before.
> >
> > The Garretts were both being investigated for the murder of their crime
> > partner, Gregory Wilbon. This investigation was dropped, according to
> > Wefald, after they testified that Williams "volunteered" a confession to
> > them.
> >
> > Deputy Gilbert Gwaltney perjured himself when he supported Garrett by
> > testifying that the informant had a sound alibi at the time his crime
> > partner Wilbon was murdered. Wilbon's body was so badly decomposed,
> > Williams' lawyers write, that it was impossible to establish a time of
> > death and thus impossible to establish an alibi.
> >
> > Another informant also claimed that Williams had "volunteered" a
> > confession to him -- but only after a police officer had left the police
> > file on Williams overnight in the informant's cell for him to read
> > before he testified the next day, according to Wefald.
> >
> > The prosecutor, who had already been censured twice by the California
> > Supreme Court for discriminatory behavior, threw three African-Americans
> > off the jury, leaving a majority-white jury with few or no blacks (at
> > least one juror's racial identity is in dispute).
> >
> > Wefald's appeal was turned down by the California Supreme Court on Nov.
> > 30 by a 4-2 vote. This is not uncommon, especially in cases which do not
> > involve DNA evidence.
> >
> > Every appeal to the California Supreme Court made by wrongfully
> > convicted prisoner Gloria Killean was routinely denied for 16 years,
> > until a federal court overturned her life sentence. And Thomas Goldstein
> > filed repeated appeals to the court for 24 years before being exonerated
> > by a federal court.
> >
> > And the California Supreme Court's divided vote "indicates the
> > seriousness of the issues that were raised by the motion," Williams'
> > attorney Jonathan Harris said.
> >
> > But the railroading never ceases. The moment the Dec. 13 execution date
> > was announced last month, authorities rushed Williams to the holding
> > cell next to the death chamber, three weeks before the usual holding
> > period begins.
> >
> > Now the ultimate humiliation is being required of Tookie Williams. Like
> > the innocent women at the Salem witch trials, he is being told he should
> > confess in order to save his own life, a Catch-22 if ever there was one.
> > This he refuses to do. He says he will not compromise his dignity and
> > integrity, the most powerful and precious forces in his life today.
> >
> > One of the most compelling arguments against the death penalty is that
> > we inevitably kill innocent people. Britain abolished capital punishment
> > in 1965 after Timothy Evans, hanged for strangling his young daughter,
> > was later found to be innocent.
> >
> > Now, new developments like DNA evidence are leading to the release of
> > significant numbers of innocent people from death rows and prisons
> > across the United States, and support for the death penalty is steadily
> > declining.
> >
> > In 2000, the same year that Illinois Governor George Ryan declared a
> > moratorium on executions in his state, a California Field Poll showed
> > that 73 percent of Californians supported a similar moratorium. The
> > number is probably higher today.
> >
> > Instead of spending hours agonizing over Tookie Williams' fate (and his
> > own political future), Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger should do the right
> > thing and suspend the executions of all 637 death row inmates
> > immediately.
> >
> > PNS contributor Clive Leeman lives in Ojai, Calif., and writes about
> > human rights issues.
> >
> >
> >
> > So your picture below is relevant how???
> >
> >
> > On 13 December 2005, Steve Osteen wrote:
> >
> > > **** WARNING GRAPHIC SHIT AHEAD****
> > >

> > >

Just to play devils advocate here.

Just cause he wrote some childrens books and did all this anti-gang crap
after the fact doesn't necessarily mean he was rehabilitated or turned a
corner.  Maybe...who knows.

But then again can't some just spew forth what is wanted from them just to
get something?  It's like the guy who cheats on his girlfriend or wife and
then says I'm sorry and does anything he can to apologize to her, even
though he's not sorry.  Or like the book smart people who can go into class
read a bunch of information and then regurgitate that info back onto a piec=
e
of paper and get an A.  Does it mean they really know what they're doing?
no...just shows they know how to give what is expected of them.

I'm not saying that he wasn't sorry for what he did or turned himself aroun=
d
or anything, but i'm just saying just cause you do some bad shit and then
some good shit doesn't mean you're not gonna do bad shit again.

If you're not willing to do the time...don't do the crime.  I personally
think it should be eye for an eye.  I bet if we adheared to that rule a lot
more, there'd be less crime (I could be wrong, only way to know is to try
it)  You shoot someone in the face with a shotgun...you get shot in the fac=
e
with a shotgun.  I also think lethal injection is the pussy man's death
sentence.  If you're being put to death for violent crimes you should feel
serious pain and remorse before you die.  Put em in the gas chamber, they
get a few minutes to choke to death and die painfully to think about what
they did.  What good will it do them after they die?  Or what good will it
do to society after they die?  None...but if our going to rape and beat a
girl to death or something, then you should die a nice painful death.  Mayb=
e
if this whole reencarnation thing is true, they'll remember that in their
next life.

However as the Bloodhound Gang has told us, if you got the crime, we got th=
e
time.

--
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

> the
> coin.
>
> Not a diss on you man - but very few people actually take any REAL time
> even
> ATTEMPTING to think of the environment folks like that come out of. Can
> they
> rise above that? YES. But some (like in Tookie's case) may not get that
> chance til after they've already made a serious mistake. Does that make
> them
> any less worthy of of life? I mean - the guy has obviously turned a corne=
r
> and found ways to give back to the community he helped damage. That shows
> remorse on many levels. Correct me if I'm wrong, but prison is SUPPOSED t=
o
> rehabilitate, not be a holding pen for people on the way to the slaughter=
.
>
> When you reduce people's lives to nothing more than cattle in a
> slaughterhouse, you are playing god.
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "John Dee" <antitux@gmail.com>
