Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Attn EDM-based artists of all types

This goes out to all of you who are involved in this "scene" of ours in one
way or another...

I've recently added new section to the newsletter, a monthly spotlight
featuring various artists associated with dance culture. This includes DJs,
producers, designers, writers and even dancers who feel they offer a unique
perspective - basically I'm down to feature anyone who feels they have some
creative offering that revolves around the dance community.

What I provide.

4 week full-page spotlight in D'Fly News. (Bio, featured work, pics, etc)
I offer to host the material during the feature period (music, photos,
writings, etc). Unfortunately, streaming video is too large for me to host
through my own server, but if you are a visual artist and have video online
then I can push the link instead.

Most of all you get lots of free, wide-spread expsosure (well over 3000
heads now, globally).

Interested?

If so, then drop me a line at feature@djdragnfly.com and tell me what your
all about.  I've broken down what I'd need from those wanting to submit
material for consideration. 

DJs - 60 continuous mix. Mix should be clean (no trainwrecks please) in the
form of a CD or high quality mp3.

Producers - at least one original track that is audience-ready in the form
of a CD or mp3.

Designers (clothing, flyer design, event decoration) - got a portfolio
showcasing what you've done to create those unforgettable environments? Send
me a sample of pics or a link where I might find some of your work.

Dancers - Liquid, breaks, poi, glowsticking. anything goes... Have a source
of streaming video featuring your abilities? Again I can't provide hosting
for video, but if you have streaming video up already, then I can include a
link to that if you're featured.

Writers - people have inspired to write some great stuff as a result of a
great party. Have something you'd like to share? I'd like to hear it and
pass on your stories.

Well that's about it.

If you're looking for an example of what a feature looks like, then the last
page I had dedicated to GAMMA. http://www.djdragnfly.com/feature/GAMMA/ 

If you have any questions just shoot me an email or through myspace at:
http://www.myspace.com/dragnfly


; )
dina
http://www.djdragnfly.com







---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] paging dj darwyn

Er..  Yes, FC playing at OW is a semi-annual occurance sometimes..  The reason for that is he always rocks the party, brings a lot of vibe, and is a long-term favorite of much of the bay area's most clued-in dancers.
 
 Motherfucker is somehow able to do this garganuan live set running Ableton Live with a pretty decent number of tracks on an age-old iBook- that's magic, in my book (Macs don't run Live well).
 
 ..and SCO is a legend!  (for good reason)
 
 Who would you rather see?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] *BSP* New Years Eve 2006 @ OtherWorld

> I'm just wondering if this party will be accessible
> by BART/shuttles like it was last year.

yup!  we'll have at least 3 shuttles running all night
from a parking lot next to the 19'th street bart. 
this parking lot will also have security all night.  
so we ask everybody to take the shuttles and not drive
to the venue.  at the last event we had a lot of cars
broken into and we'd hate to see that happen again.  
also it helps the venue not to have a ton of people
and cars out front. 
   
anyways we're doing everything we can to make this
event as safe as possible, so please work with us and
take the shuttles even if you know how to get to
OtherWorld.
the shuttle parking lot is only 1 mile from
OtherWorld, so it's just a couple minutes drive and
there should be little wait if any. 

more info coming on that.  check the website for
updates... 
                                           thanks, Mike

Daniel Bell was outstanding, the dancefloor was packed (and
bouncing!), and we all had a blast!  Special thanks to those that
traveled many miles (New York, Boston, Seattle, Eureka, Los Angeles,
Vanuatu, etc!) to be there with us.

THANK YOU ALL FOR AN AMAZING 2005!!!

you a New Year's Eve soiree you won't want to miss!

On Tue, 20 Dec 2005, Dragn'fly wrote:

-&e->This goes out to all of you who are involved in this "scene" of ours in one
-&e->way or another...
-&e->
-&e->I've recently added new section to the newsletter, a monthly spotlight
-&e->featuring various artists associated with dance culture. This includes DJs,
-&e->producers, designers, writers and even dancers who feel they offer a unique
-&e->perspective - basically I'm down to feature anyone who feels they have some
-&e->creative offering that revolves around the dance community.
-&e->
-&e->What I provide.
-&e->
-&e->4 week full-page spotlight in D'Fly News. (Bio, featured work, pics, etc)
-&e->I offer to host the material during the feature period (music, photos,
-&e->writings, etc). Unfortunately, streaming video is too large for me to host
-&e->through my own server, but if you are a visual artist and have video online
-&e->then I can push the link instead.
-&e->
-&e->Most of all you get lots of free, wide-spread expsosure (well over 3000
-&e->heads now, globally).
-&e->
-&e->Interested?
-&e->
-&e->If so, then drop me a line at feature@djdragnfly.com and tell me what your
-&e->all about.  I've broken down what I'd need from those wanting to submit
-&e->material for consideration. 
-&e->
-&e->DJs - 60 continuous mix. Mix should be clean (no trainwrecks please) in the
-&e->form of a CD or high quality mp3.
-&e->
-&e->Producers - at least one original track that is audience-ready in the form
-&e->of a CD or mp3.
-&e->
-&e->Designers (clothing, flyer design, event decoration) - got a portfolio
-&e->showcasing what you've done to create those unforgettable environments? Send
-&e->me a sample of pics or a link where I might find some of your work.
-&e->
-&e->Dancers - Liquid, breaks, poi, glowsticking. anything goes... Have a source
-&e->of streaming video featuring your abilities? Again I can't provide hosting
-&e->for video, but if you have streaming video up already, then I can include a
-&e->link to that if you're featured.
-&e->
-&e->Writers - people have inspired to write some great stuff as a result of a
-&e->great party. Have something you'd like to share? I'd like to hear it and
-&e->pass on your stories.
-&e->
-&e->Well that's about it.
-&e->
-&e->If you're looking for an example of what a feature looks like, then the last
-&e->page I had dedicated to GAMMA. http://www.djdragnfly.com/feature/GAMMA/ 
-&e->

On Tue, 20 Dec 2005, Dragn'fly wrote:

-&e->This goes out to all of you who are involved in this "scene" of ours in
one
-&e->way or another...
-&e->
-&e->I've recently added new section to the newsletter, a monthly spotlight
-&e->featuring various artists associated with dance culture. This includes
DJs,
-&e->producers, designers, writers and even dancers who feel they offer a
unique
-&e->perspective - basically I'm down to feature anyone who feels they have
some
-&e->creative offering that revolves around the dance community.
-&e->
-&e->What I provide.
-&e->
-&e->4 week full-page spotlight in D'Fly News. (Bio, featured work, pics,
etc)
-&e->I offer to host the material during the feature period (music, photos,
-&e->writings, etc). Unfortunately, streaming video is too large for me to
host
-&e->through my own server, but if you are a visual artist and have video
online
-&e->then I can push the link instead.
-&e->
-&e->Most of all you get lots of free, wide-spread expsosure (well over 3000
-&e->heads now, globally).
-&e->
-&e->Interested?
-&e->
-&e->If so, then drop me a line at feature@djdragnfly.com and tell me what
your
-&e->all about.  I've broken down what I'd need from those wanting to submit
-&e->material for consideration. 
-&e->
-&e->DJs - 60 continuous mix. Mix should be clean (no trainwrecks please) in
the
-&e->form of a CD or high quality mp3.
-&e->
-&e->Producers - at least one original track that is audience-ready in the
form
-&e->of a CD or mp3.
-&e->
-&e->Designers (clothing, flyer design, event decoration) - got a portfolio
-&e->showcasing what you've done to create those unforgettable environments?
Send
-&e->me a sample of pics or a link where I might find some of your work.
-&e->
-&e->Dancers - Liquid, breaks, poi, glowsticking. anything goes... Have a
source
-&e->of streaming video featuring your abilities? Again I can't provide
hosting
-&e->for video, but if you have streaming video up already, then I can
include a
-&e->link to that if you're featured.
-&e->
-&e->Writers - people have inspired to write some great stuff as a result of
a
-&e->great party. Have something you'd like to share? I'd like to hear it
and
-&e->pass on your stories.
-&e->
-&e->Well that's about it.
-&e->
-&e->If you're looking for an example of what a feature looks like, then the
last
-&e->page I had dedicated to GAMMA. http://www.djdragnfly.com/feature/GAMMA/

-&e->
-&e->If you have any questions just shoot me an email or through myspace at:
-&e->http://www.myspace.com/dragnfly
-&e->
-&e->
-&e->; )
-&e->dina
-&e->http://www.djdragnfly.com

>-&e->4 week full-page spotlight in D'Fly News. (Bio, featured work, pics,
>etc)
>-&e->I offer to host the material during the feature period (music, photos,
>-&e->writings, etc). Unfortunately, streaming video is too large for me to
>host
>-&e->through my own server, but if you are a visual artist and have video
>online
>-&e->then I can push the link instead.
>-&e->
>-&e->Most of all you get lots of free, wide-spread expsosure (well over 3000
>-&e->heads now, globally).
>-&e->
>-&e->Interested?
>-&e->
>-&e->If so, then drop me a line at feature@djdragnfly.com and tell me what
>your
>-&e->all about.  I've broken down what I'd need from those wanting to submit
>-&e->material for consideration.
>-&e->
>-&e->DJs - 60 continuous mix. Mix should be clean (no trainwrecks please) in
>the
>-&e->form of a CD or high quality mp3.
>-&e->
>-&e->Producers - at least one original track that is audience-ready in the
>form
>-&e->of a CD or mp3.
>-&e->
>-&e->Designers (clothing, flyer design, event decoration) - got a portfolio
>-&e->showcasing what you've done to create those unforgettable environments?
>Send
>-&e->me a sample of pics or a link where I might find some of your work.
>-&e->
>-&e->Dancers - Liquid, breaks, poi, glowsticking. anything goes... Have a
>source
>-&e->of streaming video featuring your abilities? Again I can't provide
>hosting
>-&e->for video, but if you have streaming video up already, then I can
>include a
>-&e->link to that if you're featured.

>-&e->Writers - people have inspired to write some great stuff as a result of
>a
>-&e->great party. Have something you'd like to share? I'd like to hear it
>and
>-&e->pass on your stories.

>-&e->

Subject: [sfraves] Partygoers consider rave class action suit

--=====================_30014421==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Partygoers consider rave class action suit

Alan Choate DAILY HERALD

Legal proceedings against Utah County officials over two law enforcement raids on large raves this summer could expand to include allegations that officials violated the rights of all the people who attended the parties.

"We're considering filing a separate lawsuit for the people in attendance," said Brian Barnard, a Salt Lake City attorney who is representing the plaintiffs <http://adserver.harktheherald.com/adclick.php?n=a1d19a67>
[]
 in the case.

The organizers of the raves, which took place July 16 and Aug. 20 in Spanish Fork Canyon, and the owners of the property where they occurred already have filed suit in federal court, alleging the Utah County sheriff's officers went too far when they shut down the rave and forced everyone off the property. 

"The current lawsuit is on behalf of the landowner and the promoters," Barnard said. "It essentially asks the sheriff to leave them alone."

As for the attendees -- about 350 at the first event, and 1,000 at the second -- "most of them are law-abiding citizens who paid money to see a concert and got scared out of their wits and chased away by SWAT officers," said Barnard.

"An ordinary citizen has the right to be left alone."

In court filings, Utah County has said that the events weren't properly permitted and that law enforcement officers witnessed "rampant" drug use, which prompted them to shut down the raves.

The filings also contend that the actions of law enforcement did not violate anyone's rights and were reasonable given 
the situation. 

Named in the pending lawsuit are Utah County, Sheriff James Tracy, Lt. Grant Ferre, county attorney Kay Bryson, and county commissioners Jerry Grover, Larry Ellertson and Steve White.

Attorney Peter Stirba, who is representing Utah County, could not be reached for comment Tuesday.

The plaintiffs have set up a Web site, www.utahconcertraids.com, for people to report their experiences at the events.

The new suit, if filed, would be a class action seeking monetary damages for the attendees. A class action allows a court to address the claims of a large group of people without the need for hundreds of individual lawsuits.

"The class action is for everyone who was there at the show," said Brandon Fullmer of Uprok Records, one of the promoters of the events. "Their rights were violated. ... Especially the ones who got harmed, and there were quite a few of them.

"You go to a show, you don't expect to be there for a half hour and then get shut down because of what 'they' wanted to do -- because 'they' don't think it's right."

Barnard said officers could have dealt with any illegal activity less intrusively.

"You punish the people who are doing something wrong," he said. "You don't throw out a dragnet and go after everybody who was there."

Alan Choate can be reached at 344-2556 or alanchoate@heraldextra.com.
This story appeared in The Daily Herald on page A1. 

http://www.newutah.com/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=71527



MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 06:27:13 -0800 (PST)
From: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Are you symmetrical?

A study of Jamaican teenagers done at Rutgers finds that people who are more symmetrical are judged to be better dancers, "The new study involved 183 Jamaican teenagers, ranging between 14-19 years old, who danced while their movements were captured using motion-capture cameras similar to those used in video games and movies to give computer-generated characters fluid movements.  Women watching the recordings preferred the dances of men who were more symmetrical, while men were more impressed by the dances of more symmetric females."
 
 I'll also note this little tidbit, "While most people don't go around measuring and comparing body parts of potential mates, it's thought that we pick up on these cues subconsciously. The idea that there is an association between body symmetry and health comes from various animal and human studies. Peahens and barn swallows prefer males with more symmetrical tails. One study found that women experience more orgasms during sex with male partners whose features are more symmetrical, regardless of the level of romantic attachment or the sexual experience of the guy."
 
 http://news.yahoo.com/s/space/20051221/sc_space/symmetricalpeoplemakebetterdancers

Herbal is one of my favorite clubs ever..  Super tasteful yet unpretentously beautiful little downbeat lounge upstairs, great views, cheap booze..  Go down the stairs a bit and you can duck into a really wonderful big room, great sound, beautiful vibe.  The people there have been some of the best crowds I've ever hung with after stumbling out of a club at 4:30am.
 
 Fuck I miss London.  (someday I'll live in Shoreditch, I tells ya)

Message-ID: <20051223062500.29621.qmail@web81410.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 22:25:00 -0800 (PST)
From: boomerang <petersandifer@sbcglobal.net>
Reply-To: petersandifer@sbcglobal.net
To: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] "It's All Gone Pete Tong"    (DVD review)

In this mockumentary fable set in the dance scene, a pathetically arrogant (yet loveable) Ibiza
superstar blows out his brain on drugs and liquor, and his eardums on the music.

Gone completely deaf, our hero battles his manager,  the industry,  groupies (including his wife),
and the dancers that become demons when he can no longer mix for shit.  

In some of the film's funniest moments of idiocy , it's hard to tell if our superstar
vinyl-slinger is deaf or stupid, or both.

In the saddest, he describes the familiar passion that lead to his broken eardrums:  "I love them
both:  DJing, and hearing."

In terms of film production, there are many aesthetically-pleasing moments of audio-visual play
centered around deafness and hearing; at the same time toying with our concept of  "feeling"  or
"seeing" the music.   And aof course, it wouldn't be a rave movie without a double-meaning in the
theme of becoming isolated in madness from overconsumption of the scene.

It's not an award winner, but it should be a decent semi-cult, semi-classic when we are all
shouting at each other like 90 year old war veterans.

I'ver never heard of this movie until last week.  And no, this is not a film about Pete Tong.  The
title refers to an expression from British rhyming slang.  

But there are cameos by superstars like Tiesto (the techno antichrist), Whathisname Van Dyke and a
bunch of other industry stars who thankfully I have never heard of but apparantly play their own
real badass selves.  Available on DVD.

peace,
boomerang








.  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  . 
MP3s, Writing and Funny jpegs:
http://briefcase.yahoo.com/petersandifer@sbcglobal.net
.  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .

--- boomerang <petersandifer@sbcglobal.net> wrote:

> In this mockumentary fable set in the dance scene, a pathetically arrogant (yet loveable) Ibiza
> superstar blows out his brain on drugs and liquor, and his eardums on the music.
> 
> Gone completely deaf, our hero battles his manager,  the industry,  groupies (including his
> wife),
> and the dancers that become demons when he can no longer mix for shit.  
> 
> In some of the film's funniest moments of idiocy , it's hard to tell if our superstar
> vinyl-slinger is deaf or stupid, or both.
> 
> In the saddest, he describes the familiar passion that lead to his broken eardrums:  "I love
> them
> both:  DJing, and hearing."
> 
> In terms of film production, there are many aesthetically-pleasing moments of audio-visual play
> centered around deafness and hearing; at the same time toying with our concept of  "feeling"  or
> "seeing" the music.   And aof course, it wouldn't be a rave movie without a double-meaning in
> the
> theme of becoming isolated in madness from overconsumption of the scene.
> 
> It's not an award winner, but it should be a decent semi-cult, semi-classic when we are all
> shouting at each other like 90 year old war veterans.
> 
> I'ver never heard of this movie until last week.  And no, this is not a film about Pete Tong. 
> The
> title refers to an expression from British rhyming slang.  
> 
> But there are cameos by superstars like Tiesto (the techno antichrist), Whathisname Van Dyke and
> a
> bunch of other industry stars who thankfully I have never heard of but apparantly play their own
> real badass selves.  Available on DVD.

PS: by the way, this is fucking cool -- http://www.pandora.com -- it even
knows who John Tejada is (I'm listing to "John Tejada" radio, which is basically
a playlist of songs it things are like John Tejada). Sometimes it's actually 
dead-on. For example the Lawnchair Generals can be Tejada-like & in-fact it 
suggested a L.G. track I often play alongside a Tejada track... kinda cool that 
it thinks like I do ... this could be a useful DJ tool ... if you need hints on 
songs that might mix well with a given track or artist currently playing.
(It would be cool if this was a plugin into Reaktor or Traktor 3.0 :-))

From: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
Reply-To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Something to keep in mind

There are scores of hangover cures advertised on the internet, from Dr Ralph's Monday Medicine to Nux Vomica, a homoeopathic remedy that claims to do just what it says on the tin. But few if any of them work, researchers say.
 
                                                  The authors of a study in the British Medical Journal said: "No compelling evidence exists to suggest that any complementary or conventional intervention is effective for treating or preventing alcohol hangover."
 
 
  Taking a couple of paracetamols and a pint of water before bed is too simple for most seeking relief from a night's hard drinking. Bananas, barley grass, cabbage, charcoal tablets, eggs, exercise, green tea, hair of the dog (more alcohol), kidney dialysis, milkshake and Vegemite on toast are among recommended remedies.
 
 
  A search of the medical literature revealed 15 trials of hangover cures, from the blood pressure drug propanolol to a herbal treatment containing extract of artichoke. Most of the trials, which tested eight agents in all, showed no beneficial effect. However, the researchers, led by Edzard Ernst, professor of complementary medicine at the University of Exeter, found encouraging results for borage, a herbal remedy with anti-inflammatory properties, a product based on dried yeast called Morning Fit and tolfenamic acid, a painkiller. Professor Ernst said a major problem preventing development of an effective cure for hangovers was the lack of information about the effect of alcohol on the body.
  "We don't understand the mechanism of what a hangover is. We know it has to do with the toxic effects of alcohol and dehydration but we don't know how it works."
 
 
 
 http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/health_medical/article334813.ece

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "boomerang" <petersandifer@sbcglobal.net>
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 10:25 PM
Subject: [sfraves] "It's All Gone Pete Tong" (DVD review)


> In this mockumentary fable set in the dance scene, a pathetically arrogant 
> (yet loveable) Ibiza
> superstar blows out his brain on drugs and liquor, and his eardums on the 
> music.
>
> Gone completely deaf, our hero battles his manager,  the industry, 
> groupies (including his wife),
> and the dancers that become demons when he can no longer mix for shit.
>
> In some of the film's funniest moments of idiocy , it's hard to tell if 
> our superstar
> vinyl-slinger is deaf or stupid, or both.
>
> In the saddest, he describes the familiar passion that lead to his broken 
> eardrums:  "I love them
> both:  DJing, and hearing."
>
> In terms of film production, there are many aesthetically-pleasing moments 
> of audio-visual play
> centered around deafness and hearing; at the same time toying with our 
> concept of  "feeling"  or
> "seeing" the music.   And aof course, it wouldn't be a rave movie without 
> a double-meaning in the
> theme of becoming isolated in madness from overconsumption of the scene.
>
> It's not an award winner, but it should be a decent semi-cult, 
> semi-classic when we are all
> shouting at each other like 90 year old war veterans.
>
> I'ver never heard of this movie until last week.  And no, this is not a 
> film about Pete Tong.  The
> title refers to an expression from British rhyming slang.
>
> But there are cameos by superstars like Tiesto (the techno antichrist), 
> Whathisname Van Dyke and a
> bunch of other industry stars who thankfully I have never heard of but 
> apparantly play their own
> real badass selves.  Available on DVD.
>
> peace,
> boomerang
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: The Surface of the Sun

"The composition and  mechanical inner workings of the sun beneath the visible photosphere have  remained an enigma for thousands of years.   There are a whole host of  unexplainable phenomena related to the sun's activities that still baffle gas  model theorists to this  day because they  fail to recognize the existence of an iron alloy  transitional layer that rests beneath the visible photosphere.  Fortunately  a host of new satellites and the field of  heliosiesmology are starting to shed light on this mysterious  transitional layer of the sun that is located about 4800km beneath the visible  photosphere.  In addition, studies of solar wind suggest that  solar wind also originates on the same transition layer under the photosphere.   NASA's SOHO satellite and the Trace satellite program have both imaged this  transition layer of the sun that sits beneath the  photosphere.  These 21st century satellites and  technologies now enable us to peer behind the outer plasma layers of the  chromosphere and photosphere and  allow us to study the rocky, calcium ferrite transitional layer with incredible  precision."
 
 http://www.thesurfaceofthesun.com/

edge, for those of you who dig on that...gonna be a
rockin weekend!

Some of the money that was donated ended up getting pocketed by the people at the gate too.  It was all very chaotic and I personally saw one person pocket the money I had handed her.  I decided not to make a big deal out of it at the time, but I am pretty certain I wasn't the only person this happened to.
 
 Next year that entry gate needs to managed better if you guys want to keep this thing going...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Roll Call


Tequila actually tastes better as it gets shittier.  Like, Jose Cuervo 
Gold > 1800 > Patron.  Patron sucks, I think it's actually an elaborate 
scam.  Herradura + Tres Generaciones + and that crap Sammy Hagar makes are 
good, but in general, like, cheap tequila is tastier and less likely to 
taste like a sour ashtray.  Tequila should ideally be drunk when already 
shitfaced, have nowhere to be for like 5 days, are with your coworkers, 
and forced down your throat in large quanities, and then head shaken by 
crazy people blowing whistles while your new best friends all cheer and 
laugh knowing you're gonna puke soon.  A lot.  But only if God is merciful 
and doesn't let your body keep doing things while your brain is on 
[f|s]iesta.  In fact, it should be a tagline...

Cheap Tequila is Just Better - 1,000,000 unplanned pregnancies after three 
day weekends in Tijuana/Mexicali/Rosarita Beach/Ensenada can't be wrong.

andyw

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scratching on a Xone 62

As much as those mutherfuckers cost - it better be!!!

Oddly enough, I checked out some shitty looking American Audio mixer the 
other day at a friend's house. It looked like the atypical bargain mixer. 
But holy fuck - everything about it sounded great, felt great, the faders 
had the most bitching curve adjustment, etc.

I was so blown away I am honestly considering selling my mixer to get 
one...for $200 - it makes Pioneer look like a Gemini kit mixer. No shit.

------=_Part_6025_7594653.1135818849813
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Hmmmm....NYE and a Xone:62 mixer you must be playing on the SWATSound
System...hahaha, that silly Marshallllllll.

No you can't really scratch on the Xone:62.  It has a very smooth curve on
the x-fader.  I don't know if you ever met or seen my friend/former roommat=
e
scratch.  He's very good, Bad Boy Bill-ish good, and he could barely scratc=
h
on that mixer.  The problem is you have to flick the fader so far over just
to get enough of the sound to come through that a lot of the times
you basically cut all the way across.  If you're really damn good you can d=
o
some fairly basic scratching, but nothing fancy like triplets or crabbing o=
r
anything like that.  It's purely a studio/trance mixer....nice and smooth
from side to side.

Also, make sure you dont accidentally hit the x-fader button or it gets eve=
n
worse, as you move the x-fader across the side your playing will get quiete=
r
as you get closer to the middle rather then staying the same volume until
you get to the middle.  There have been times we've listened to some DJ and
for some reason the mixes were sounding funny, the music would get quieter
and then louder and back n forth during the mixes and we'd walk up and sure
enough they hit the x-fader button thinking it would make it a shaper cut,
which it doesnt.

Oh and one last thing....use the pretty blue lights sparingly.  The PCF
curve tweak knobby thingies get annoying real quick.  Specially when someon=
e
doesn't know how to use em and have the knob turned the wrong way and they
think they're gonna do something cool and in fact it does the exact opposit=
e
of what they wanted to do.  Oh and beware of fader flicking on the x-fader
and the lateral faders as the knobs like to fly off at high speeds.

Other then that it's a pretty solid mixer.  it's held up to lost of parties
and still works like a charm.  I wouldnt buy one for myself as it's cost to
feature aspects are severelly out of proportion, but it's a solid mixer non=
e
the less.
--
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

The fader is nice. I think it's the same thing I have in my Rane. I'm 
sure it has a curve too. Although I think it's the kind you'll find on a 
Pioneer DJM600. Not a dial you can adjust any way you like. I think it's 
a switch with three curve options. Fast, slow, and somewhere in between.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Chester Copperpot" <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
To: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
Cc: "SFR" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, December 28, 2005 5:14 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] scratching on a Xone 62


Hmmmm....NYE and a Xone:62 mixer you must be playing on the SWATSound
System...hahaha, that silly Marshallllllll.

No you can't really scratch on the Xone:62.  It has a very smooth curve on
the x-fader.  I don't know if you ever met or seen my friend/former roommate
scratch.  He's very good, Bad Boy Bill-ish good, and he could barely scratch
on that mixer.  The problem is you have to flick the fader so far over just
to get enough of the sound to come through that a lot of the times
you basically cut all the way across.  If you're really damn good you can do
some fairly basic scratching, but nothing fancy like triplets or crabbing or
anything like that.  It's purely a studio/trance mixer....nice and smooth
from side to side.

Also, make sure you dont accidentally hit the x-fader button or it gets even
worse, as you move the x-fader across the side your playing will get quieter
as you get closer to the middle rather then staying the same volume until
you get to the middle.  There have been times we've listened to some DJ and
for some reason the mixes were sounding funny, the music would get quieter
and then louder and back n forth during the mixes and we'd walk up and sure
enough they hit the x-fader button thinking it would make it a shaper cut,
which it doesnt.

Oh and one last thing....use the pretty blue lights sparingly.  The PCF
curve tweak knobby thingies get annoying real quick.  Specially when someone
doesn't know how to use em and have the knob turned the wrong way and they
think they're gonna do something cool and in fact it does the exact opposite
of what they wanted to do.  Oh and beware of fader flicking on the x-fader
and the lateral faders as the knobs like to fly off at high speeds.

Other then that it's a pretty solid mixer.  it's held up to lost of parties
and still works like a charm.  I wouldnt buy one for myself as it's cost to
feature aspects are severelly out of proportion, but it's a solid mixer none
the less.
--
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

wow, i can't believe you're actually good for something!

so i checked the AH site and you're right.  the crossfader adjust has
two settings:  cut and dip.

and as Gavin said...that crossfader can either have the standard fader
cap or that annoying wide and flat cap that you see on some volume
faders.

Message-ID: <4111.24.7.99.229.1135827141.squirrel@secure.saturn5.com>

From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Monday Night/ Tuesday Monrning Adventure

So I got this job on like Sunday night... & started Monday morning... the
boss/ owner/ CEO dude picked me up in his car, bought me coffee that
morning.. Mind u, this job's in Campbell in the South Bay & yes.. we
discussed my commute & all that prior, so it was all good.. but the whole
picking me up my 1st day kinda threw me off, ya know?

Anywaze.. work day came, went, la la la... the CEO dude was away in
meetings all day, gets back, the 1st thing he asked me when he got in (no
lie), "So how you getting home tonight?"

I mean.. i understand that i shouldn't assume that just cause some1 picks
me up, that don't mean they wren't gonna take me back home... but usually
they tell me right away that they can't & I usually make my way.. but
yeah...

He drops me off @ the Cal Train Station around 7:30PM... I wait 4 like 2
hours... OK.. i know i'm lame 4 this.. but i didn't have the CEO's cell #
on me.. i kinda left it on my comp @ home... & well. i didn't have any of
any1's like phone #'s who live in the Southbay... I mean.. i didn't think
I was gonna need more than like well.. I dunno... but well.. i just didn't
think of preparing myself w/ anything extra that what i already had w/
me... well.. i guess it would be a good idea to bring around an address/
phone # book w// me in my bag...

So after several attempts of calling people & my parents, I was like fuck
it.. then i saw that strip mall across the street & decided that i should
go there where it's well lit & not stay out in the dark where the station
was... as soon as i got 2 the strip mall, this homeless dude asked me if I
had 50 cents so he could make a phone call... I told him i had 50 cents,
but i needed it 2 make a call.. then he gave me this long ass story about
like how he had to talk to his ex girlfriend's cousin about goin' 2 her
house to talk 2 his ex about his Mom who was is a coma.. well.. I dunno
man.. i was like thinkin' & kinda sympathized & i had some cas i could
easliy change, so I gave it 2 him... he used the phone, called, then we
talked somemore.. i told him my whole missing Cal Train thing & how my new
boss la la la... then i asked him if i can like kick it w/ him & he said
yeah... so we just hung out!

So we end3d up going 2 his ex girlfriends cousins pad arund the corner
from the strip mall... soh yeah.. this guys name is Jack.. the ex-gf's
cousin, her name is Jessica, so she meets us outside, calls her cousin,
Jack's ex-gf, & they talk on the phone for like 1/2 hour... he cries &
laugh.. this whole time, I talk w/ Jessica, pick well.. what i thought
were really deformed awesomely huge lemons off a tree, & well. talk 2
Jessica more!  Then the 3 of us chiull in her car for a while talking...
they asked me about my life, they told me about theirs...

Jack suggested we go kick it down town if i got hella hours 2 wait 4 Cal
Train 2 open up again & he needed 2 go down there anyway.. so we walk over
a mile to the lightrail station...

OK... so for the next several hours, we visit some of his friends, go to
like the 24/7 resturaunts donw there 2 talk 2 people (& there really isn't
much), we went 2 these abandoned houses & kick it there, hide from cops, I
mean, it was a fun fuckin' time & I was pretty safe 'cause Jack made sure
i waws OK the whole time!  By the time like 9 PM hit, we went
WinerSnicitchel on ummm... 1st i think & just say down & talked somemore
b4 I went my way & he went his...

By 9:30 i was on Lightrail & started the whole commute thing... I got back
2 Hercules around 2 seomthing, almost 3PM... LoL.. but it was the best
fuckin' time I've had in a long time!  LOL!  YAY!  OK.. just thought i'd
share!

---OK.. u don't have 2 read this... I"m just venting now, but Hello
2Day!!! ----

Oh yeah.. so anywaze, this new job thing... I didn't get fired, but my
employment is frozen w/ the company.. reason being that when me & the CEO
dude spoke on Sunday night, I told him the soonest i'd be able to make it
out was during the latter part of the week, like Wed-Friday to start
training.. but he insisted I come out on Monday for training, but we
agreed that I couldn't come in on Tuesday so i could do a day of homework
& come back in on Wed... well.. when he called me on Tuesday evening, i
told him the whole story about Cal Train & la la la.. OK.. he got pissed @
me.. he told me I wasn't using my common sense, he said i was very
irresponsible, he told me I used poor judgements on my decisions in
handling being stranded, he said my family was lame & worthless if they
weren't even gonna come & pick me up like ummm, 80 plus miles away from
Hercules (I did call my house like 3 times from the pay phone 2 try 2 tell
my Mom what happen w/ Cal Train), & he called me stupid basically... but
honestly.. everything he accused me of not doing, i did or i tried, well
granted, I didn't have anyone's phone #s of the South bay people...

But i thought he would understand that my school stuff is important 2 me &
i do need time 2 do this stuff 4 my school, ya know?  I mean, it'snot my
fault he was a high school drop out & never looked back & doesn't
understand those of us going back 2 school 2 get degrees & shit... & I
wanted 2 help himn out as  afavor 'cause he is always streesssed about not
having enough help & all this shit...

But when things went the way they did & I did have alot of failed attempts
@ like tryin' 2 cover my ass 4 being stranded... I mean.. I did what i
usually do when i'm stuck & just roll with a train of thought & survive
somehow 'cause I alwasy seem 2 get in these situations.. no biggie 4 me...
but apparetnly the CEO dude had a problem w/ that.. so i dunno... although
my employment w/ his company is on hold rightnow.. I'm not sure i wanna go
back actaully... I mean... this CEO dude is so fucki'n self centered that
he thinks he always right!  He excpeted me to be on his frame of
mentallity throughtout this whole ordeal or atleast be prepared 4 it... I
mean... I do what i can when I situation calls for it & it's usually just
liike whatever i can find what to do, ya know???  It kinda hurt when he
was putting me down 4 my sttempts @ atleast being safe the whole 13 hours
I was kinda going along w/ the flow.. many people who have hung out w/ me
on the weekends know about this!  LOL

So yeah... my 1st day w/ that company is sadly my last!  I mean.. it was
set up so that I would stay in the Southbay like 3-4 nights outta the week
'cause he set up an apartment for me 2 stay in & shit.. but I dunno... i'm
gonan look for a different gig now i guess.. LoL.. Hello2Day! Wow!

I guess lesson learned.. HELLO 2DAY, bring in a list of phone#'s of every1
I know just I"m stuck in your part of the world :)

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
To: "Chester Copperpot" <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
Cc: "SFR" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, December 28, 2005 5:23 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] scratching on a Xone 62


wow, i can't believe you're actually good for something!

so i checked the AH site and you're right.  the crossfader adjust has
two settings:  cut and dip.

and as Gavin said...that crossfader can either have the standard fader
cap or that annoying wide and flat cap that you see on some volume
faders.



On 12/28/05, Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hmmmm....NYE and a Xone:62 mixer you must be playing on the SWATSound
> System...hahaha, that silly Marshallllllll.
>
> No you can't really scratch on the Xone:62.  It has a very smooth curve on
> the x-fader.  I don't know if you ever met or seen my friend/former
roommate
> scratch.  He's very good, Bad Boy Bill-ish good, and he could barely
scratch
> on that mixer.  The problem is you have to flick the fader so far over
just
> to get enough of the sound to come through that a lot of the times you
> basically cut all the way across.  If you're really damn good you can do
> some fairly basic scratching, but nothing fancy like triplets or crabbing
or
> anything like that.  It's purely a studio/trance mixer....nice and smooth
> from side to side.
>
> Also, make sure you dont accidentally hit the x-fader button or it gets
even
> worse, as you move the x-fader across the side your playing will get
quieter
> as you get closer to the middle rather then staying the same volume until
> you get to the middle.  There have been times we've listened to some DJ
and
> for some reason the mixes were sounding funny, the music would get quieter
> and then louder and back n forth during the mixes and we'd walk up and
sure
> enough they hit the x-fader button thinking it would make it a shaper cut,
> which it doesnt.
>
> Oh and one last thing....use the pretty blue lights sparingly.  The PCF
> curve tweak knobby thingies get annoying real quick.  Specially when
someone
> doesn't know how to use em and have the knob turned the wrong way and they
> think they're gonna do something cool and in fact it does the exact
opposite
> of what they wanted to do.  Oh and beware of fader flicking on the x-fader
> and the lateral faders as the knobs like to fly off at high speeds.
>
> Other then that it's a pretty solid mixer.  it's held up to lost of
parties
> and still works like a charm.  I wouldnt buy one for myself as it's cost
to
> feature aspects are severelly out of proportion, but it's a solid mixer
none
> the less.
> --
> Chester Copperpot
>
> "Goonies never say die!"
> "Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
> "I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

the

Subject: [sfraves] chicago

Alright so I love SF and all I can't ever see moving and the diversity of
music is great and all, but, was back home for Xmas and in ONE FUCKING
WEEKEND I got to see: Heather, Diz, Little Louie Vega, Gene Farris,
Derrick Carter, Dan X, Justin Long, James Curd from Greenskeepers, and
some other locals I love but SF folk probably wouldn' know.  Haven't
danced that much in one weekend for a lonnnggg time.

I don't know how many househeads are actually on this list but talk about
a reneducation, I really wish this city had more of teh straight up jack
and funk and jazz and soul in it's house music. :(  Too much electro and
glitch in the scene for me right now, I like a bit of it but I'm on
overload out here.  Still better than anywhere else in the US though so
whateva.

A

Looks like Chicago is alive and well again.  I heard for a while it was on
the skids, but the last few years it's made a rebound.  SF needs to retrace
it's influences back to chicago and new york house again, I'm gettin' reall=
y
sick of this bouncey-bounce house!  I miss quality deep and funky house lik=
e
onionz, h-foundation and dubtribe  :(

On 12/29/05, Rollin' wit da Phelan <mailinglists@djandrewphelan.com> wrote:
>
> Alright so I love SF and all I can't ever see moving and the diversity of
> music is great and all, but, was back home for Xmas and in ONE FUCKING
> WEEKEND I got to see: Heather, Diz, Little Louie Vega, Gene Farris,
> Derrick Carter, Dan X, Justin Long, James Curd from Greenskeepers, and
> some other locals I love but SF folk probably wouldn' know.  Haven't
> danced that much in one weekend for a lonnnggg time.
>
> I don't know how many househeads are actually on this list but talk about
> a reneducation, I really wish this city had more of teh straight up jack
> and funk and jazz and soul in it's house music. :(  Too much electro and
> glitch in the scene for me right now, I like a bit of it but I'm on
> overload out here.  Still better than anywhere else in the US though so
> whateva.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] chicago

No shit - I want to murder BBB for shitting all over good house and making 
people think they have to play 600 records in an hour to be "cool".

But it's wierd to hear people talk about SF not having good house. I mean, 
when I think deep, dubby, tribally house - I think SF.

H-Foundation, Dano, Tony, Garth, Dubtribe, Red Melon, Tango, Siesta, SWAT, 
M3 ....

I guess I don't go out and listen to that much house these days - but I have 
a hard time believing that NO ONE plays that kinda house here anymore. I've 
heard it out at Club 6, Butter, Lingba Lounge and some other spots here and 
there...but is that it?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] chicago

How ironic! I'm new to this list - I just joined a few weeks ago when
I arrived in Chicago for new job training and in my spare time started
immediately missing the familiar SF dance vibes I had come to know and
love.

I thought about asking for advice on where to start looking for
fantastic danceable music (some house and breaks would be lovely) but
somehow never got round to it. I guess that's why you have to speak up
on these things!

Lesson learned... Advice then, on where to find out what's out there
in this new-to-me city? I'll be back in SF for New Year's, but staying
in Chicago after that until mid-February.

sunshine day!
teresa.

> I dunno the SF house sound is kind boring to me.  Grated dubtribe and jen=

> and grarth are awesome.  But the people who spin that repeadative triball=
y
> congo maddness house annoy me.  I like Hipp-e and Halo, but most of the
> H-foundation tracks the last couple of years have been really boring for
> me.  Same with Onionz.  I like his sets, but some of the tracks he pumps =
out
> are more boring then minimal techno.  Too many bongos and earthy bass
> sounds.  Not enough funk to it.  DJ Dan plays a lot of the funkier stuff =
i
> dig (when he's trying to stray away from the funky tech-house sound, whic=
h
> can be kinda boring in large amounts too) Donald Glaude too...  I don't
> really hear a lot of that style houes from other DJ's at least not locall=
y.
>






> Justin Hale does a good job bringing back that kinda funk, major props to
> him for that.  I know there's a few others, but their names escape me.




That Andrew Phelan fellow plays some funky stuff, and i love chicago house,
> but sometimes that can be a little to "tracky" for me and sometimes the
> horns can be over done, but it still holds that funky bassline which i lo=
ve
> so much.




But when it comes to the SF sound (at least over the last couple of years)
> *BARF* I'm so over the congo madness music.




BBB definatly sucks now, but back in the day he fucking rocked.  When he
> played real Hard House and not just this funky tech house stuff mixed ver=
y
> quickly.  Poogie Bear, Mark V, The Klubbheads all that Chicago Hard House=
 is
> fucking dope.  I can never get enough of BBB's Bangin the Box 1-4 and the
> House connection 1 and 2.  After that Hard House for the most part
> disappeared.  I know there are some locals who still play it, but it's no=
t
> the same.  They made it less bouncy/booty and more hardcore-ish and sped =
it
> up even more and mix it longer and it just makes it sound like crap.

---
 From: "Ben Haus" <benhaus@gmail.com>
Sent: Thursday, December 29, 2005 8:44 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] chicago

Imperial Dub is your GOD   haha

NO MORE OF THIS PLAYING 6 HOURS OF THE SAME STUFF ALL NIGHT!!!
---
 
 Yeah- the passing of IDR hit me nearly as hard as the shit-ifying of the Top.  Two institutions that meant "San Francisco" going down in rather quick succession.  With the advent of mega-coke-culture and the bleep-bloopifying of the music to the detriment of its musicality, the ug house club scene has begun more and more to resemble the ratty, bratty cousin of mainstream clubbing, instead of the primal, connected experience it had been at IDR, Come-Unity, and related parties.  This has been either a revelation or a curse, depending on who you ask.  Your shoes *will* get more attention now, if they're fly.  Just don't expect to stumble out of 6 as the sun comes up having made 4 new friends and danced your ass off all night.
 
 I love bleepy house, don't get me wrong, but it feels like there are some social changes neccesary in the cold, hard electro-clashy culture it seems to be coddling.  When I go to rock or punk shows these days I see much the same thing.  Posturing poseurs flaunting elaborate getups and even more elaborately practiced sneers and goose-step crack dancing.  Who wants that on the dance floor?  Does anyone here get a charge out of that?  Am I missing the point?
 
 I read someplace recently that Pink has replaced The Top for a lot of people.  I wish I could understand why.  $400 bottles of bubbly proudly hocked from mirrored signs, fashion-centric vibe, less than inspiring soundsystem, dj up on a pedestal, the whole place being too clean and modern-design-y to inspire any level of kickbackery..
 
 To me, on a good night there are many many small clubs in the city that could have taken that mantle.  Hell, UGSF itself could have learned from its mistakes and regained its crowd instead of fracturing off into whatever it's doing.  Anu can be downright cosy and vibey on a good night.  Even Wish, Butter, etc have their good times.  Oh well.
 
 I feel like I'd better get a prison tattoo of an eagle with lightning bolts in its mouth across my arm if I'mma be cool right now..  
 
 
 ---
On 12/29/05, Alex Laughlin <aldendy@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Deep house is the devil, it's the worst music in the world. I'm all about
> some bangin' funky house, though.
---
 
 Deep house as it's been co-opted by the supa-vocal-smooth-R&B-but-wait-it's-got-a-weak-house-beat-let's-call-it-house crowd, I'll agree, IS the devil.  Makes me unproud to call myself a house producer.  Deep house in the Chicago, SF, even London (sometimes) tradition is, well, pretty damn sublime.  Without the deep you wouldn't notice how bangin' the funky shit is, anyway.  You'd be at 100% all the time- that's no kind of listening experience..
 
 (unless you're into hardcore, which actually IS the devil..  ;) ;) ;) ;) *wink* *nudge* *j/k*
 
 Argh, 
 -gee out

------=_Part_19366_4867108.1135880082999
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Any warehouse with high ceilings and a big sound system.  I'm not really
partial to any clubs but I would prefer to go to places with top notch soun=
d
like 1015, Mighty and Mezzanine.  Primal/Get Underground used to have some
sick parties at Club 6, but when the lower room gets going, the ceiling
starts dripping with sweat and it starts to feel more like a steam room tha=
n
a club.

Fav party at the moment, albeit it only happens about 1-2x / year is
Markie's Alumni Parties, althought I just wish he would do it somewhere
other than DNA Lounge.

Raindance has done some crazy parties in the last year as well, even though
they tend to cater more to a breaks audience.

The things I like about SF House: the trippy psychedellic, acid, funk
driven, deeeeep organic stuff mixed in with funky, acid and electro breaks.

The things I dislike:  bouncey bounce house from texas that has infected SF
which caters to a more yuppiefied house audience; ie Joey Youngman + others
have totally infected SF and ruined one of my fav labels;
Tango/Nightshift/Detour
And Om Records!  I used to like this label- and they do still put out some
decent stuff, but the majority of deep house on there now totally boooores
me.... like kaskades stuff.. zzzzz

"I love bleepy house, don't get me wrong, but it feels like there are some 
social changes neccesary in the cold, hard electro-clashy culture it seems 
to be coddling.  When I go to rock or punk shows these days I see much the 
same thing.  Posturing poseurs flaunting elaborate getups and even more 
elaborately practiced sneers and goose-step crack dancing.  Who wants that 
on the dance floor?  Does anyone here get a charge out of that?  Am I 
missing the point?"

> ---
> From: "Ben Haus" <benhaus@gmail.com>
> Sent: Thursday, December 29, 2005 8:44 AM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] chicago
>
> Imperial Dub is your GOD   haha
>
> NO MORE OF THIS PLAYING 6 HOURS OF THE SAME STUFF ALL NIGHT!!!
> ---
>
> Yeah- the passing of IDR hit me nearly as hard as the shit-ifying of the 
> Top.  Two institutions that meant "San Francisco" going down in rather 
> quick succession.  With the advent of mega-coke-culture and the 
> bleep-bloopifying of the music to the detriment of its musicality, the ug 
> house club scene has begun more and more to resemble the ratty, bratty 
> cousin of mainstream clubbing, instead of the primal, connected experience 
> it had been at IDR, Come-Unity, and related parties.  This has been either 
> a revelation or a curse, depending on who you ask.  Your shoes *will* get 
> more attention now, if they're fly.  Just don't expect to stumble out of 6 
> as the sun comes up having made 4 new friends and danced your ass off all 
> night.
>
> I love bleepy house, don't get me wrong, but it feels like there are some 
> social changes neccesary in the cold, hard electro-clashy culture it seems 
> to be coddling.  When I go to rock or punk shows these days I see much the 
> same thing.  Posturing poseurs flaunting elaborate getups and even more 
> elaborately practiced sneers and goose-step crack dancing.  Who wants that 
> on the dance floor?  Does anyone here get a charge out of that?  Am I 
> missing the point?
>
> I read someplace recently that Pink has replaced The Top for a lot of 
> people.  I wish I could understand why.  $400 bottles of bubbly proudly 
> hocked from mirrored signs, fashion-centric vibe, less than inspiring 
> soundsystem, dj up on a pedestal, the whole place being too clean and 
> modern-design-y to inspire any level of kickbackery..
>
> To me, on a good night there are many many small clubs in the city that 
> could have taken that mantle.  Hell, UGSF itself could have learned from 
> its mistakes and regained its crowd instead of fracturing off into 
> whatever it's doing.  Anu can be downright cosy and vibey on a good night. 
> Even Wish, Butter, etc have their good times.  Oh well.
>
> I feel like I'd better get a prison tattoo of an eagle with lightning 
> bolts in its mouth across my arm if I'mma be cool right now..
>
>
> ---
> On 12/29/05, Alex Laughlin <aldendy@gmail.com> wrote:
>>
>> Deep house is the devil, it's the worst music in the world. I'm all about
>> some bangin' funky house, though.
> ---
>
> Deep house as it's been co-opted by the 
> supa-vocal-smooth-R&B-but-wait-it's-got-a-weak-house-beat-let's-call-it-house 
> crowd, I'll agree, IS the devil.  Makes me unproud to call myself a house 
> producer.  Deep house in the Chicago, SF, even London (sometimes) 
> tradition is, well, pretty damn sublime.  Without the deep you wouldn't 
> notice how bangin' the funky shit is, anyway.  You'd be at 100% all the 
> time- that's no kind of listening experience..
>
> (unless you're into hardcore, which actually IS the devil..  ;) ;) ;) ;) 
> *wink* *nudge* *j/k*
>
> Argh,
> -gee out

Subject: Re: [sfraves] your favorite house nights, venues, djs

I don't know enough about the house scene here to say - but...

DJ's/Producers:
M3
Iz & Diz
Garth
Mark Farina (I still love him - u can all fuck off)
East Coast Boogiemen
Dano
Jeno
Danny Tenaglia

and on the techy/electro-y or proggy tip(s):
John Tejada
John Acqaviva
Lee Burridge
Craig Richards
James Zabiela


I like those sorts of folks cuz they tend to really work mixes. Take your 
ears and feet on a journey. That's why I can't stand DJs like BBB - it's 
just this relentless pounding with cheesey "quick" mixes. And WAY too fast. 
I like my house at like - 128 bpm's tops. None of this 130 and up crap. 
That's for breakbeats dammit. I like DJs who bring a groove to the floor. If 
I wanted pounding beats - I'd go for straight up techno....

That's why I love Markie's Alumni parties.  Before EDM was completely
splintered into all these subgenre's you could hear a mix of house, techno,
trance (the good shit IMO!) and breakbeats all being played in the same roo=
m
over the period of the night.  That's also why I love dj's like Jeno, Garth
and Francois K, they're not scared to dig deep into the crates and shy away
from what the crowd expects a dj to spin.  Which just reminded me I have a
mix of LTJ bukem from 1991i found recently spinning straight up house  :)))=
)

t
> on the dance floor?  Does anyone here get a charge out of that?  Am I
> missing the point?"

> > cousin of mainstream clubbing, instead of the primal, connected

> > it had been at IDR, Come-Unity, and related parties.  This has been

> the

> > elaborately practiced sneers and goose-step crack dancing.  Who wants
> that
> > on the dance floor?  Does anyone here get a charge out of that?  Am I
> > missing the point?
> >
> > I read someplace recently that Pink has replaced The Top for a lot of
> > people.  I wish I could understand why.  $400 bottles of bubbly proudly
> > hocked from mirrored signs, fashion-centric vibe, less than inspiring
> > soundsystem, dj up on a pedestal, the whole place being too clean and
> > modern-design-y to inspire any level of kickbackery..
> >
> > To me, on a good night there are many many small clubs in the city that
> > could have taken that mantle.  Hell, UGSF itself could have learned fro=
m
> > its mistakes and regained its crowd instead of fracturing off into
> > whatever it's doing.  Anu can be downright cosy and vibey on a good
> night.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Opel's Infuse NYE - $40 presales available, $50 at the door

>From Syd Gris:

The champagne is bought, the decorations worked out, the art planned,
the breakfast all set, and all the things we will provide are in
place. Now we just need you, in your full color and beauty and
splendor. Really looking forward to seeing you at Infuse NYE: The
Rekindling of Hope, what will certainly be a sanctuary of good music,
vibes, and people on New Years Eve.

Saturday, December 31st: New Years Eve 2006

Opel presents Infuse NYE: The Rekindling of Hope
w/
Lee Coombs (Thrust / Perfecto / Fingerlickin', UK)
Dylan Rhymes (Kingsize / Lot 49, UK)
Jondi & Spesh (Qool / Looq)
Syd Gris (Opel / Opulent Temple)
Ethan Miller v. ViaJay (Friends n' Family)
Hoj (Opel / djhoj.com)
Melyss (Opel / Sister SF)
Fred Funk (Brass Tax)
Aaron Jae v. Bam (Evil Breaks / sfbreaks.org)
+ more

All the NYE fixins and a sanctuary of music, vibe and people on NYE.

9pm- till you stop dancing
DNA Lounge
375 11th St. @ Harrison St.


Main:

9-10 Shanti
10-11 Fred Funk
11-12 Hoj
12-2 Lee Coombs
2-3:30 Dylan Rhymes
3:30-4:30 Bassbin Twins
4:30-6 Aaron Jae vs. Bam
6-? Open for whatever happens...

Up:

10:30-11:55 Ethan Miller v. Viajay
12:05-1:15 Melyss
1:15-2:30 Scott Carrelli
2:30-4:15 Jondi & Spesh
4:15-5:30 Syd Gris


Light Dancing and other performance art, midnight ceremony and
countdown, complimentary champagne toast, 2 rooms of breaks, house,
progressive and trance, lounge areas, ins and outs all night, visuals
by On the Fly Films, outdoor smoking area, NYE party favors, free
breakfast at 5am, decor by the Opulent Temple and Analogia.

The NYE tix update: If you're still undecided take note our party is
guaranteed quality in terms of crowd, vibe, and price. Other all-
night NYE parties with this much to offer are anywhere between $70 and
a $100, ours is $50 and will stay there. There's still around 20 $40
tix left at BPM. Their hours today are 11-7. They won't last long!
Then they're $50 there, as well as on line but getting them at BPM
saves you the service charge if you can make it down there. On line
tix available   HERE.

Pre-sales are recommended. You are guaranteed entry anytime even if we
sell out (and we might, actually), and you use your own VIP express
line (not the general admission line). If you already have tix well
done! If you're spending midnight with us (we hope you are!), give
yourself plenty of time to park and get in.

We're seriously going to rock it.

--

On Thu, 29 Dec 2005, georgeC | origami wrote:
-&e-> Yeah- the passing of IDR hit me nearly as hard as the shit-ifying of 
-&e->the Top.  Two institutions that meant "San Francisco" going down in 
-&e->rather quick succession.  With the advent of mega-coke-culture and 
-&e->the bleep-bloopifying of the music to the detriment of its 
-&e->musicality, the ug house club scene has begun more and more to 
-&e->resemble the ratty, bratty cousin of mainstream clubbing, instead of 
-&e->the primal, connected experience it had been at IDR, Come-Unity, and 
-&e->related parties.  This has been either a revelation or a curse, 
-&e->depending on who you ask.  Your shoes *will* get more attention now, 
-&e->if they're fly.  Just don't expect to stumble out of 6 as the sun 
-&e->comes up having made 4 new friends and danced your ass off all night.
-&e-> 
-&e-> I love bleepy house, don't get me wrong, but it feels like there are 
-&e->some social changes neccesary in the cold, hard electro-clashy 
-&e->culture it seems to be coddling.  When I go to rock or punk shows 
-&e->these days I see much the same thing.  Posturing poseurs flaunting 
-&e->elaborate getups and even more elaborately practiced sneers and 
-&e->goose-step crack dancing.  Who wants that on the dance floor?  Does 
-&e->anyone here get a charge out of that?  Am I missing the point?
-&e-> 
-&e-> I read someplace recently that Pink has replaced The Top for a lot 
-&e->of people.  I wish I could understand why.  $400 bottles of bubbly 
-&e->proudly hocked from mirrored signs, fashion-centric vibe, less than 
-&e->inspiring soundsystem, dj up on a pedestal, the whole place being too 
-&e->clean and modern-design-y to inspire any level of kickbackery..
-&e-> 
-&e-> To me, on a good night there are many many small clubs in the city 
-&e->that could have taken that mantle.  Hell, UGSF itself could have 
-&e->learned from its mistakes and regained its crowd instead of 
-&e->fracturing off into whatever it's doing.  Anu can be downright cosy 
-&e->and vibey on a good night.  Even Wish, Butter, etc have their good 
-&e->times.  Oh well.
-&e-> 
-&e-> I feel like I'd better get a prison tattoo of an eagle with 
-&e->lightning bolts in its mouth across my arm if I'mma be cool right 
-&e->now..

OMG, did what I've been doing the last like 10 years just become cool?  I 
TOTALLY WRITE BLIP!  I'VE WRITTEN SOFTWARE THAT WRITES BLIP FOR ME EVEN!!  
Now I just need to get a bad tatoo of an eagle holding a bleeding heart in 
one talon and crushing a beercan with the other?

"what does your tatoo mean anti-w?"

"it doesn't mean anything to me baby, just like you. just keep sucking 
and try not to move your head up too much, it skips the decks"

Pickup lines like "nice shoes babe, they'd look great next to mine on the 
floor of a cheap motel" and "hey baby, you look kinda tweaky... you know 
what takes the edge off that TOO MUCH COCAINE feeling baby?  More 
cocaine... you know you want it, I'm Hollywood actor Beck Bristow".

News flash... the trance and techno scene grew in the SF underground out 
of the vacous and superficial house club scene of the time.  Ask anybody 
who was there... when I came into all this it was almost antifashion.  A 
raver was visually identified as less a fashion and more just a couple 
little cues (their pants a little wide, the ball chained wallet, the hoody 
and the crooked grin walking home at 8am).  Someone wearing designer this 
and that out the ass was actually seen as somewhat of an outcast.  All 
things in cycles.  The 16-19 year old cheese kids have now left the trance 
massives and are the 22-25 year old beautiful people of the clubs.  
Enjoy.

We identified with E cause we hated coke.  Now E is passe, people have 
more opinions on beverages in an average night than meaningful encounters 
aside from hookups and comparing notes on that girl that just walked by.

As for dark music, well... I love my music minimal, it opens up the places 
that mean the most for me, let's me walk around inside my head.  I miss 
music being a bit more tracky, but the sound you're talking about and what 
I'm referring to a little bit different I think (I'm thinking like "No 
Way Back" by Adonis).  Repetitive, simple, hypnotic, yet funky... very 
electronic and angular with little in the way of "real" sounding strings 
or bass or horns or anything.  But still mostly house.  Like 4am jack 
business.

Golly, wish I was playing house somewhere next month... *whistles*
andyw

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
"Nothing real can defeat us.  Nothing unreal exists." - Buckaroo Banzai
My band **the Lag** LIVE 12/29 @ Stork Club in Oakland  $5 - 21+ - 9:30

On 12/29/05, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
>
>
> On Thu, 29 Dec 2005, georgeC | origami wrote:
> -&e-> Yeah- the passing of IDR hit me nearly as hard as the shit-ifying o=
f
> -&e->the Top.  Two institutions that meant "San Francisco" going down in
> -&e->rather quick succession.  With the advent of mega-coke-culture and
> -&e->the bleep-bloopifying of the music to the detriment of its
> -&e->musicality, the ug house club scene has begun more and more to
> -&e->resemble the ratty, bratty cousin of mainstream clubbing, instead of
> -&e->the primal, connected experience it had been at IDR, Come-Unity, and
> -&e->related parties.  This has been either a revelation or a curse,
> -&e->depending on who you ask.  Your shoes *will* get more attention now,
> -&e->if they're fly.  Just don't expect to stumble out of 6 as the sun
> -&e->comes up having made 4 new friends and danced your ass off all night=
.
> -&e->
> -&e-> I love bleepy house, don't get me wrong, but it feels like there ar=
e
> -&e->some social changes neccesary in the cold, hard electro-clashy
> -&e->culture it seems to be coddling.  When I go to rock or punk shows
> -&e->these days I see much the same thing.  Posturing poseurs flaunting
> -&e->elaborate getups and even more elaborately practiced sneers and
> -&e->goose-step crack dancing.  Who wants that on the dance floor?  Does
> -&e->anyone here get a charge out of that?  Am I missing the point?
> -&e->
> -&e-> I read someplace recently that Pink has replaced The Top for a lot
> -&e->of people.  I wish I could understand why.  $400 bottles of bubbly
> -&e->proudly hocked from mirrored signs, fashion-centric vibe, less than
> -&e->inspiring soundsystem, dj up on a pedestal, the whole place being to=
o
> -&e->clean and modern-design-y to inspire any level of kickbackery..
> -&e->
> -&e-> To me, on a good night there are many many small clubs in the city
> -&e->that could have taken that mantle.  Hell, UGSF itself could have
> -&e->learned from its mistakes and regained its crowd instead of
> -&e->fracturing off into whatever it's doing.  Anu can be downright cosy
> -&e->and vibey on a good night.  Even Wish, Butter, etc have their good
> -&e->times.  Oh well.
> -&e->
> -&e-> I feel like I'd better get a prison tattoo of an eagle with

I have to admit, that's one area where moving from LA to SF has surprised
me...
the lack of deep thumpin' house on the weeknights. In my mind I have this
expectation of the "San Francisco Sound" and yet most of the house I've
heard has been way techier than deep.

>From door to door, my commute takes approximately 90 minutes, perfect for a
nice 90 minute set. Tuesday I listened to a friend's set from an innerweb
radio show I listen to dated 7/22/02 and realized how much of it was what
I'd classify as "San Francisco" house... a few Greyhound tracks, and of
course the classic "hangin' out" jam from Jay-J that I love so much. And
then I thought, hmm. No naked. In the four months I've lived here, I have
not heard a *single* Naked producer/dj spin out. Come to think of it, very
few OM djs either, and none from Moulton or Loveslap. I must remedy this.

Could it be that the sound of San Francisco House is changing?




On 12/29/05, Rollin' wit da Phelan <mailinglists@djandrewphelan.com> wrote:
>
> Alright so I love SF and all I can't ever see moving and the diversity of
> music is great and all, but, was back home for Xmas and in ONE FUCKING
> WEEKEND I got to see: Heather, Diz, Little Louie Vega, Gene Farris,
> Derrick Carter, Dan X, Justin Long, James Curd from Greenskeepers, and
> some other locals I love but SF folk probably wouldn' know.  Haven't
> danced that much in one weekend for a lonnnggg time.
>
> I don't know how many househeads are actually on this list but talk about
> a reneducation, I really wish this city had more of teh straight up jack
> and funk and jazz and soul in it's house music. :(  Too much electro and
> glitch in the scene for me right now, I like a bit of it but I'm on
> overload out here.  Still better than anywhere else in the US though so
> whateva.
>
> A
>
>

To: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>, SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] your favorite house nights, venues, djs

The Liquid:
One place I used to be totally addicted to was the
Liquid (near 16th), but that was a few years ago when
DJ Dave was resident (and there was another white guy
dj-ing with him but I don't know his name, if anyone
knows please tell). The type of music played was
house/progressive house (but not the funky type, more
like dark or tribal). The crowd was also very varied
and fun.
Then the Liquid got bought by new owners (French I
believe), and the atmosphere totally changed (it feels
snobish now, I could develop why), the DJs have
changed and the music I learnt to love at the Liquid
seems to not be played anymore there. 

If anyone knows where DJ Dave (and his white buddy
whose name I don't know) are now mixing I would love
to now !!!

The 1015:
Never really liked it, feels like a fitness center to
make asian kids jump. The music is rather commercial
in the big room and pretty much sucks. The other rooms
are sometimes better (and more Housey !) but quality
varies and there's no real consistency.

111 Minna Street Gallery
Sometimes there's some good house and good crowds
there (Qool parties).

Club6:
The place is event based, so it's a bit a hit or miss,
I went to some exceptional parties with hypnotic
progressive house ruling the night with a packed dance
floor. But then I also went to parties other there
with boring music and empty dancefloors and very
little people staying...

responsible staff. All I ever seem to locate is thieves, con artists,

responsibilities they must uphold. I am now really beginning to
understand why many of my colleagues have gone solo! Is there any light
at the end of the tunnel?

=20

I have used Craig's list, but seem to notice the only people on there
that are not employed..... is because there is a very good reason, THEY
SUCK!=20

=20

universities? Do they often work out for long term positions? I am so
tired of the new-hire and employee retention headaches. Maybe it's time
to start doing more outsourcing and use recruiters again :-(=20

Interns?  IMO, everyone in the IT tech industry (as opposed to IT 
support for another
industry) is treated like an intern.   So much work == mandatory 
overtime, rotten pay,
the threat of H1Bs taking your job (because they're happy to be 
treated like an intern)
The tech industry is basically slave labor and the idea of a union 
for tech people is a good
one, but won't ever fly for various reasons.    Anyone with any sense 
becomes a contractor

And recruiters are evil.  The last one was using NLP on me to beat my 
ego down so I'd accept
a $35 / hr job.   And I have a goddamn Master's

At least in the UK, I get a month's vacation right from the start, 6 
weeks after a few years and
some respect for my master's from one of the top 5 unis in all of Europe.

try offering people a month's vacation and ignore most everything but 
their attitude.   There's
too many tech people in CA with a bad attitude.

doug

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Many thanks to all of you sfravers for the b-day greetings.  Haven't seen most of you for quite a spell.  Miss you.  This has been an Annus Horribilis for my partner and I...and for lots of other folks.

Every time my birthday comes around one tune fires in my brain and takes over for a day or two:  "Sixteen Tons."  I can sing all the lyrics from beginning to end...a literal description of the coal miners' plight and a metaphor for "workers" with blue or modern white collars.  The "company store" is now the mortgage and credit card bank :-)

And so the chorus:  



You load sixteen tons, what do you get?
Another day older and deeper in debt
Saint Peter don't you call me 'cause I can't go
I owe my soul to the company store




Merle Travis wrote and released the song in 1947 and Tennesse Ernie Ford popularized it.  "Sixteen Tons" almost immediately began to generate controversy causing Travis  problems in the anti-communist Cold War hysteria of the late forties. Some in government saw songs dealing with workers' woes, and folk music "activists," as potentially subversive. It made no difference that Travis was a patriot. Veteran Capitol producer, Ken Nelson, who worked at WJJD radio in Chicago in the late forties, recalled in a 1992 interview that FBI agents advised the station not to play Travis' records, because they considered him a "communist sympathizer," which was, of course, completely untrue. 

My father was an old-school country and western fan and I suppose I picked up the lyrics, like many other C&W classics, from listening to them with him.  Still love Hank Williams and, of course, the great Johnny Cash.  

This is probably more than you wanted to know about me and "Sixteen Tons."

Wish you all a New Year full of light and love!!

Apollo









MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

having too many different types of music can be just as annoying if  
not more.  i've always liked the standard configuration of 1 feeding  
1, 2 feeding 2 and 3, like house or whatever the main type of music  
and then a side room with ambient chill out music, and mayybe some  
jungle in a small room as well.   any more than that though, you're  
standing in some dumpy warehouse and all the music coagulates in your  
head and you want to go jump off the nearest bridge.

HAPPY NEW YEARS !!! May 2006 bring you peace and blessings abound, round 
and round, the cyclical nature of life shall astound...
Ouroboros ... teaches us...
As above, so is below.... increase the love and breath of what we know
Bestow and grow in love and light's glow...
Let the darkness be your light ...
All is One
>From dusk to dawn and the setting sun...
The moon by starlight night, stars shining,. glistening bright...

We dance as one in transcendance ....

<3 Karina

SPECIAL NOTICE:
Are you a self-proclaimed Technical Geek who is a Development Guru? Might 
you / your colleagues be interested in becoming
involved with the next generation of the SFRaves Calendar Project?

The SFRaves Calendar is located @ 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2

More information about Zope is located here: http://www.zope.org
All interested parties should have a solid understanding of and 
development experience with authoring and building applications
using the Zope application framework, ZPT, Python, PHP, MYSQL. Plone and 
other languages that might be used to enhance the SFR
Calendar Application.

Please note if you are seeing issues with the current calendar incarnation 
(bugs, errors, etc) please note that I am aware of
them and am currently in the process of addressing / fixing these issues.

Please send responses to karina@hyperreal.org

Alternative solutions are also being considered for the next generation of 
this codebase. This includes other languages specific
to the development of applications in a web environment.

--

******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Champions of the Arena. DeeCee's Soul Shakedown alongside True Skool and 
Daddy Rolo with promotional support from San Francisco Bay Guardian, On 
The Corner Productions, Mr. E, Sake1, PlayAreacodes Spicey Promotions, DJ 
I-CUE.com, and Upper Playground. Bay Area Massive!! New Year's Eve is 
almost here and we are bringing it to you with fiya!! Thanks to all that 
scooped up the $20 tickets ......you didn't sleep on it...... now we got a 
limited $25 tickets..... the price goes up next week...... and you know 
you all hate lines at the clubs so get your presales and go through the 
express line .............so get on it....www.soulshakedown.com
